Praefatio.	Prefatory Note.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished with you, my son, this book which is the last of my works on medicine, completed with the aid of your contributions, I have reached the end of my studies and pronouncements, and I have undertaken to complete it with this treatise which is a part of the art of surgery, that is, medicine with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery in our age is a work of the hands which is being neglected in our times, and since its secrets have vanished from the world, except for brief accounts in the ancient books which have become altered by the hands of men: and there has arisen from this an error and hesitation, until the intentions of the art have been closed and its spirit prolonged: It is necessary for me to bring together in this treatise the order of this art according to its position and pronouncements, and its abbreviations: and to explain the forms of the instruments of cautery and other implements of surgery, in accordance with the pronouncements and their preparation which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why one does not find a perfect artist of this kind in our age is that the art of medicine is vast, and the author must be exercised in the science of anatomy before he can understand the movements of the limbs, their forms, and their connection, and their separation, and to have knowledge of the bones, nerves, and lacerations, and their number, and their exit, and the pulsation of veins, and quietus, and the loci of their exits
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said that the name is great when the work is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already mentioned this at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is ignorant of what we have said concerning anatomy will fall into error, and will cause harm to men: as I have seen many of them who have learned from this science and practice it without science or experience
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What is this, because I saw the doctor seize the scrofula from the woman's throat and it caused some arteries in the throat to burst: why did the woman's blood flow until she died between her hands?
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who presumed to extract a stone from the bladder, which was in the bladder, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	It came to pass that he extracted it with the bladder's husk
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself was called to extract it: and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who took charge of a certain Duke of our land because of a disease: and it happened to a black slave who was with him, a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the doctor, with his ignorance, bound the fracture with nails and pins, and did not allow the wound to drain.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he died according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he dismissed him for a few days, and commanded him not to loosen the ligament: and he remained like that until the bone of his leg and his foot were completely decayed, and he came to his end
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him again: and I advised him to loosen the ligament: and there was peace, and he was freed from his pains
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But indeed corruption was confirmed in the limb: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore the corruption ceased to walk in the limb until it perished
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who perforated a cancerous tumor: and it ulcerated after days, until the malice of the disease increased with the master himself.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	When the cancer is pure and exudes from melancholic humour, it is not permissible to leave it with iron altogether, except in the case where it is in a member that can tolerate it, in which case it should be entirely excised.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And thus, my son, you must know that an operation which is associated with safety is divided into two parts: that which is associated with health, and that which carries the peril in various positions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	I am excited about all the places in this book where the operation is mentioned, which is fraught with terror and fear
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, you must be cautious about this, and be humble: so that you do not speak arrogantly, and become dishonest
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Accept now measure with humility and protection, and the sick with facility and firmness, and utilize the gentler method which carries greater benefit, giving thanks to God for the success and praiseworthy outcome: and dismiss the terrifying diseases which are difficult to heal: and take away the spirits of those who fear them, so that there should arise in you trust in your work and comfort in your soul
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For in this world there remains a lasting memorial to your glory, and a fragrance in this world, and finally in your numbers.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen thus said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You do not cure a bad disease: do not give a bad name to the doctor
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have, however, divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of cautery with fire, and cautery with acute medicine, a chapter, and arranged from the head to the feet, and the forms of instruments and materials for cautery: and everything that is necessary for the operation
Capitulum secundum.	Second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Concerning incision and perforation, bleeding, and packing, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and matters of a like nature: and the whole of this chapter is arranged according to the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Third Chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Concerning restoration, and dislocation, and the treatment of torsion, and matters of a like nature: this chapter is arranged from the head to the feet, and concerning the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Concerning the application of a dressing, and the use of the cautery: and in what complexion it is suitable, and when: and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter I
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before any operation is undertaken, it is necessary to state the quality of the dressing and instruments to be used: and in what complexion it should be displayed
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say, therefore, that the discourse concerning the quality of the cautery dressing and its instrument is a lengthy, subtle, scientific, and secret discourse.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And it has been said by many learned men, and they have differed in their opinion: and indeed little is sufficient from their discourses, fearing the length of the matter
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say, therefore, that the cautery is applicable to all complexions, that is, with matter and without matter: except for two complexions, which are the hot complexion without matter, and the dry complexion without matter
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	In the hot and dry complexion with matter they disagree
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some have said that the Cauterium is used for incisions.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others have said the opposite, namely that the Cauterium is unsuitable for wounds due to their heat and dryness: for fire is by its nature hot, and it is unsuitable to heal wounds by heat and dryness when they require warmth and moisture.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And some have said the opposite of that: that the Cauterium makes incisions in all wounds which arise in the bodies of men: for when you compare the body of a man to the heat of the fire, you find the body of a man to be cold to the touch
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	I myself have observed in practice that it is often useful
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	It is true that in some cases the Cauterium is useful. However, it should not be used without prior experience and a thorough understanding of the various types of wounds, their causes and symptoms, and the time required for their healing.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Except in the case of very severe wounds, there is no reason to fear the Cauterium: and especially in wounds that are cold and wet.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	I have observed that all doctors concur in their use of the Cauterium in such cases.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	Note that the Cauterium is safe when used with fire and promotes healing along with medicinal herbs: for fire is simple, and its action does not extend beyond the part which is cauterized; and it does not harm any other connected member, except for a slight burning sensation.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The medicinal properties of the burn do not extend beyond the part which is cauterized: and it may even cause difficulty in the healing of the wound, and even death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the excellence of its matter, does not do this unless it is excessive
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that is done in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But that is done in few.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But that is done in few.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	But that is done in few
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is done in few
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	But that is done in few
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But that is done in few
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	But that is done in few
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	But that is done in few
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	But that is done in few
Caput II.	But that is done in few
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	But that is done in few
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: first of all, the physician should evacuate the patient with a solution of urine that will alter the head for three nights, or four, as the nature of the patient's ailment, age, and habits demand.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to make a circular burn on the head with a needle
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands, so that his hands are placed over his belly
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then put the root of your thumb on the root of his nose between his eyes
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever his middle finger reaches, that is the place to make the burn.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then ignite the Cauterium Oil: thus is its shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the designated place with the burn, with a gradual descending movement, until your hand is grasped, and then withdraw it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly lift your hand and look at the place
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that there is already a quantity of hair equal to the head or the nails, then lift your hand immediately
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the process with the iron alone, or with something else if it becomes cold: until you see the bones, as I have told you
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink it, and put it on the place: and keep it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put on it a buttered dressing, and remove the burn from the place until the eschar is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have said that the more a wound remains open, the more pus it emits: which is better and more advantageous.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	Some have said that the skin should be cauterized until the bone is reached: and the cautery should be retained until the substance of the bone has hardened
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it is withdrawn after that which has been cast off from the bone, and it is cured.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	Others say that the cautery should be continued until it makes an imprint in the bone, so that the bone breaks, like the form of a chisel, or like the instrument which women put into the bath with a small letter: and they say that from this place arise vapors of the head, and the wound remains open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it is cured, until the fracture is consolidated
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	I, however, do not approve of two kinds of cautery in general, except in some people according to their fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And I send it away, for with me it is better for the health of the patient.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head grows weak from the continuity of its natural solution: as we have witnessed in the rest of the limbs: and especially when the head of the patient is weak by nature: and the first kind of cautery is more safe and better for me than the other, and it is useful: to work with it for the health of the patient
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	In the case of cauterizing the head in the case of general pain of the head.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is chronic pain in the whole head: and it persists in the patient, and boils, and abscesses, and headaches, and ointments, and applications are used
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	If, therefore, the burn has been cauterized with one cautery, as we have said, and nothing further adheres to it: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	If the patient's head is strong in nature and not weak, and he experiences a feeling of heat: then reburn with another cautery under that.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then burn the entire circumference of the head with the cautery, but do not pass through the skin, and uncover the quantity of bone as we have said.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	Burn the cautery once on the back of the head in the place which is called the uas: for that is the place where the bone is placed. Raise the burn upwards in this way, and do not uncover the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	The patient feels pain because of this heat, and different from the pain of the other cauteries of the head in general.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	I say this: The cautery is to be applied in this place: the horns of the head are to be cauterized with one cautery, while the back of the head is to be cauterized with a finer cautery.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	In the treatment of hemophilia, both with medicinal herbs and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occur in any part of the head, or if the pain extends as far as the eye, and it evacuates with physicians who apply soothing remedies to the head, and the rest of the treatment is administered as I have said in the treatise on diseases, and nothing more: then the burning in this case is done in two ways: either with acute burning medicine or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The burning with acute burning medicine is as follows: take a tooth of another, and burn the area with it, and remove the extremities from both sides
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then sever the place of pain at the time with a wide lancet, until it be made in that place under the skin, where the teeth capture.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then insert it thus into the very under-skin, until it is hidden: then tighten above it with a thread of constriction of a fair measure, and keep it bound for fifteen hours. Then take it away, and evacuate the wound for two or three days. Afterwards place above it the lower part of the limb submerged in butter, until the place has yielded pus: then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you do this with some physicians who are learned in burn injuries, whom I have written about in the twelfth tractate on physicians who are learned in burns.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	The cauterization of it is like this with iron.</start_of_turn>
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The iron for the cautery, which is like this in shape.</start_of_turn>
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Claudius: because the shape of its head is like the shape of a key, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle of it there is a small prominence.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it above the place, and hold your hand: and withdraw the iron gradually with speed: and let the quantity which is to be cauterized from the thickness of the skin be like half of it.</start_of_turn
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand, so that it does not burn the artery which is beneath, and that the flow of blood does not increase.</start_of_turn
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the limb in salt-water, and place it above the place, and leave it for three days: then place the limb in butter: afterwards care for it with ointment until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this half-circle with the second extremity of the cautery.</start_of_turn
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And indeed from the incision of the artery in this hemisphere, not in the former manner.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	And indeed from the incision of the artery in this hemisphere, not in the former manner.
Caput V.	And indeed from the incision of the artery in this hemisphere, not in the former manner.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are treating a hemiplegia, when you have done what we said concerning the treatment of preceding diseases, and when you have said concerning the methods of treatment, and it does not suffice: then you must cauterize the tissue with a needle until it turns white when you touch it at the place of the pain with a line whose length is half of a digit, or as much as that: and lay your hand aside and grasp the needle until you have cut through the artery, and hold it until you reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	It is true that you must take care that you do not cause the continuation of the mandible to move during mastication, neither to become hardened, or the nerve which moves it, from which the spasm arises.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be careful of the safety of the flow of blood in the artery that has been cut
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in the cutting of it there is fear, and especially for him who is ignorant of this and is not studious, or not an expert: and he departs from the operation at once.</start_of_turn>
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with the reminder of the regimen of the flow of blood that has occurred from the artery according to its custom, and in its place here in this book.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you are aware of the disease that does not suffice with this Cauterium, and if you are aware that the body of the patient tolerates Cauterium in the middle of the head, as we have said, then take care of the wound, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if necessary, administer Cauterium, as we have said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with Cauterium having two blades.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	It is better to cauterize than to leave it open.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	As to the cauterization of the ear in pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens in the ear pain from cold, and it is cured with solutions, and the rest of the treatment as we have said in the previous discourse, and the pain is not relieved, then ignite Cauterium: and that is what is called the Punctum, which has this shape
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then burn the Punctum with this after its ignition around the entire ear, as it is rotated: or around both sides, if the pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And prolong it with Cauterium to the root of the ear beside, after you have marked the place with the burn: and let the quantity of Cauterium be ten points in each ear, and as much as that
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then care for the place, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	As to the cauterization of a burn
Caput VII.	Chapter VII
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	A burn which is cured by cauterization is not except from those which arise from phlegm, as we have said in the discourse on diseases
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And you must cauterize the species which arise from exiccation and nervous spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you have cured this species of burn with urine, and saffron, and blisters, and the cure does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize the diseased part with three Cauteriums: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little lower from its edge, and the third at the junction of the two lips
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cautery from the opposite side of the lower part which is diseased.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the softening does not take place, unless in the part which appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	The form of cauterization is that you cauterize with the cautery itself at the direct extremity of the upper ear under the horn of the head somewhat: and at the same time in the temple: whose length is as long as the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cautery until the quantity of middle part of the thickness of the skin is burned
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	This is the form of the cautery, and it is like a knife, whose shape is like this: truly it is not finer than that of a needle: and it must be that the knife is in that place somewhat superficial
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place, with that which went before: until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	Thus the cautery is to be used in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When the ancient apoplexy has become chronic, and when your medicine has not been of avail, and the sick man does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries over all the horns of his head, and a cautery in the middle of the head, as we have said, and a cautery in the back of the head, as we have said before: and the manner of cautery is as we have said before
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also to be cauterized with the cautery over the bones of the stomach: and this is the last method.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the patient, as we have said before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	Thus the cautery is to be used in oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	The head should be placed in the first place in the bath, and the nourishing pills should be given to the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then the whole head of the patient should be washed, and upon the crown of his head should be placed a compress of rue described in the treatise on compresses: and let him put it on several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the manner of the Cautery: and do this according to the order which I have said above.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make for him three cauteries on the back of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and put between every cautery the breadth of a finger
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then take care of the cauteries, as has been said before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	And if you wish to make an addition, and the patient is able to tolerate it: then make for him a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	And if you wish to make an addition: then cauterize the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then take care of it, until he is healed: and let the cautery be done according to its form, as has been said before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	Thus cauterize in Paralysis, and for mollification.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	You must proceed in the treatment of the head with oil, and as has been said above
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then wash the head of the patient: then cauterize the middle of the head, and the cautery on every horn of the head, and the cautery on the back of his head, and three on the bones of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, the digestion is difficult in the inflammation of the body because of the numerous bodies, and the patient is tolerant, and the inflammation is strong: then burn it with four burnings over the spines of the back, and the last one with the fourth, until it is consumed from the utmost part of it, and lift up your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for it until it is healed: and thus burn olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	In the manner of burning in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.</start_of_turn>
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic patient is not to be burned, except for that in whom the epilepsy proceeds from phlegm.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary therefore to temper the brain of him in the first place with herbs, and with the rest of the treatment as we have said in the preceding discourse: when the patient is great, or is tolerant in receiving the medicines.</start_of_turn
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, he is a child, who does not tolerate the medicines, then is administered a gargling and nourishing of the brain with food for many days before the benefit of the nourishment of the body.</start_of_turn
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then temper his head, afterwards burn it with one burning in the middle of the head, as we have said before in the manner: and with another burning on the back of his head, and over all the hair of his head burn with a third burning.</start_of_turn
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	And if the patient is strong and is tolerant, then burn it with burnings, which I have said in the case of paralysis, and mollification of the body over the spines of the neck and the spines of the back: and let the burning be with olive oil as before.</start_of_turn
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If, however, the patient is a child, then place the burning under cover, according to this method.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterization in Melancholia.
Caput XII.	On the method of cauterization in Melancholia.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupt humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with cauteries, as we have said in one having paralysis
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	When the cause of melancholy is excessive coldness and leads to melancholy, and the body of the patient is soft and wet, then take from it in the belly what will temper the brain of the patient: as it has been said before in the explanation. Then cut off the head of the patient and make a circle from the entrails of the intestines.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then put it in the middle of the head: and the patient sitting upright is to be held fast from all sides
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply linimentum.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is better from old butter or oil
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a tempered fire, as the finger can tolerate when it is introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of the head in a circle, and keep it until it is cold to the touch
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the patient every week once, with the rest of his treatment being good, until he is healed
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you will, cauterize it by making many small punctures of it, besides which you will hold the hand with the cautery: for it will smell badly.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For these are the qualities of cauterization which humectate the brain.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put over it a bandage soaked in butter, or fat from a hen
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the method of cauterization in descending water to the eye
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the water in the eye is declared ready by the signs which I mentioned previously, then begin and instill the potion, with that which will modify its head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep it away from all moistnesses, and make it sit in a warm bath for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command it to raise its head, and cauterize it in the middle of its head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over two tempora with two cautery instruments: if there is an incipient descent of water in both eyes simultaneously: or from one side only, if there is an incipient descent of water in only one eye: and cut away with the cautery all veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let there be blisters in those which are long in the width of the tempora: and burn from the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	And if anything escapes from it, then immediately cut it away with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and the cutting away of them, and care for the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized in the pupil, under two bones, with two last cautery instruments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	Thus cauterizing in the ancient tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIIIII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, thick: and are upon the veins and arteries which are in the exterior of the head, it is verified that this is from excessive cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the same instrument which I mentioned in the beginning concerning the incipient descent of water, the cautery in the middle of the head, and with two cautery instruments over two tempora, and with two cautery instruments in the pupil under two bones
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if digestion is insufficient, then cauterize it throughout all the sides cautiously around the eye, over the end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	In the eyebrow region, cauterize cautiously around the eye, over the end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating this and it does not yield to medication, as we have mentioned previously, then cleanse it and give the patient three baths at night: then remove its head and cauterize it with a middle-sized cautery, with olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two cauteries of claws, over the two eyebrows under the hair somewhat
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And keep away from the artery, so that you do not damage it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of cautery with claws
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	In the softening of the Palpebrae (eyelids).
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened by heat or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with a single cautery, like a lunar cautery
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it over the two eyebrows somewhat with two cauteries in all parts: and extend from two points for two times: and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow: and do not put your hand too close to the cautery, but according to the amount that is to be burnt of the third of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of cautery in this manner of lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	When the hair is burned by the incandescence of the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is of two kinds: either with fire or with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cautery with fire, the patient must precede the instrument, so that it may expel its hair, if there are any that move in the area, until the hair is prolonged and even
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If, however, it pricks them at their root: then compress their eyes with a bandage, so that they do not move, until they are healed.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are healed and even, then place the patient's head in your lap: then mark over the eyelashes with charcoal, according to the figure of a myrtle leaf: and this is the beginning of the mark, close to the hair
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then put on a soaked cushion on the edge of the eye: or on the hair of the eyelashes over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then burn the cautery, which is of this shape.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then burn over the figure which you have marked gradually in many places, until the surface of the skin is burnt, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, throughout.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	The sign of the completion of your work is that if you press the eyeball the eyelashes recoil from the puncture point.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then withdraw your hand: and let it go in three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then put on the cushion again with butter, until the eschar has disappeared
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any hair remains after an hour, and the eyelashes are softened: then repeat the cautery in the same place as before
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If, however, the hairs are in the lower part: then cauterize it itself, until they rise to their natural place: and make even so that they do not puncture the eyes.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In such a case, cauterize with the burning medicine in the same way
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is necessary to command the patient to discharge the hair, until they grow long and be made even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from parchment a form like the leaf of myrtle.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from soap known, and from chalk not soaked from any liquid whatsoever a weight of an ounce or almost like that: then smear it together well, and do this with care, so that it does not freeze
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from the palm of your hand the thing which you made like the leaf of myrtle and put it over the eye or eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And put under the eye a bit soaked in albumen or oil: and keep the patient's head in your hand.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And put your index finger on the medicine and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move it whenever the patient feels the biting of the medicine: because its biting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	When you have finished this, then discharge the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the biting has ceased, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	Consider then, if the eye is raised towards the contraction like that which happens with fire, or with an incision, it is well done: and if not, then repeat the medicine over the place where the medicine does not leave its mark, and does not irritate, until your operation is complete and the eye is contracted
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place above the aforesaid Cotum with butter, until the skin of the wound is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with an ointment of diaphanicon, or something like it, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary that you should keep guard after the operation, lest anything from the medicine should fall into the eye.</start_of_turn
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eye becomes soft after a day, and something from the hair has fought its way into the eye, then repeat the medicine upon the place that is softened from the eye itself, as you did at first.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you know that the eyes of men differ in size and in shape.</start_of_turn
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore you must take this into consideration: and do not hide the truth of rectitude from her who is skilled in this art.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	As regards the cauterizing of the fistula of the tear duct.</start_of_turn
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.</start_of_turn
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating the fistula, when it is not responding to your treatment: then it is necessary to cauterize it according to this method.</start_of_turn
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to place his head in your lap, and hold his head between your hands like this, so that it does not move or be agitated with his head.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a soaked Cotum on the white of his eye, or in the mucous of his hair: then apply the Cauterium, which is shaped like this.</start_of_turn
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae, et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	Sit concave, like the shape of a quill pennaceous, and if the vein is penetrating until the other extremity, or if it is above, then grasp it thus
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Sit concave, like the shape of a quill pennaceous, and if the vein is penetrating until the other extremity, or if it is above, then grasp it thus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place the cautery upon the wound, which is kindled with heat.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	Hold your hand parallel to the Cautery from the eye towards the nose, so that your hand does not move, or irritate the patient: and place the Cautery on the fatty tissue of the eye, and burn it through.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you proceed with the Cautery from the beginning until the bone, it will be good.</start_of_turn>
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the Cautery once or twice if you deem it necessary: and leave it for three days.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a bandage with butter, and care for it with an ointment of exsiccation, until it heals.</start_of_turn
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If after forty days it has not healed: then place upon it a sharp medicine corrosive until the bone is exposed: and remove it according to what is written in its chapter.</start_of_turn
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of Cautery for fistula, which some of the first said.</start_of_turn
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Aim at the location of the fistula, and find it: then place under the fistula a thin cushion, that is, a cannula, which has this shape.</start_of_turn
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And mix in it the quantity of lead that is equal to a drachma of liquid lead, and hold your hand with the cannula firmly retained, and do not move the patient at all, so that it does not run, or cause the liquid lead to reach the eye.</start_of_turn
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place upon the eye of the patient a bandage soaked in albumin or in water.</start_of_turn
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	The lead will consume the location of the fistula, and will heal it with a miraculous healing.</start_of_turn
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, with the Cauterio and treatment mentioned earlier, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	If not, it is necessary to administer a nose opening, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, as it comes in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	In the manner of cauterizing in lip fissures.</start_of_turn>
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many times, acid occurs in lip fissures, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you have cured the fissures, when the treatment which we mentioned in the discussion of ailments has not been of use, then you should burn the little knife with the cautery, according to this shape.</start_of_turn
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its curvature be according to the sharpness of the knife.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the flame quickly in the fissures, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with a bandage, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	In the manner of cauterizing in the ear fistula.</start_of_turn
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When swelling occurs in the root of the gingiva, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus forms, and it bursts: afterwards it becomes inflamed, and pus comes out, and a fistula forms: then you must cure it, and if no use is made of the treatment, then it is necessary to burn with the cautery according to the quantity that is in the fistula.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the flame into the hole of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the iron is burnt through to its very bottom, and its tip: do this once, or twice more.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for yourself afterwards, until the time when you are cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If he is cured of the wound and is healed, it is well.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the place, and take out the corrupt bone according to what comes to pass in his head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	Regarding the cauterization of the gums, and the softening of teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.</start_of_turn>
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are softened by moisture, and the teeth are mobile, and you care for it with the physicians, and do not fear: then put the head of the patient in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply the cautery, whose form will come after this, so that you place a canula over the tooth: and introduce into it burning Cautery quickly: and hold your hand firmly, until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.</start_of_turn
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand: then repeat the Cautery several times, as you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient rinse his mouth with salt water, and keep it for one hour: and then spit it out.</start_of_turn
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth will then be firm, and the gums will be softened and relaxed, and the moisture will be dried out.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Regarding the cauterization of toothache.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.</start_of_turn
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is due to cold, or if it is cold itself, or if there is worms, and the care does not suffice with the physicians: then the Cautery is to be applied in two ways: either with butter or with fire.</start_of_turn
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery is like butter, for you take up a piece of butter and apply it to the swelling, or to the veins.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take hold of the cautery and apply it to the edge of the wound.</start_of_turn>
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse it in butter: and place it upon the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it is cold: then repeat it several times until the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, immerse wool, or cautery in cold butter, and place it upon the painful tooth: and place upon it a burning iron, until the fire reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth.</start_of_turn>
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cautery is like fire, for it extends to the marrow of the bone, or the iron.</start_of_turn
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And be careful in its handling, lest its heat should reach the sickly bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take hold of the cautery, whatever its shape it may be: and place it upon the tooth: and hold your hand until the cautery is cold.</start_of_turn
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do it several times, for the pain will subside, or on the same day, or on another day.</start_of_turn
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary to press upon the cautery impression, so that it may fill the diseased bone with butter, and hold it for an hour: then remove it.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.</start_of_turn>
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Use it with whatever limb you wish, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the cannula.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing in the Strophulis.
Caput XXIIII.	On the method of cauterizing in the Strophulis.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the Strophulae are filled with phlegm, and are cold from moisture, and do not obey digestion by medicines, and you wish to expedite their digestion: then you must use the Cauterium in its concave form, which is like this in shape.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, like a flame issuing from the other end of the Cauterium: put the flame on the surface of the abscess once, and again if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the abscess
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then put the Cauterium according to the size of the abscess.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then remove it after three days, and put upon it a bandage soaked in butter, until the burn caused by the fire has healed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with oil of the teeth, until the abscess has healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in raucedine uocis, and constriction of the anhelitus.
Caput XXV.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in raucedine uocis, and constriction of the anhelitus
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the wind brings moisture upon the channel of the lungs, and especially when it is with the coldness of the complexion: then it is necessary to evacuate the morbid matter first with the aid of medicinal solutions.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize in the night at the root of the epiglottis in a depressed place: and burn, so that you do not reach the gut with the Cauterium, nor the skin, unless something compels you to do so.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize again with another Cauterium at the junction of the neck in the last cartilage of its kind: and let the Cauterium be fixed according to the mode which went before.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the treatment of wounds of the lungs and chest, and the tussi (coughs).
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When coughs and pulmonary wounds are from cold moisture, and the patient has neither fever nor phthisis, nor an old wound: then cauterize with two cautery irons above the rib in the depressed areas, at the angles, and on the veins.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize also in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the cautery iron be like the shape that preceded it.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to make a cautery puncture with the cautery, which is called Punctum, which has the shape that preceded the puncture of the pain of the ears: and let the punctures be from thirty punctures up to almost as many
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And if the cautery has three branches: according to this shape
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore the surrounding area is relieved when doing this with three cautery irons at the same time.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In the treatment of titillation, in dislocation of the humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.
