When the head of the humerus is dislocated due to moisture, and does not settle back in its place within an hour of its dislocation, until it has become accustomed to its return, then it must be reduced by a small movement, as we have seen it happen in other cases: then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation immediately.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the patient is laid on his back, or on the healthy side
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then elevate the skin, which is inside the Tililian space to the upper parts with the left hand digits: and if the joint is dislocated inwards.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then have the cautery with two prongs.
Cuius forma est haec.	Which is this shape like?
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and will come the shape of the cautery with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when it is cauterized with a cautery having three prongs, because of this the shape of the cautery will be six cauteries: and these are the second ones following the thickness of the attempt
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	This is the shape of the cautery having three prongs
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one more is added above in this way, because there are eight cauteries in total
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put above the cautery crushed sponges with salt
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the patient adhere calmly, so that the limb does not move at any time, until it is comfortable
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upwards, and this is rarely the case, then cauterize the upper part of the humerus with the cautery of the claw, or with many punctures
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint becomes firm, and the moisture is driven out: and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	In this way cauterize the stomach
Caput XXVIII.	The head of the eighth
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture happen in the stomach, until they are expelled from their combination, and multiply catarrh to it, and take care of these things diligently, and do not confer: then it is necessary that the patient lie on his back, extend his limbs, and move his hands
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cautery instruments, a cautery under the breast of the pectoris of quantity equal to one digit with a cautery nail, and two cauteries below from two sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries is triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And prolong between each one so that they do not join together, when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery is the quantity of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be in this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: let there be one cautery which is like this one according to the figure of a circle according to this form
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And cauterize the stomach by pricking it with that which returns from this cautery: and it is that there are signs above the stomach at the puncture according to quantity, as much as you wish with encasement: then cauterize itself with the cautery of the puncture: then care for it with care which preceded until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	In this way cauterize the Epar with cold.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the Epa that there is pain from cold and wetness, or from large wind, until it escapes from its natural composition by excessive emission, and the patient is cured, as we said, and does not progress in it: then it is necessary that the patient be placed on his heels, and that signs be made with three cautery instruments according to this figure and this quantity below the hypochondria, where the elbow of a man rests: and let there be space between every two cauteries according to the thickness of a digit: and let the cautery be according to the length of the body of the rectum: and do not press your hand too much with the cautery
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of the ointment which is applied to the roughness of the skin be not added to the middle quantity: and let the patient be standing on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	And if he is not standing, then he is lying down, who has extended his limbs and raised his arms
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of cauterization.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed it is possible that you burn these carbuncles with a cautery knife, when there is skill and prudence in the art
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And take heed, that you do not proceed too far in the cauterization, and that you burn the roughness of the whole skin, for which the whole body is burned, and that it reaches the intestines: for the skin there is thin, as you know well
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Concerning the cauterization of the after-effects of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When the discharge occurs, and you wish to write, if the after-effect is in the liver itself, or in its membrane: then if it is in the liver itself, there is pain, and severity without acuteness: and if it is in the membrane of the liver, with acute pain that is severe: and know that I say this because it fatigues the physicians of this cure
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is necessary therefore that the patient lie down on his belly
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the after-effect with the cautery: then you burn the ointment which is assimilated by the rays.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with one cautery, until the whole skin is burnt, and it reaches the spleen, until the whole body is healed: then care for the discharge of the after-effects, until the patient is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation.
Caput XXXI.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation. The ancients say that cautery with the roots of aristolochia should be used for cold pleurisis in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation. And it is thus that from the dry roots of aristolochia one should take a long root, which is found from among them, and let it be as thick as a digit
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Neither is it proper that any surgeon of this sort should use cautery without having diligently studied the art of medicine for a long time: for it is by the experience of many that these diseases concur with this operation. Then plunge the root into oil and ignite it with fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery at the place between the continuation of the collarbone and the jaw, and with two small cauteries under guidance slightly depressed to the part which is under the beard
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	Then also with two cauteries between the fifth and sixth ribs depressed downwards to the rear part: and with one cautery in the middle of the chest and another above the stomach
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	Then also with three cauteries from behind: one at the place between the two ribs, and two cauteries on the two sides of the chest, the lower cautery being between the two ribs
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	Neither must you compress your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be open and smelling freely
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cauterization after it has been discharged so that pus is emitted for many days: for this is more conducive to recovery than all the other treatments that follow the care.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	In the treatment of hydrops, care must be taken with the cauterization so that pus is emitted for many days: for this is more conducive to recovery than all the other treatments that follow the care.
Caput XXXIII.	The head is the third part to be treated with cauterization
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not suffice in hydrops unless the vein is severed at the same time.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating hydrops with the methods of care that we have mentioned in the previous section, and the cure does not take hold, then it is necessary to cauterize the four veins surrounding the navel, one above the stomach, one above the spleen, one above the liver, two behind the ribs between the vertebrae, and one in the direct region of the chest, and one in the direct region of the stomach: and the amount of depth of the cauterization should be proportional to the thickness of the skin
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then discharge the cauterization openly so that pus is emitted over a long period of time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	Do not remove the diseased part from the care after the cauterization: for this will bring two results together: and will hasten the healing with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery when it is used for the belly is like nails: as it has been described before: and the shape of the cautery when it is used for the back is like olives as it has been described before
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	Regarding the treatment of the legs and feet with cautery.
Caput XXXIIII.	The head is the thirty-fourth part to be treated with cauterization
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When swelling appears in hydrops, and the abdomen is filled with citrine urine: it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot between the ankle and the heel: and hold your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not move it at all
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The urine is yellow, and the cautery should be performed in this fashion.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make upon each foot two incisions on either side of the ankle, and perform the cautery with the tip of the cautery knife: and perform the cautery along the length of the leg, one below the knee and the other below the other ankle, approximately in the middle of the leg: and make upon every buttock two incisions: and withdraw the cautery without closure for a long time: until some urine is excreted thereby: then care for the rest as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Thus perform the cautery in the solution of the belly.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the belly is from cold and moisture until the toughness is relaxed and digestion is finished, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cared for with the methods of care and not healed: and the sick person tolerates the excessive heat of the cautery, then cauterize him with a large cautery over his stomach, according to what was done in the cautery of the stomach with the circular cautery, and four cauteries around the navel, under the ribs, and a cautery on the navel itself, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if the urine moistens the excessive heat, and the sick person tolerates it, then cauterize him with a cautery on the loin, and a cautery on every hip: and perhaps add two small cauteries near the large one on the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	There is indeed a useful cure for this, whose method does not err
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	Chapter 6. How to cauterize hemorrhoids
Caput XXXVI.	When the solution of the belly is from cold and moisture until the toughness is relaxed and digestion is finished, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cared for with the methods of care and not healed: and the sick person tolerates the excessive heat of the cautery, then cauterize him with a large cautery over his stomach, according to what was done in the cautery of the stomach with the circular cautery, and four cauteries around the navel, under the ribs, and a cautery on the navel itself, or two cauteries
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many or one old hemorrhoids, and they are from thick, cold or moist humours, and they do not yield to treatment, then cauterize three times with cautery over the lower part of the spine below the almond-shaped prominence and triangularly around it, and cauterize under the navel like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is hardened, and his food is not digested, and his face is pale and sweating, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cautery, as before: and cauterize over the liver and also over the spleen, with a cautery like a nail: and leave the cautery open for some time: then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	In this way, cauterize the anal opening after its excision.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7.</start_of_turn>
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you excise the anal opening, then burn cautery that absorbs heat.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning cautery into the excised anal opening: and pull your last finger until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows: do this once or twice.</start_of_turn
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many anal openings, then cauterize each one as we have said.</start_of_turn

¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	In this way, cauterize the fistula in the anus.</start_of_turn
Caput XXXVIII.	Head Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the diseased part does not obey the section and the work which we have mentioned in its place, and returns to its original position, it is possible that it will heal with cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When this happens to any fistula, and it becomes old, pus flows from it, and it softens the corrupted matter
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is necessary to explore it with a fine hook.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then recognize the depth of its cavity with the hook.</start_of_turn
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply cautery, which is like a rod.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then enter the flame itself into the fistula and the quantity in which the clamp has entered.</start_of_turn
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery over the part, until all the corrupted bodies are consumed, once, or twice, or three times, according to the necessity.</start_of_turn
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard against the burning of nerves, if there are any, or great veins: or if the fistula goes to the belly or to the intestines, then guard against these places.</start_of_turn
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	Do not do this except when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and remember that it is not penetrable.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it heals.</start_of_turn
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed and the matter is removed from it, and remains thus for a long time: then you know that it is fully healed.</start_of_turn
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if the matter is not removed from it, then you know that it is penetrable, or that there is a broken bone in its depth, or something like that: of which memory will come to its place.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterizing the Renes.
Caput XXXIX.	On the method of cauterizing the kidneys.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When it happens in the kidneys that there is pain from cold or from great swelling, and that it diminishes because of that what is diseased, then it is necessary to cauterize the latter over the marrow above the kidneys, cauterizing all the kidneys with the cautery of the claw, which must be preceded by recollection.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we must also cauterize the latter in the same marrow.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	For there will arise three lines.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore will there remain two behind the cautery mark
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	When there is pain in the bladder from cold or from great swelling, and that it diminishes because of that what is diseased, then it is necessary to cauterize the latter over the bone above the bladder, cauterizing the whole bladder with the cautery of the claw, which must be preceded by recollection.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When pain affects the bladder, and swelling from gravel and moisture persists until the patient is unable to retain urine, then cauterize the lower part of the belly above the bladder where the hair of the testicles begins, and cauterize from the right side of the belly and from the left side of it: and let the length of the cauterization be according to the quantity of the thumb node. And cauterize the lower back, or two cauterizations if necessary: and let it be as the previous cauterization was.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	When pain affects the bladder, and swelling from gravel and moisture persists until the patient is unable to retain urine, then cauterize the lower belly above the bladder where the hair of the testicles begins, and cauterize from the right and left sides: let the length of the cauterization be as great as the thumb joint. And cauterize the lower back, or twice if necessary.
Caput XLI.	When pain affects the bladder, and swelling from gravel and moisture persists until the patient is unable to retain urine, then cauterize the lower belly above the bladder where the hair of the testicles begins, and cauterize from the right and left sides: let the length of the cauterization be as great as the thumb joint. And cauterize the lower back, or twice if necessary.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When pain affects the bladder, and swelling from gravel and moisture persists until the patient is unable to retain urine, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we have mentioned in the treatment of the bladder, and also cauterize the lower back, or twice if necessary.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	When pain affects the bladder, and swelling from gravel and moisture persists until the patient is unable to retain urine, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we have mentioned in the treatment of the bladder, and also cauterize the lower back, or twice if necessary
Caput XLII.	When pain affects the bladder, and swelling from gravel and moisture persists until the patient is unable to retain urine, then it is necessary to cauterize three times around the navel, as we have mentioned in the treatment of the bladder, and also cauterize the lower back, or twice if necessary
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous membrane flows down to the knee of the Ancha, and this is the cause of its displacement from its place: and the sign of this is that one thigh is prolonged over the other, when compared to the normal: and the dislocation is found in that part.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	It is necessary therefore that the cautery be applied to the diseased part above the Anchae nut with a cautery of similar size in a circle: when you have signed with the cautery around the circumference of the nut, as it is wont to do: and that the nut itself should fall into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	The cautery should be of the size which was previously mentioned in the cautering of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cautery is not present, then you must cauterize with three cauteries, with a large olive cautery: and make the depth of the cautery according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin of the whole
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	Regarding the cautering of the sciatica.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the nut of the Anchae, and the cause of it is cold and moisture: and the disease is cured with that which we have mentioned in the treatise, and no other remedy is of use, and the disease persists: then it is necessary to drain the diseased part from the gross humours with poultices of stench, or with artificial pills, or things of that kind.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.</start_of_turn
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cautering in these two ways: either with the cautery and the burning of drugs, or with fire alone.</start_of_turn
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cautery with fire is in various methods.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of them is that you cauterize above the Anchae nut with three triangular cauteries, in this shape.</start_of_turn
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make the depth of it well, or little.</start_of_turn
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there shall be space between every burn of quantity equal to the length of a finger: and let the burn be of olive oil.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, the burn is made in the middle above the head of the arch of the same.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Because there are four burns.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you burn with a circle, whose form precedes the burn of dislocation of the arch, one: so that it encloses the whole arch
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the whole skin
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the manner of burning in Sciatica, when the pain is adhering to the arch itself, and does not extend until the cox and thigh
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If, however, it extends until the cox and thigh, then burn with two burns on the cox, on the place where the sufferer feels the pain there, and with the fourth burn four fingers wide on the lower side: and let the burn be with a knife
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the burn be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	And if the sufferer says that the pain extends almost up to the toes, then burn there where the pain is felt with a single burn, or three, or four, or as many as are needed there
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he says that the pain is under the knee towards the thigh, then burn there with a single knife burn
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And burn in all your burning, so that you do not reach the nerves or great artery, and that you do not draw down the diseased matter over the sufferer's body, or cause contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I also know of one and another who have burned above the foot, and have finished their burning, and the thigh has swollen, until the whole foot has become swollen, and has burst open, and become corrupted throughout: then there has followed a solution of the belly, and a black fluid has appeared after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If pain exists in two parts simultaneously, cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said concerning cauterization of the anus, that this is the method.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a mark like that from iron, whose diameter is the middle of the palm: and be at the orifice according to the thickness of the kernel of the thumb, or less: and there be within it a third of itself.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And there be space between every mark according to the quantity of the thumb knot: and the marks be opened from two parts: and their height be like a knot, or two knots: and make a handle of iron adapted to the center of the marks
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is ignited in fire, until it turns red, and spits out sparks: then it is placed over the abscess inflamed over the healthy side
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Thus do three cauterizations round about in one place
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave it for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	After that apply butter with ointment: and discharge the wound opened for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it heals
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, concerning this kind of cauterization, we rarely use it, because of the terror of its appearance: and because of this, few people expect it over it
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Indeed, from the good ones it has its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cauterization with physicians is confirmed, so that you make two marks having a perforated arm, in which the kernel of the wrist comes down from the air, or from iron, the length of the wall: whose height be two knots, or like those.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there be space between each two quantities of the length of a finger, and there be openings below and above: and there be that which contain themselves against each other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	And lay the thumb upon the heel of the foot, the sick lying upon the broad side of the sound foot
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And compress your hand upon the heel of the foot much
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	And pour between two circles of hot water, which be heated with fire lightly, and keep it for the quantity of an hour of time: and the sick shall endure the biting of it, and the biting of him, for he himself finds the biting like fire, until the biting ceaseth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And lift up your hand with the instrument, and wash the hot water from the whole foot with sweet water: and send it away for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put upon it butter, until the black of the wound be removed: and send it away for a few days, and there shall come out of it pus.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is in the end in the healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	And care for it with unguents, until it be healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extend unto the hip, or the thigh: make for him a bath in which there be water equal to that which thou didst make in the foot.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the manner of hot water: and I have written concerning it in the treatise of the rectification of medicine.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali, and burnt lime of both an equal part: mix them both together and put them into a new vessel, of which the lower part be pierced with a small hole according to the quantity which enters into it: and put under the bottom of the vessel another vessel filled with water: and pour over the alkali and the lime from sweet water, which shall cover both by a finger: and when thou hast compressed them with thy hand well: and send away the vessel, until the acute water of the lower part of the treated vessel descend.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then add the whole water and throw the upper heel over the lower heel: and withdraw until it returns.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	The heel is then made strong and acute, which is administered in many medical operations, and in cauterization of the remaining limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it does the work of the fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And among the physicians, those who cauterize extensively, such as tessies, and beech gum, and nutgall, and lime with soap, know how to mix both of these together
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen himself reports that a certain ancient physician, who cured the pain of an ingrown nail and sciatica: and praised his skill.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He also said that it is unnecessary for any other treatment, and that he was cured by a single bath, until he returned, for he himself perhaps dipped into the hot bath, and came out of it already cured
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is taken from the green barley of the seer: and if it cannot be found green, take it dry, pounded: and take it often with some fat, and apply it to the ankle, knee, or thigh: and bind it, and leave it for three hours, or for as long as the patient feels its soothing effect
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the body is softened by the bath, put it into the bandage
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain disappears, and it is cured
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that no other cauterization should be used along with these physicians, except after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	Dioscorides also reports that when goat dung is cauterized with the nail of a sciatica, it gives relief: and it does cauterize in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let a lancet be taken, and let an ancient oil be drunk, and let it be placed upon the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot and between the heel, and is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and burn it, until it is charcoal
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it upon the lancet and let it go, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Do it again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease to do this until sensation returns through the middle until the pain has ceased
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called the cauterization of the Vaccinum.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cauterization of the pain of the back
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When pain occurs in the back from a wound of many, or from a fracture, or from excessive evacuation, or in like manner, from the infusion of cold and humid material: and the cauterization is not useless, except in this kind alone, which is made from the infusion of cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after evacuation of the patient with foul pills and like things, to make three lines upon the back, where the pain is, according to the width of the palm of the hand, after having signed with the cautery in every line five burnings, or more according to the quantity which comes from the patient's tolerance or the extent of his suffering: and let the cauterization be made with the cautery needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you will, cauterize three or four times with the middle caulking needle, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the manner of cauterizing in the swelling of the knee
Caput XLV.	Head Chapter XLV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	Many times this ailment occurs in young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its beginning in children is that it occurs with a tightening of the bowels in inspiration towards elevation, and movement: and you will find it in the last rib and the nodes of the back, which begin to bulge over the rest of the ribs.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you have done this, and you wish to make it, then burn it with a cautery in the shape of a circle around this form
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And take the cautery and burn it equally over every part of the ribs: and if you wish to burn around the ribs with a point cautery, make two or three points close together.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for the place, until it heals as we have said
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And be careful, lest you administer the cautery to the swelling, which is in the spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	In the same way as for cauterizing in podagra, and for joined pains.
Caput XLVI.	Head Chapter XLVI
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of the joints are from cold humors that flow upon any part of the body, and when pain occurs in the feet, it is customary among physicians to call this Podagra
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When it is cured by cold causes of Podagra, with the methods of treatment, and not by removing the pain, then the cautery will remove it
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is to be done after the evacuation around the joints of the feet with many cauteries: and let the cautery be of Olive oil
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	If the point has become softened upon the foot, then make as with the cautery of the point.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If pain rises up to the knee, or if the other bands remain, and this often happens, then cauterize the whole knee with three cauteries, or four from all sides, with the same cautery of Clauili.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If indeed further cauterization is necessary, then cauterize it.</start_of_turn>
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	Do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but rather keep the thickness of the skin around it.</start_of_turn>
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If pain rises up to the knee and the back: then perform what we said concerning the cautery in its chapter.</start_of_turn>
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pain is in the hands only, then point the cautery around the nails, as two lines are twisted together.</start_of_turn
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If, however, there remains pain in the toes, then point the cautery on every knot of the point, and on the nail of the hand.</start_of_turn
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pain rises up after a day to the elbows or the shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides.</start_of_turn
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	Do not burn the patient from the regimen of good treatment, from the recovery of physicians.</start_of_turn
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if there is a good regimen and the phlegm is evacuated, the patient will be healed by the aid of God with this cautery.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	About the cautery of ruptures.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and the intestines or bladder descend towards the testicles, and this is at the beginning close by: then it is necessary for the sick man to vomit immediately on that day.</start_of_turn
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And as it descends from the belly, it is softened by the [use of] gentle [instruments].
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then sit between your hands over his back: and command him to hold his breath, until he emerges, or until you see a wound or an intestine
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then draw it out with your fingers and sign over the fracture below the ribcage, with the sign of which extremity is similar to the middle of the circle towards the upper parts of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then burn the cautery, which has this shape, until it turns white, and throw away the black matter.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or the wound to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then put your hand over the place, so that the intestine does not go out: and I will open between the ribs, and put under it powder, and a servant over his ribs, and another over his chest which holds his hand
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then put the cautery over the sign, your hand with the cautery standing upright
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it until you reach the bone: or repeat it with it once more if you did not achieve it with it from the first time until the bone
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And be prudent in observing the exit of the intestine during the cautery, that you do not burn it, and that it comes out through that over the patient or the blood, or great malice
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And you know, that when you do not achieve the bone with the cautery, your operation is useless.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery be fine for children, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the rest of the wounds, until they are healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And if a patient lies upon his back for forty days, until the [healing] sign appears.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it must be provided that you give him nourishment throughout the duration of his treatment, so that it softens his belly: that it does not remain empty alongside the ailment and cause evacuation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when the sign appears after forty days, then administer the ligature of the navel done, and keep it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And take away from his labor, and give him food and drink, and fresh air.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when you use this regimen, it will heal completely.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I say the treatment of ruptures is with incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however ruptures occur in the rest of the belly, and are in their beginnings, and you wish not to add them, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let this be until it has hardened like a third of its size
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for it as we have said: and do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some people say: cauterize the rupture with a triangular cautery, according to this shape
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	When the sign appears with encrustation, and a line is drawn which is through the width at the upper side of the rupture, and a line which is lower
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cautery nail.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	In the case of pains caused by a fall or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When an accident happens to some part of the body, either from a blow or from a wound, and the pain persists for a long time and does not subside with treatment from physicians: then it is necessary to cauterize with the Puncti instrument.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	The cautery must be performed according to the size, shape, flexibility, and toughness of the part, and according to its position and the degree of pain arising from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If, therefore, healing takes place from the first cautery, that is good
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat the cautery over it again
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For in the case of these kinds of pains, it is customary to pass from one part to another that approaches them
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore one must follow them with the cautery until the patient is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	Concerning the cautery of Lepra.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVIX
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy, however, must sometimes be cauterized with the greatest intensity.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy that arises from the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: in such a case one must carefully consider the cautery of it
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If, however, the leprosy is severe and does not yield to treatment as we have said above, and does not subside: and times over the patient extends over the whole complexion of the body: then burn over the head five times: one in the middle of the head, and the second below it at the end of the hair, and two over the two horns, and one behind the nape of the neck
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally touch your hand with the cautery lightly, until it makes an imprint in the bone, and the cortices are dislodged from it: so as to allay the emission of foul vapor from it. And cauterize also the spleen according to what has been said before
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If however leprosy has become sparse on the diseased person and is clearly visible: then it is necessary that it be cauterized with these cauteries which we mentioned at the head, and with cauterization on the extremity of the nose, and with two cauteries on two maxillas, and with two cauteries on two spondyles of the neck, and six on the spondyles of the back, and one large one on the flanks near the great buttocks and one above the very belly: and two on the ankles: namely one on every ankle, and two on the knees, one on every knee, and two on the humeri, and two on the cubits, and two on the tendons of the chest. And cauterize it over every joint, from the joints of the fingers of the hands and feet, and from every heel of the feet.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And cauterize them from the nerves which are over the back of the heel, so that you do not burn those.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when cauterizing is done with a cautery over the rib cage, and another over the stomach, and another over the spleen.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add cauteries, the greater the damage, and the greater the risk.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And you know that the sick person does not feel pain in the cautery, just as they do not feel it in health: because the body of him is already stupefied.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauteries should be of a suitable size, and in number according to the parts and joints: according to what precedes from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cauteries with herbs and honey, and the rest of the treatment until he is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	In the manner of cauterizing in the Stupor.
Caput L.	Head L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When any limb is stiff and does not recover with physicians, oils, and plasters, then cauterize the stiff limb with cautery, according to the size of the limb or its hardness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery not pass through the thickness of the skin lightly.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it heals
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when cauterized for some stiffness of the hand or foot, in the vertebrae of the back near the exit of the nerves that move that limb: then the stiffness will be removed
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not presume this without knowledge of the anatomy of the limbs and the exit of the nerves that move the body
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	In this manner cauterize in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Head LII
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras is old and does not improve with any treatment: then cauterize over the deep cautery with a great cautery, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color is changed
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with barley flour, and lentils with rose oil, and arnica leaves, and columbine blood, and hyssop blood: take a part of each of these things: mix them together and apply them over the wound, and they will adhere to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	In this manner cauterize in cancer
Caput LII.	Head LII
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning and you wish to make it stop: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circumference as it turns around
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men have said, "The last cautery should be done in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I do not see that. For I fear that it will cause damage. And I have seen this happen many times before.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	It is better to cauterize around it with a circle, as we have said, or with many cautery instruments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	Concerning the cautery of Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has Adubelati and it is delayed in maturation, or because of excessive swelling, or because of old age which makes the blood weak, or because of time, and you wish to speed up the maturation of Adubelati, then cauterize around it with many small cautery instruments by pricking
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then remove the swelling
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will itself speed up the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If you wish to perforate it with the cautery, then make a small incision with the cautery instrument.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be distant from the infirm from that which follows.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	Concerning the cautery of a running wound.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A running wound is not except for a corruption in a movable limb, and it consumes it: like fire consumes dry wood
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If you see a running wound in a place where you can apply the cautery with fire, then make many small and large sparks, according to what is convenient in the place where the running wound is
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then burn it thoroughly from all sides until you have removed the entire corruption, and let nothing remain of it inside.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Leave it for three days, and place above the burned area sulfur in powder mixed with oil, until all the carbuncles are eradicated and all corruption is gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Care for it with nourishing poultices of flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If, however, after three days, new flesh has grown in a healthy state, without any corruption, that is good
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then burn again the parts that remain of the corrupted areas
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	The wounds are treated with acute medicine as needed
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	The burn itself disappears from the place where it was made.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Indeed, the burn is faster with fire: and I have already said that the cauterization of that is with acute medicine in its entirety: take it there wherever you wish it, when you wish it there
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	In this way, burn in Clauis and Verucis.
Caput LV.	Chapter LV.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Many times this disease occurs in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a gross, oozing thing that spoils the foot
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And the cauterization of it is in two ways: with fire, and with hot water
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As for the fire, make the cauterization of the concave surface like the nail of a lizard: which is done with iron, according to the quantity that it contains the limb from all sides: and let it be fine along the edges
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the burning iron on the limb
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then draw the hand back with the cautery around the circumference of the nail, until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail: and leave it for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then cover it with wool plugs and bandage it with salt: and leave the bandage on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	It will itself disappear from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the place where the tissue has been burned, until it heals
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not congealed, and many of them happen in the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet: then apply in it the cautery with warm water: and take a needle from the air, or iron, or from the quill of an ostrich: and place it over the nail, or the splinter
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a little quantity of warm water into the needle: hold your hand firmly, and draw the needle out with pressure, so as to impress the mark of the needle at the root of the nail, and find the warm water at the depth, at the root of the nail: and expect the patient to wait a while above the application of the warm water for an hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then leave it, for the nail will be eradicated with its roots
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Thus do with one after the other, until you arrive over all those which are in the body from the cautery
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they have been eradicated, with what is generated from the cautery of the flesh
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	In this way, cauterizing in Tremore.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to anyone to have a tremor from the cold in a nerve, or from a quartan fever, or from something else: then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauteries, or five over the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra cauterize with the cautery, and in the belly of it cauterize, and over the stomach of it cauterize
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	The tremor ceases when the olive oil cautery is applied, and health returns to the cold ailment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	The tremor subsides when the olive oil cautery is used, and health returns to the cold ailment.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When the bad blood is expelled from the body of Albathir, that is, pus that arises from corrupted matter
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, in the first place, when they appear, they must be cauterized over every head of the pus with fine cautery made of the branch of myrrh, whose extremity is kindled with fire
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with lenticular cautery
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they are cauterized diligently, at the beginning of their expulsion, in this way: and they do not grow; they are broken down by excessive flow, and health returns from the heat.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it is necessary to perform this after the expulsion with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	How to cauterize in the flow of blood from an artery to a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.
