When there is a great flow of blood from an artery that has been cut at a wound, which happens either externally or at the base of the wound, or by cautery of a limb, or similar things: and this makes it difficult to close the wound
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to anyone, then take hold of your hand at the orifice of the artery, and place your index finger above it: and tighten it much, until the blood stops flowing from under your finger, and does not flow out from there again
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put on the fire a few small olive stones and many more in number: and blow over them until they are ignited.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from the jar one, or a few, or many, according to the wound and the place, where the artery is ruptured, and place the cautery on the very wound: after which you withdraw your finger quickly: and hold the cautery until the blood is clotted
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If it is expelled with the withdrawal of the finger from the orifice of the artery, and you extinguish the cautery, then take another cautery quickly from those which are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Do not cease to do this until the blood is clotted.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	Be careful, lest you burn the nerve which is there, and do not add anything else to the wound.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And you know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to stop it: especially when the artery is great, except with four fingers.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with the cautery, as we have said before.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by extraction, when it is not extracted
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the extremities recoil and the blood is clotted
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is bound with a strong ligature
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or are placed upon it medicines which have the property of clotting blood, and are bound with a tight constriction
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever performs an excision of it with a ligature, and a tightening with a bandage, or with fire, or other similar things, does not give it sufficient pain, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If however it happens to anyone of these, and there is no physician present, neither medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the orifice of the wound, as we have said, and constrict it tightly until the blood is overcome from the upper part of the wound, and over the artery
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger must not be moved, but rather let it rest upon the ice-cold water until the blood congeals, and then it will swell up and be separated.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	Meantime, consider what is needed from the cautery or from medicine in this case.</start_of_turn>
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	(End of first part of the treatise.)</start_of_turn>
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Second Part.</start_of_turn>
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	Concerning Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in wounds, and things of a like nature.</start_of_turn
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already said in the first chapter that every ailment which demands the use of either cautery or burning medicine, and which has its causes and its instruments, and the forms of cautery.</start_of_turn
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I shall treat of the chapters following from the head down to the foot.</start_of_turn
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I shall proceed in this chapter in the same way: as a seeker of knowledge demands.</start_of_turn
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin this, let me remind you, dear son, what was said in the first chapter concerning cautery.</start_of_turn
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	Therefore, you must be cautious in this operation, for in this chapter there are many instances where blood flows out excessively with the opening of the vein, or the incision of the skin, or the opening of an abscess, or the draining of a wound, or the extracting of an arrow, or the incision of a stone, and such like: from which all these things are associated with tremor, and fear, and cause a loss of blood in many.</start_of_turn
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not be afraid of this, for in this art as in the art of healing the sick, there is always some danger.</start_of_turn
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	He who is angry with his ailment is like the sea towards him: because of his expectation that he will find from his illness and the length of his suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	When an ailment is accompanied by fear of death, it is truly terrifying
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from him who takes care of his ailment, and who hopes for his recovery, his ailment itself becomes harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	It is not right that you should consent to the arrival of him from whom comes his ailment.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	Be wary of excessive expectation, rather than of love and rapacity
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	Do not presume that you know more than is proper from him, except after you have learned the certain science which reveals to you what is useful and what is harmful
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	Utilize all the means for the care of all sick people, for prognostication and for the indication of what is beneficial to health
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in this lies your help in acquiring fame and glory, and in memory and praise
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, his son, your intellect, and do not take away from you direction and inspiration: for this is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I, too, have set this chapter apart by chapters, following the order of the Cauterion from the chest down to the feet: so that I may relieve you of the burden which you suffer from, and of which you inquire
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the treatment of water which collects in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You know that this ailment often occurs in children at the time of birth: or when the midwife tightens the head of the child without lubrication.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	Whenever anything happens, even from an occult cause which is not discerned.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	I have not observed this ailment in others besides children: and concerning all those from whom I have learned, the sea has always been sufficient for them; therefore it seems to me that it is necessary for me to defer the operation in this case.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	I have observed among children that when their heads were filled with water and their heads grew large every day, they could not sit on their own because of the size of their heads, and there was an increase in moisture until they died
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	Moisture of this kind either collects between the skin and the bones or accumulates under the bones over the flesh
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	If there is moisture between the skin and bones and the swelling is slight, it is necessary to make a single incision in the middle of the head, about the length of two knots, in order to drain the moisture.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the form of the sponge.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If the moisture is much increased and the swelling is great, two incisions should be made, according to this form
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	If the moisture is under the bone and its sign is that you see the edges of the head open from all sides: and the moisture is drained out when you press your hand inwards, without it being hidden: then it is necessary to make three incisions in the middle of the head, in this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision drain out all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then stitch the incisions with strips of skin and wool.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then cover this with oil and vinegar until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligament and care for the wound with tension and attention.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	Do not suspend the tying of the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And bind the diseased limb with little moisture, until it is comfortable and healed
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is when you consider where the swelling of the abscess is great, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is at the back more, or in the cheek, or in the right, or in the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore ascend gently with the incision where you see the abscess and the collection of water: and cut that as much as you can.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	Observe, that you do not cut an artery, and there is increased flow of blood, and the diseased limb will die from that flow with the evacuation of the moisture
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Of the incision of the arteries which are behind the ears
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When any swelling occurs to the eyes or to the chest, and it grows old, and no remedy of medicine helps: then the last remedy is the incision of these two arteries
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	It is necessary therefore when you wish to cut easily, that you draw out the diseased head
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then bind the diseased limb with anything that you wish
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein beats.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places where both of them are, which are behind the ears depressed: and they are rarely hidden, except in some people
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then sign with a burn on each side: and cut each one with a needle as sharp as possible, cutting through to the bone: and do this for the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	If necessary, introduce the sponge inside the vessel and cut the vein above with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	The length of the incision should be like two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood flows out with a pulsatile flow, which jumps inside frequently
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If the artery does not appear to be sensible, then it is necessary to measure from the ear to the quantity of three fingers
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with a cautery, and find until the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which must be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps more or less is emitted from it
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	The whole of this is according to the quantity which appears to you from the suffering of the patient and the refilling of the artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there remains anything to the bone from the soft parts, then cut that, so that no thick swelling remains: then bind up the wound with strips of linen cloth
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with oil, until it is healed
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries, which are in their time
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that an ancient hemorrhage occurs, or an acute catarrh because of acrid humilities and heat in the lacertis of the times, or an old soda, or urine, or similar things: and it is medicated with the methods of treatment of medicine, and it does not suffice: then we are experts in these ailments of the arteries of the times, or in cauterizing them, as we say
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of the operation in the extraction of these is that the sick man grasps the hair which are in the times, and directs it towards the visible artery in the time.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	The pulse itself is often observed to betray its secrets, and is rarely hidden except among a few men or in cases of great cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden, the sick person tightens his head with any garment he has: then he rubs the place with rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or he vaporizes the place with warm water, until his pulse reappears clearly.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take sponge, which was before like this form
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then cleanse with it the skin with ease, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then draw out the thread to the outside, and pull it out from above, until you have drawn out the thread from the skin, and made it retract from the tunic which are under it from all sides
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If the artery is fine: then loop the thread with the end of a needle
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And then cut from that part according to the quantity of which the extremities are elongated, and tighten, and the blood flow does not occur.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut, and if it is not tied off, the blood does not rise fully
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then evacuate from the blood about six ounces, until three ounces remain
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then it is necessary that you bind the thread in two places from a double thread, strong, from silk: or from horsehair, so that it does not become putrefied before the wound is consolidated, and the blood flow is restored
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut off the surplus, which is between two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this in an hour, or after an hour
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if necessary, cauterize the thread with a cautery until it reaches the bone, with a surgical knife: until the extremities have receded from it, and the place of the work is stable.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	It is better work if the patient does not have a fever, or if their complexion is flushed.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For indeed the cautery is an agent which brings about the drying out of humors.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to treat the patient.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the extraction of arteries that the place be closed with a cautery in its former state: and that there be placed upon the latter part of the thread which has been made in the middle
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the closing should be cared for with dry medicines which cause the generation of flesh, and with sponges, until the wound is healed
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Should blood flow from the artery meanwhile while you are working, then immediately stop it with the cautery, or tie the place with silk: and press your hand, until the blood is stopped
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If nothing of these is present, then put over the place your finger, until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And embroider the place with cold water, until the pain has ceased, and then bind as seems necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And concerning that which is easier and more convenient for the extraction of an artery, it is that you cauterize the vein with this cautery which has two blades: and that the pain of the two blades be similar to an almond
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	Indeed their pain is much less than that of two blades
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are acute, like two blades, both are subject to cold: and they do not cause the flesh to tear with speed
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	And because in the air there is a little of the size of a barleycorn, it is held in the air of the fire and is severed more quickly: with this work is better in all respects, and is easier, and more convenient.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let there be space between two knives equal to the length of a finger, after you have marked two points with the cautery: and lay both of them alight until they reach the bone, and they shall penetrate in two places: so as to lengthen that which is between their extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For this cautery does not coagulate deeply.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	About the care of acute tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter III
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are acute and flow from the eyes which are above the outer part of the head: and do not cause any medicine with the physicians, and the tears make the face of the patient red, and he feels walking in front like ants: and his eyes are swollen, wet, as if they were eaten away by the scales: and his eyelids are inflamed from the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients deemed it necessary in their treatment for these tears to perform an operation, and they called this treatment "Ens.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is necessary to shave the hair on his face for the patient.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead equally distant according to the length of the forehead: and let the length of the incision be like two fingers, and one incision be equidistant from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length of the lower part of the jaws, and the third from the other side: and burn from the arteries which are in the two sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two mandibles, and let there be space from the incision equal to the length of three fingers together: and let there be a sponge prepared, or dry cloth, with which to soak up the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce the sponge-bag of two acute extremities, whose shape follows.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision from the temporal side to the second incision: and scrape the whole skin between the two incisions, with the sponge-bag, which is above the bone
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do the same from the middle incision to the second incision
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then withdraw the sponge-bag and introduce another instrument into the first incision, which is called the acute knife, from one side gently, not acutely from the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place the acute edge of it towards the meat attached to the skin, and the gentle side towards the bone: and press it in until it reaches the middle opening: and cut through everything that descends from the head to the eyes: except that which continues from the skin.<start-of-turn>
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do the same in the middle opening until the other opening.<start-of-turn>
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after it has bled out an equal amount, express the place from the clotted blood.<start-of-turn
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place on every incision a bandage of old cotton, and place over that soaked sponges in wine, and wax or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And take care that there be no formation of a soft swelling.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day suture the ligament, and give a plentiful infusion with warm water.<start-of-turn>
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the wound from the marrow, and leave the other wounds to heal: until they are healed.<start-of-turn>
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	As for the care of the acute tears and catarrh of the eyes from the inside of the head.<start-of-turn>
Caput V.	Chapter V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When acute carbuncles occur, the area, edges and surrounding parts are affected: and the eyes become swollen, small and languid; the aspect is therefore distorted: the palpebrae are ulcerated, hairs fall out from the skin, and there is acute pain in the depth of the head, causing sneezing. Then take note of these signs, for these matters do not arise from carbuncles alone, except from numerous ulcers.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	The best treatment for these is to take note of these signs.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	It is also proper to shave the patient's face.</start_of_turn>
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision one finger's breadth in the middle of the face, or on the other side across the width, and begin the incision from the left ear to the right ear: and keep the incision down to the bone: and stretch your hand from the edges of the wound, which move with chewing, until the bone is reached: and you will have excised the whole blood with the sponge.</start_of_turn>
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate the two lips of the wound with coarse cotton wool, or with strips of linen.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then bind up above with threads: and soak the threads with wine and oil, so that there does not form a thick scab.</start_of_turn
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you have finished with this, and the swelling of the wound has diminished: then it is necessary to compress the bone, until new flesh begins to form in it.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for yourself with a regimen of nourishment that promotes the healing of the wound: thus as if you were taking from wheat flour two parts and from barley four parts: and prepare from these ingredients a plaster, and administer it to the wound until the flesh has healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	Concerning the care of that which falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	Concerning the care of that which falls into the ear.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Every thing that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral substance, like stone, or something like stone, such as iron; or it is vegetable, like cicer and beans; or it is a flowing substance, like water and vinegar, and wax like things; or something animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When such things as stone or other substances of like nature fall into the ear, they expose the ear to the open air: if oil is poured in, let some of the oily liquid be drained out of the ear with the finger or with a tube.</start_of_turn>
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then extract it and make the eardrum taut with conchs; anoint the nostrils above the eardrum, after you have put around the ear a bandage of cloth or wool, and extend the ear upwards.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many things go out with this care.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	If they do not go out, then extract them with tweezers, which are fine like needles: their form is like this.</start_of_turn
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If they go out with the tweezers, that is good.</start_of_turn
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if they do not go out, extract them with a blunt needle of small size.</start_of_turn
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If they do not go out by this, make a tube of brass, and insert the end of the tube into the ear very much, and pour oil around the tube with soft wool, so that there be no air except the tube: then draw out with your hand.</start_of_turn
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Many things go out with this treatment.</start_of_turn
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If it does not go out in this way: then take from the helkalimbat, or from the moisture, that is, prepared gluten, with which birds are captured, and put it on the extremity of the radius after you have wrapped around it above the ankle that is positioned downwards: then introduce it into the ear opening with ease, after you have expelled the wax from the moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If it does not go out as we have said, then prepare to make an incision, before the swelling becomes hard, or spasm.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	The way of making the incision is like a vein-cutting in the head: and extract from it from the blood according to the measure of its virtue.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, and bring round his ear to the upper part, and find the opening of the ear at the root of the ear towards the cartilage in the depressed place: and make the incision in a semicircular shape, until you reach the bone: then remove it with the instruments
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the incision quickly and diligently, and care for it, until it heals
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If anything falls into the ear from a seed that grows and swells: then administer the extraction of it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not come out for you, then take a small sponge, fine and subtle, according to this form
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the excision of that kind from the grains that fall into the ear, and do not do that when you think that that grain is already moistened by the moisture of the ear, until you have put upon it many sponges: then extract it with hooks, or with a fine hand, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction will alleviate it.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	And in water that enters the ear, it is necessary for the patient to cough at first: and immediately put in his ear a little of the old cotton wool: and it is placed upon that ear in which is the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If he goes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	If not: then take many stones, according to the length of the digit, tight, loose, and warm them with fire near, and introduce the sick person through one ear: and let him go out through the other ear, and strike him with a stone on the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Do not cease doing this with the stone and the stone, until all the water has gone out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And when the water has gone out, take from the fire or from a jug one, and introduce its extremity one into the ear: and raise the other extremity with fire, until most of it is consumed.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the jug with another, and do this many times, until all the water has gone out: and extract it with a tube according to what is promised in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of an animal that is within the ear, if it is small of the body, like a flea, and the like, take care of it as I have said in the explanation
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of the body that appears to the sense: then manage the extraction of it with the hand, and with hooks: and its matter is easier for all who hold it in the ear
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction of the worms generated in the ear, when you have cured it with what we have said in the discourse and in the treatise on distillations, and it does not yield your care: then it is necessary to burn the ear in the sun
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If anything appears there from the worms, then extract it with the hand, or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If nothing appears there, then take a tube, whose form is like this, strict below, wide above: and introduce the lower extremity into the ear according to the quantity that the sick person tolerates: then draw it out with that strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do it many times until all worms emerge.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you until they come out, then pour oil around the cannula with earth, as I said on the stone.[start_of_turn]
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	When they do not emerge even with this, then perform distillations, which the ancients were experts in for the elimination of worms: and you will find this in the treatise on distillations.[start_of_turn]
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your effusion be like that which you pour with oil and medicines into the wound with this instrument, whose form is shown here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Like the wax which you make from silver or gold, tightly closed below, with a small hole above, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let the force which is in the concavity of the cannula be made of air centered
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a sponge and moisten the end of it with a coating of the decoction: then pour oil, or gum, or whatever you wish of these medicines into the cannula: and let it be in the wound: then introduce the sponge with the coat above, and express it out with your hands in a temperate compression, until the oil is driven into the concavity of the ear, and you feel it inside the ear: and what is poured into the wound should be heated with fire immediately: for medicines do not tolerate being distilled when cold.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Of the care of the burn of gold.
Caput VII.	(The provided text continues with the next section of the translation.)
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When some infants emerge from the holes of their mothers’ wounds unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And sometimes it happens to some people that their ear is burned from the wound, or is born with it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And sometimes this swelling arises in the profound cavity of the Ear, without causing any unusual sensation: and sometimes it occurs on the exterior of the cavity, and causes some unusual sensation.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	And thus that which arises in the profound cavity of the Ear, and which does not comprehend the outward aspect, is difficult to heal in many situations
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And when it causes sensation, the Ear must be placed under a sole, and the swelling must be pressed with a fine sponge: then if the swelling appears to be subsiding, open the opening somewhat with a slight incision, so that its edge may be slightly obtuse, while the remainder of the sponge should be soft on either side, so as not to irritate the Ear
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If the swelling is caused by a natural growth of the flesh in the substance of the Ear, then hold it with a fine needle and cut it away with ease until the whole piece of flesh is removed
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the swelling is in the profound part of the Ear, then take a fine needle, soft and heat it with fire: then pass it into the substance of the Ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If then you sense swelling with this, which causes the patient to suffer from the weight of the hearing, try to open it with ease: and be careful not to injure the nerve of the Ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the Ear a plaster cast according to the quantity of the opening which you have made in the Ear: leave it for a few days, until you are certain that the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take a plaster cast, and moisten it with rosewater, and sprinkle over it ground alum, and use it on the Ear.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the Ear still swollen after removing the swelling: then you must take out the cast and put it on another cast, which is made with rosewater, until the swelling subsides: then care for it until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If blood flow increases: then immerse the sponge, or pack the abdomen in cold water, and place above it a bandage: and employ the remaining treatment which separates the blood flow mentioned in the treatise on distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Regarding the care of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the Altheli which arise in the eyelids, when they are wet and when they are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	It is necessary therefore to press them with pins: or with a single finger, and cut them away from their roots
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place above the place a soaked sponge.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If blood flows from the wound, then cauterize it with a fine lancet
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And the cauterization is better after the incision
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Many of them indeed remain as long as something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, they burn those roots and they do not remain
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Regarding the care of the great eyelid of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Many things happen in the eyelids something which assimilates the Crandini in its height, and its hardness, and because of this it is called great: and it is an accumulation of thick moisture in the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation therefore in this is, as you see, if there is a great one proceeding from the eyelid, which appears from the eyelid and moves to every part, and its resolution is easy
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Find therefore above it a split through the width
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then cleanse the wound from all sides with ease, until it be satisfied.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend the wound with a single suture, and cut it off.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if it is not prepared for cutting, except when you penetrate the eyelid with a small incision, then it will be harmful to the patient in some way.</start_of_turn>
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the wound is large: then gather it together with a suture: and care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, it will not cause any harm from it.</start_of_turn
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The ointment will restore it and nourish the wound.</start_of_turn
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if it is large and extends downwards towards the inner part of the ear from the surface outwards, then turn the eyelid, and suspend the greatness with a single suture: except that you do not need an incision, and press the wound from all sides.</start_of_turn
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	And if you lengthen the eyelid by an incision, it will not cause any harm.</start_of_turn
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the greatness with salt water: and care for the place with it which is nourished, until the patient is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelids.</start_of_turn>
Caput X.	Chapter 10.</start_of_turn>
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a secretion which is generated in the upper eyelid: and it mostly happens in children: and it weighs down the eyes of them, and it causes them to have black spots in the mornings, and they are not able to see the sunlight, because the tears run down to them, and because of this the tears cause their faces to be always wet, and to sleep with their eyes open, and their eyelids are always wet under their eyebrows: and the prominence of the Axirnath is seen in the eye, and when you press on it with your fingers, you feel the Axirnath between them.</start_of_turn
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	Thus is the manner of his operation, that he place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take the sheet of linen and prepare it in it a basin, and make from it a circle according to the quantity that contains Axirnath from every side.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place him thereupon, and press with your fingers from every side, so that Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle thereof moisture with some sponge-wool adhering to the tears of the wound for the width, and let not the wound be greater than that which is made in phlebotomy at depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary that you find the whole skin, until Axirnath proceeds from the wound according to the form of a white loaf of bread in many positions
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract therefore the said limb with the cloth which you have filtered between your fingers to the outside: and you will turn your hand to the right and left, until it is dispersed: and be careful, lest you add to the wound, so that you do not reach the eye with the sponge-wool, and damage it
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if indeed Axirnath does not appear at the beginning of the wound, you add a little to the wound with ease, until Axirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract the limb as we have said above
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them upon the place, and bind them with threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from men there are some who smear salt, and place it into the cavity of the wound, so that the remainder of that moisture may be liquefied.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if there happens to be in the place of the after-boil a soft swelling, then care for it with cold compresses until it is healed
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	Concerning the mode of treating the eye when the eyelids are softened, so that it does not bulge as it should not.
Caput XI.	Concerning the mode of treating the eye when the eyelids are softened, so that it does not bulge as it should not.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs are added beyond the normal course under the natural hairs, and are of an excessive quantity: then they harm the eye, and cause methods of injury, such as excessive tears, softening of the eyelids, and pus, until such time as this becomes the cause of destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And Ataxmir of the eye is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, as is mentioned previously in the chapter on cautery
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or by incision and stitching
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by cannas, as I shall say
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the patient in your lap
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then stretch out the eyelid of the eye with your left hand
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is wrinkled, that is good
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: introduce the needle into the fold where there is a hair from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread near the hairs themselves, that is, near the margin of the eyelid where the hairs are found: and draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and tighten the fold.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	And find under the added hairs in the interior part of the eyelid, with the greater lachrymal sac coming down to the lesser lachrymal sac
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then draw out the thread, and place under the eyelid a small piece of cotton wool or cloth: then mark over the eyelid with cautery, so that it is like the figure of a myrtle leaf
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	The wound must be closed, so that it forms a figure according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for it varies in different people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	The wound must be closed so that it forms a figure according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for it varies in different people.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	When the suture has been passed through two lines which you have marked, and you have begun from the larger lachrymal gland up to the smaller, make a single split near the natural hair, as is the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the needle through one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then remove the entire skin.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather together with the suture the two lips, with needle and fine thread: and stop the bleeding, and cause the excess to adhere to the two eyebrows, with some useful substance, if you wish to do so: or if not, do not cure it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the suture and the thread, three or four days later: afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, remove the scab without a suture, and care for it, which will dry and contract
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is elevated with the closing of the wound and the gathering together of its parts: but the future is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This is the way of healing which the ancient Ataxmir doctors taught.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	Indeed, in this is solicitude over the infirm, and this is from a good operation, and not in this is there any fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another way is in Ataxmir also: and it is that the sign on the eyelid should form a figure like the figure of the leaf of a myrtle, as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then elevate the eyelid with three separate hooks, or gathered together, according to the shape of this which follows, then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this shape, with equality of the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If, however, it is not possible to hold the hook, and it is not equal: then grasp the point where the suture is, and insert it into the middle of the figure: and insert another suture near the greater lacrimal gland, and another suture near the smaller lacrimal gland: and gather together the threads between your fingers with equality
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then elevate your hand with equal elevation: and elevate the skin above which the mark is made of the limb, as we have narrated.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture: and care for it until it is healed.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If, however, swelling occurs at the incision or the wound: retain this swelling with a compress, and with similar things, from sitting unguents.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelids are also swollen, as their hair turns them.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is necessary therefore that you use what we have said concerning the incision: but the suture of both is artificial
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	About care for Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, that you cover the eyelid, and split the wound which is between the teeth, according to what I have narrated
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two needles, or two slender sticks: whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and the width of them is less than the width of the pupil: and insert it at the extremities of both from both parts where you have the thread.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather together both things with slightness over that which is superfluous from the eyeball, and string two needles from both parts firmly, and let go of them every few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin, when tightly stretched, will die, darken, and decay until it falls apart by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If it lingers, then cut it through with scissors.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it has consolidated, elevate the eyelid: and do not puncture the hair.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two needles, which you make according to this figure and the quantity in length and width.</start_of_turn
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding the elevation of hair pricked in the eye with a needle.</start_of_turn
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.</start_of_turn>
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in this case is as follows: take a fine needle and introduce it under the silk thread, which is fine.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then join the ends together and knot both ends with a fine knot: and let the length of the thread be equal to one palm.</start_of_turn
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then make another fine thread pass through the eye of the needle in a short space, and knot the ends of it if you wish.</start_of_turn
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then place the patient's head in your lap, and let it be close to the ground so that the operation is evident: because the operation is fine, or even less.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with the thread through the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly, until you have extracted the natural hair.</start_of_turn
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw out the hair until above the thread: and introduce into the thread the light of the hair: if there is one, or two, or three, not more.</start_of_turn
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then grasp your hand with that [same] hand, until the hair emerges with the bristles mingled in the eyelashes with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	Then grasp your hand with that hand, until the hair emerges with the bristles mingled in the eyelashes with the natural hair.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either join to it a long hair from the natural hair and elevate it with that: or cast it away, until it has grown out again, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	Concerning the care of the eyelash that happens in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this happens to the eye, it is called the Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this eyelash is either natural or accidental
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental, therefore, is done from the consolidation of a wound, or a section, or a cauterization, and the like of these things
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the way to operate on this is to find that consolidation, and to separate its lips, and to put between them a little piece of linen, and to bind them together, until it heals
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And do not use in the treatment of this anything that will irritate and constrict: for if you do, the eyelash will deteriorate more than before: rather use those things that soften, such as barley-straw: and embroil with water, in which be dissolved salt, poppy seed: and oil of ivy, which is liquefied with some oil: and mix with that the lint, and care for it with that.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	Your surgical skill is such that you can overcome every difficulty without hindrance, following the initial form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	This operation is not complete without some rectification of the Alkhatrati, so that the form may return to its original state.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	The care of the Alkhatrati which is in the lower eyelid is to raise or contract above to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This lower Alkhatrati is what is truly called the Alkhatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	It is natural, and is accidental
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	It is caused by a wound, or a split, or a burn, or things like these
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way to perform the operation in this case is to grasp the needle, which has a doubled thread, and pass it through the meat from the left lacrimal gland to the right lacrimal gland, until the thread reaches the two extremities of the meat
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	And then extend the meat upwards with the needle, and cut the vein with a wide spatula
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If the figure of the eyelid returns to its original state, that is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, grasp the suture, and put it into the split, and close it with the eyelid: and find two holes in the inner side of the eyelid, and the extremities of the two holes are from the two angles of the incision, until they converge and make an angle: until when they converge, the figure of them both becomes like the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	And then remove that part of the meat which is as wide as the acute angle below, from that which follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts: thus with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them as we have said, with soothing medicines, and applications, until they are healed.</start_of_turn>
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if the flesh should slip from the wound, from the suture or cautery: then it is necessary to find the wound even under the eyelashes, even as before.</start_of_turn
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with an application, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the sum of the discourse concerning the care of the Alxatra is, when it is above or below, that it should be treated in that operation, according to the form of the Alxatra.</start_of_turn
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For itself, there are many varieties in the form: and a prudent artist prepares the limb in any way that is possible, until he has restored the figure to its natural shape, or as near as possible, and even the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and the instruments in many arrangements.</start_of_turn
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Of the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or the cornea.</start_of_turn
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	When this happens to many people, it is like the consolidation of the upper eyelid with the white of the eye, and it hinders its natural operations.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	It is necessary therefore to introduce the edge of the radius under the eyelid, and to elevate it upwards: or to extend it with a needle: then cut through the adhesion with a fine scalpel, which is not with the sharpness of the incision of the scalpel, but rather obtusely near: so that it does not irritate the patient during the operation, and that the scalpel be withdrawn easily, and that the eye be restored to its natural shape: and that the adhesion be completely healed.</start_of_turn
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Pour water into the eye, with water driving out the former: or distill it into it from a vessel made, from gum dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a strip of linen: and put over the eye wool soaked in alum or chalk: and after three days use a sponge, and with solids, until it is healed
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	As for the incision of the nail and the protrusion of the flesh of the tear ducts.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two modes.</start_of_turn>
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is fleshy: and is similar to rough sand, soft.</start_of_turn
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not fleshy, similar to frozen white moisture: which when it touches iron, or you grasp it with a finger, it breaks off and does not adhere to it.</start_of_turn
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both these kinds do not begin until the greater tear has gone, until which time it covers the whole, and prohibits light, and the movement of the eye.</start_of_turn
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the way of working in its incision is: as you place the sickly head on your lap.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open its eyes, and lift the eyelid with your hand.</start_of_turn
