Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then collect the nail with a pair of tweezers a few times, and stretch it upwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take the needle, and introduce it through the hair from the hair of a horse, and silk or thread: and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle, and fix it in the middle of the nail: and pierce the nail with the needle, and bind it with thread to the nail, and stretch the nail upwards: and scrape away with the nail the hair following the pupil, as if you were scraping the nail with the hair until the end of it.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then the remainder of the incision is to be made in the root of the lacrimal bone with fine spatulas, or with small forceps: and let go of the natural flesh of the lacrimal bone, so that it does not obstruct the course of the tears.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And when the nail is extended with only one nail: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then it is to be scraped away with fine spatulas, whose form is this.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And take heed, that you do not touch the delicate corneal tunic, and cause a break in it, and perforate the pupil
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, pour upon the eye some powdered salt, or make a solution from alum, and leave it in until the next day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	And care for it as is necessary, until it is healed
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is neither sensitive nor able to penetrate the soft parts, nor does it protrude in it, then it is to be treated in this way with the physicians, and will be healed as I have said in the instruction
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to make an incision, then open the eye of the patient, and grasp the delicate bone with fine spatulas, of slight curvature, of acute form, according to this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And remove the nail from above with care
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it is becoming rare and crumbling, and leaving prints in the bone, then drain from your hand into the eye from a solution of alum, or of red alum, or of salt: and wash the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat the operation above until the whole of it is removed
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless the contrary is present in the eye, leave the swelling alone, and care for the swelling until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Repeat the operation when necessary until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	The prominence of the tear gland, if it causes great pain in the eye, should be suspended with a hook, and its part should be excised: do not make the final incision, lest the flow of tears be interrupted.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then let the eye remain lubricated with a red lentil, or something like it, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	As for the incision of the pupil, and the native tissue in the eye.</start_of_turn
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.</start_of_turn
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Sometimes in the eyes of men there is a red swelling of the flesh, either composed or superposed, which covers the pupil, approaches or tightens over the eyelids, and sometimes even turns the eyelids outwards: and it looks like a rose petal.</start_of_turn
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation for this is also to put the diseased head in your hand.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open his eyes and gather all the flesh with hooks which are convenient for this: and hold it with one forceps, or grasp it.</start_of_turn
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then make an incision in the first place, until you have finished all of it with the knife.</start_of_turn
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And burn away from the eye, so that you do not damage it during the operation: and let your incision be as we have said in the incision of the nail, or with small forceps, with which the fat is collected, as it is said above.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When the incision is complete and the wound has been thoroughly cleansed, then pour salt over the eye: either dissolve it into a powder of red pepper, or use similar unguents which are corrosive to the eye. Place upon the eye a compress of cloth with alum or vinegar, in order to protect it from the heat of the afterburn.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If anything remains of the dressing, and the blood is still warm, and the swelling has subsided: then remove the eye, and keep it cool until the swelling has gone down
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over it with the operation until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	Do the same with any meat which has been added which has happened in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	It is true that it is necessary to avoid all care of the eye from natural or accidental causes during the operation with the iron, and do not introduce your hand into any of these operations until you are certain that the limb can tolerate this operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the collection of fat from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	The fat is a red wax which covers the eye, and hinders its operation by water: and it weakens the eye as long as it lasts.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	It is necessary therefore in the first place to consider whether the eye in which the fat is, is strong and not in any other way diseased, apart from the fat: then collect the fat from it
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And it is necessary to take great care not to move your head backwards
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then suspend the veins with one thread each, or two according to your prudence: and let the needle be fine like half the diameter, or two threads together according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then collect with fine forceps those one or two [objects], and drain blood every hour until the foreign bodies have been moved from the eye, and they have healed: and beware not to damage the eye with the extremities of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	Let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation lest you cause harm to them [the eyes].
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then instill in the eye some cold or reddish unguent: that its sharpness may destroy what remains of the foreign body.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If it is not possible for you to collect it all in that hour, then close the eye with this, which will soothe the pain of the eye: and keep it closed for a few days, until the pain has ceased: and protect it from the heat: and repeat the process above until it is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	This is the form of the forceps.</start_of_turn>
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	Of the reduction of the swelling of the nose.</start_of_turn>
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.</start_of_turn
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call the swelling of the nose "Fistula of Arissa," which they cure with cautery or with acute medicine that burns, as the case may be.</start_of_turn
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, do not be ashamed to make an incision at the root of the swelling at its birthplace, and evacuate all the moisture that is in it and pus, until the bone is exposed.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When the bone is exposed, and there is corruption or blackness in it, then dry it with an instrument of this shape.</start_of_turn
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called "Asperation of the head."</start_of_turn
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let iron go from the head downwards, and let its head be rounded like a cushion, which is pierced with a needle of lime or with an awl or with a fine puncture: and place it upon the diseased part of the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then move it between your fingers, and press your hand firmly, until you know that the fracture has been reduced: and do it again
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with sponges and hemostatic agents.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place is consolidated, and a wound has formed there, and the circulation of blood has ceased: and it remains for forty days, and does not return, and does not swell, and does not become inflamed in that place: then you know that it has healed
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then it is not in that limb, except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, according to this shape.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is necessary to detect the bone from the second bone with iron, or with acute medicine: and when it has been detected, then grasp the fragment according to this shape, let the iron be at an angle, equilateral: and let the wood be in a triangular extension reaching up to the extremity, like a vein.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place it upon the bone itself: and let it be close to the lacrimal: and extend your hand from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then move your hand with the fragment, until it pierces the bone, and you feel it is weak: by this you will know that the marrow is coming out through that, when you keep your hand on your nose
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore restore the place with sponges and hemostatic agents, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When therefore a wound has formed and the place has become solid: then the matter which was flowing outwards returns to the nose: and thus it is easier for it to be healed over the wound
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the reduction of the prominent eye.
Caput XX.	On the reduction of the prominent eye.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye stands out completely, and does not yield to pressure, neither by reduction nor by diminution: then it is necessary to lance the diseased part: then perform phlebotomy: afterwards apply packs to the cavity without incision, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply to the eye a liniment made from acacia, and aloe, and oil, and gum arabic
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye tightly over a pad with many feathers
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the manner of the feathers is: that you take fine wool, many, and fold every feather from four sides: make many from these: then put one upon another, according to the quantity which the eye requires: then bind over these with a strong cloth
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And repeat the packs with suction without incision
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the packs, and keep the eye closed day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If, however, the ligament is again softened, then it is necessary to bind it tightly: then remove the ligament after a day and a night, as we have said
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If, therefore, the eye is again reddish from the old tunics, it is good: and if not, then repeat the pad, and feathers, and binding, and packs, until it is healed
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Of the incision of the tunica of the eye.
Caput XXI.	Of the incision of the tunica of the eye
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When disruption occurs in the tunica of the eye, then it stands out and projects outside the eyelids like a grain of wheat, and is deformed in the form of a man by that. Then it is necessary to incumber that: then the operation in this is, as we have said, and it is that you introduce the needle into the root of the tunica from the lower part to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another needle through the part of the lacrimal bone where the doubled thread is, and make it penetrate: and draw out the first needle following its own course.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then pierce the place of the doubled thread and ligate with it the edge of the vein around the needle: and tighten it much.</start_of_turn>
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then draw out the needle, and place upon the eye a soaked lanolin on a piece of lint: and draw it out until the thread comes out with the vein.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the eye with it, which soothes it, until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when the vein is drawn out from every part with a circle of cloth, until the eye regains its great prominence.</start_of_turn
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then prick with a fine needle which reaches the depth of the eye, and let out the moisture of the albumin, and let the eye descend, and join immediately: then tighten it up until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	¶ Regarding the care of the eye.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.</start_of_turn>
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This disease which is called Alcomnati, is not merely an eye-sore, but a disease which is caused by an accumulation of matter in the eye, similar to descending water, and not by the disease itself.</start_of_turn
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the method for dealing with it is to make the patient sit on a prepared seat, or directly on the bed.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take hold of his head with your hands from both sides, and move it around, until you see the disease rise up towards the lower part of his eye.</start_of_turn
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then it will remain fixed and will not descend, and the light will be completely extinguished: and he will see the infirmity just as he saw it: and if it does not descend downwards, you know that it is water.</start_of_turn
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If the patient is not prepared for the descent of the bowels as we have said, then sit the patient between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a soft cushion and find it above the bony prominence at the junction of the joint with the cornea in the crown, until the bowels evacuate.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When they have evacuated, then pour lukewarm water into the eye in which you have mixed honey: or water in which you have boiled barley and honey: then care for it with the rest of the treatment until the eye is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	As for the care of the water that descends into the eye, or for a cataract.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.</start_of_turn
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have said the kind of water for irrigation, and what is suitable for the perforation according to the declaration and explanation, then take that accordingly for the sake of the patient.</start_of_turn
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then you must make the patient sit between your hands square, opposite the light, near the heel: and fix his eye securely, and bind it tightly: then take the outer edge of his eyelid with your right hand, if the eye in which the water is, is the left eye: or take the inner edge with your left hand, if the eye is the right.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take your right hand with the almond, if the eye is left: or your left hand if the eye is right.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then place the edge of the almond near the corner of the eye for the width of the radius in the white of the eye apparent to the tear: then push the almond with force: and you will know that the almond has pierced the membrane of the eye: and you will feel that the almond has gone through to the bottom.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	The measure of the general path of the eye should reach from the pupil to the end of the iris: this is the circumference of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see this very thing in the pupil of the eye, because of the clarity of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then place the [speculum] until it reaches the place where the aqueous humor is
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press the lower eyelid down one after the other.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If the water therefore descends immediately, the diseased part will immediately retract from that which opens the pupil, and the speculum in the eye itself
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest for a while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If the water descends again, then withdraw the speculum again, except for the part that is withdrawn by the speculum itself.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When it has settled and does not ascend: then withdraw the speculum easily: and you will rotate your hand slowly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in the water some clear salt of the gem: and wipe with it when you are done
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put over the eye the whole bandage, or soaked wool fattened with saffron, and alum: and bind with it the healthy eye
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We, however, and those who are with us at this time, put over it a rough plaster with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If it does not admit the speculum to enter the eye on account of its hardness, because it is from a person whose eye is hard and thick: then it is necessary to take the almond-shaped scraper, which is called the Alberid, which has this form.</start_of_turn>
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Scrape therefore with it only as much as is necessary, and do not move your hand too far back: and do not do anything that may cause injury to the eye.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then insert the almond, as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	Then insert the almond, as we have said. And in order to complete the work of your operation, prepare for the patient a dormitory made in the center: in which he shall sleep upon his back in a dark room: and it shall be guarded from all movements, and from coughing: and let food be given him of that which soothes the nature of his ailment: and let him not move his head to the right or to the left in any way.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And let the ligament be adjusted according to its position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then let it be resolved in that dark room, and experience its effect: and make him drink something
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligament until the seventh day
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it should not be forced that it be done at the time of the treatment, or immediately after the incision: indeed it should be delayed, because water ascends quickly through the swollen part
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If, however, a cold abscess should happen: then it is necessary that you wash the eye before the seventh day: and correct it with that which settles the abscess: until it is settled: then give him to drink something orally which will regulate his discharge during those few days, while it exists in that dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then he shall gradually go out of the room and return to his home.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And know that in this matter the pupil is not excused from his vision for a long time: then indeed he will hear about the operation
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And indeed some of those from Alayrach are saying that an almond was perforated in the magdan in Alayrach, from which water comes out
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But indeed no one in our land has done this: neither have I read of it in any of the ancient books: and it is possible that this is something new
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	These are the forms of the species from great things, so that they remain upon them who know them not.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Be like the air itself: their extremities are like the three angles of a triangle, and their summit is acute.</start_of_turn>
Formae magda.	Great things.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care of the newborn flesh in the nose.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXVI.</start_of_turn
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When various meats are born in the nose of a scorpion, there is something which is absorbed from them that causes many feet: from this comes the cancerous tumor, the stone, and the brown scum: from this also is the soft tissue, not brown.</start_of_turn
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	Therefore, in that which is soft from these meats, not fraudulent, neither cancerous, you must sit with your hands opposite to the solid part, open the nose and throw out the mucus into those meats: then draw them out to the exterior and cut away whatever you find with a fine acute knife until you know that all the meat has been removed.</start_of_turn
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If anything remains of that from whose excision is not possible: then cut it away with a fine instrument until nothing remains of it.</start_of_turn
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If, however, blood should dominate, or a thick clot form: then oppose it by that which will overcome it: either by malignant clots, then burn them out until the blood is separated, and remove all the meats.</start_of_turn
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then throw into the nose after the incision of the socket, and water, or liquid.</start_of_turn
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose is opened, and there proceeds from it moisture up to the palate, then you know that it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If moisture does not penetrate, according to what is necessary, then you know that it is within the living tissue that lies above the roots of the nose bones, which does not emerge with the cutting of the instrument.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Therefore it is necessary to introduce a thread of linen of some thickness and to knot it in many places: and to place between every knot an amount equal to the breadth of a finger, or less: and the patient will vomit, so that he shoots out one end of the thread through the nose along with the clot, until it reaches the stomach, and comes out through the gut.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And many do the same thing as this young boy Attom in school: and it is easy for him who wishes to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two ends of the thread, one that comes out through the nose and the other that remains in the nose
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	And the minister closes the wound with knots that are in the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you know that the flesh is again with the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then withdraw the thread: and place in the nose after washing the blood away a little of the unguent that you drank with the Egyptian unguent: do this three days, or more, until the unguent has eaten away all that remains of the flesh
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then put in the end of the matter in the nose a lead cannula for a few days, until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however urgent is the treatment that requires it, do so.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the application of the caputpurgium, when oil and other medicines are distilled in the nose, do this from silver, or from air: and let its mouth be like that of a small trumpet, opened like a conch: and its content like that of it.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	If one wishes to make a closed incision, like a needle.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	If one wishes to make a closed incision, like a needle.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	This is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	About the care of the nose.
Caput XXV.	Day 25
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Many are born on the tip of the nose of Thelul, and they grow large and increase in size with the days, until the wound becomes equal to their appearance
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of this, it is necessary that you cut away that part at the beginning of its appearance, and remove all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place something over the place, or cauterise, or apply a burning medicine to the place of it
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If, however, the incision tardies, until it has grown large, then consider whether it is a stone, hard, brown in colour, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron: for it is a cancerous swelling
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	Many indeed are the waters which cause swelling of the head, and which arise from it with great malice towards the light which they had before.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the swelling is soft to the touch, not brown in colour, and if the incision is possible throughout, then evacuate the patient and cut it without fear, without hesitation: and care for the place with something that dries and contracts, until it heals
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	About the stitching of the nose, and the lip, and the ear.
Caput XXVI.	Day 26
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when a solution of cohesion is continuous in a soft cartilage, it gives little support in that operation, except in some people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore when anything happens to anyone from that, that you consider whether there is a wound remaining with its blood: and then add the pain of the wound with the suture: then care for it until it is healed.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	If the edges of a wound have been separated by continued tension, and every part is sound: then it is necessary to scrub all the parts from their outer surface until they bleed again.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then add the lips together with the suture, and tighten them, and sprinkle upon it dragon's blood, and resin: and place above the powder a piece of plaster of Paris, and something else of solid plaster: and leave it bound for two days, or three.</start_of_turn>
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then dissolve it, and change the medicine: and leave it, until the threads are dissolved by themselves.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The way of suturing is to add tension continuously, or with a hook, as we have narrated in the suture of the belly: or to add tension with the thread, as you have been told.</start_of_turn
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	About the extraction of the knots of the lips.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn>
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people suffer from swelling in the insides of their lips, resembling hard grains of herbs: and some of them are small, and some are large.</start_of_turn
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore it is necessary to cover the lips, and find on every knot of them, and suspend it with a hook, and cut it off from all sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then apply to the place after the cutting a little burnt ointment, until the blood is stopped.</start_of_turn
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then it is bound with vinegar, and the place is cared for with it, in which there is a sticking [agent], until the wound is healed.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	From the incision of a new wound over the jawbone.
Caput XXVIII.	The head is in the eighth position
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many veins are born over the jawbone, as the ancients call them abuluss
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	It is necessary therefore to suspend them with a single thread: or to grasp them with forceps, and cut them at their root, and let the blood run, or the serum
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then put upon the place the dry sponge, or other powdery astringents, desiccant.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	When the flesh returns to its place after treatment, for many return, then cut the vein again, and cauterize it: for it does not return after being cauterized
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	On the reason of the tooth with iron
Caput XXIX.	The head is in the ninth position
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When they gather on the surfaces of the tooth from the inside and outside parts, and between the gums, the hard, rough coatings, and sometimes they decay, and become yellow, until it reaches that corruption of the gum, and the teeth become loose
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	It is necessary therefore to make the handle of your hands firm between your hands, and to put your head in your mouth, and to move the molar and the tooth, in which you see the coatings, and something like sand: until something remains from it, and do the same with black pigment, and yellowness, and yellowing, and other things until it moves
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore it is removed from the beginning of the reason, it is good: and if not, then repeat the reason on another day, the second day, and the third day, until you have finally completed the study of that which you desire
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And know this, that the tooth requires diverse rasps of different forms, many figures: according to what is prepared for your operation: forasmuch as the rasp which radiates from the lower part is different from the rasp which radiates between the teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	These forms of rasps are prepared for you, which you will need
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	For the extraction of teeth.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary to cure the tooth from its pain with all skill, and then to eradicate it
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	There is nothing that can replace its sublimation when it is eradicated: because it is a sublimed substance: until such time as there is no excuse for the eradication of the tooth, then it is necessary to command that the sick man eradicate it, so that it may be strengthened, and be confirmed to you that the tooth is painful
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	Many indeed deceive the sick with pain, and say that it is in the tooth itself and eradicate it: but the pain does not depart, until the sick tooth is eradicated
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we know that this is from the operation of bloodletting
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When it is confirmed to you that the tooth itself is painful, then it is necessary to sacrifice around the tooth with sponges, in which something useful is to be found, until the gums are separated from all parts: then move it with your fingers, or with fine forceps at first slowly, until you have crushed it
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place the large forceps in that place well, and hold the patient's head between your knees: which you have held well, so that it does not move: then draw out the tooth according to its straightness, so that you do not break it
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then take some of those instruments and introduce it under it from all parts with ease, and try to move it, as you did at first
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If the tooth is perforated or corrupted: then it is necessary that you fill up that hole with wool: and bind it with the extremity of a thin thread, so that it does not break in the hour of your constriction over it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary that you take care of the surrounding gum from all parts much with scraping during the process of extraction.</start_of_turn>
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And keep your courage, so that you do not break it, and remain over it until that evil has gone from it which is greater than its first pain.</start_of_turn>
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Beware, lest you do the things which the phlebotomists do carelessly in their haste, and your audacity over the eradication of it, beyond what we have said.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	Many men have made great mistakes through their pride over people's great diseases, from which it is difficult to recover, and that remain whole, or extract some of them, or extract the whole thing with some of the teeth of the jaw: as we have often seen.</start_of_turn
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then it is collected after its eradication with wine, or with vinegar and salt.</start_of_turn>
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If blood flows from the place (for many men it happens): then there is something of the clot there, and fill it with that: and if not, cauterize it if it does not bring you the clot.</start_of_turn
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The forms of the fine forceps which you must use to move the tooth in the first place: let their long extremities be broad, and their short handles be thick, so that they do not bend when pressure is put upon them with the hand: let them be like the jaws of large beavers, until when you bind them with the thread, they do not break themselves, neither bend: their short extremities must be strong and made of iron, or of twisted wire, directed towards the extremities: and in their extremities must be teeth, some of which are mixed with others, and bind the constriction gently, firmly.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when extremities resemble the shape of an eagle's beak, which is called ciconia, and are subject to strong constrictions.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Concerning the removal of teeth and the extraction of fractured jaw bones.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter I
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When there remains in the eradication of a tooth which has fractured something, it is necessary to place butter on the area for one or two days until the place is softened: then introduce forceps into the cavity, or graspers: whose extremities resemble the beak of an eagle, which is called ciconia
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The form of these forceps is as follows:
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their extremities are made like a file or like an awl
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If these forceps do not suffice to extract the tooth, then it is necessary to make an incision over the root and remove the entire pulp, and introduce a small forceps, which is called Palanca parua, whose shape is as follows:
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Its short handle and large head: and it is not to be grasped, lest it be broken
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through this, that is good: and if not, it is necessary to use other instruments whose form is similar to these
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The first triangular shape of the extremities, in which there is some thickness
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The fine triangular shape of the extremities
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument which has two branches, whose shape is as follows
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with other instruments and materials which are appropriate for teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It is also necessary to grasp with this instrument which resembles a large single unit, of this triangular shape of the twisted extremities, which has some thickness, so that it does not break: and it must not be grasped
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	Know that the instruments of the teeth are many: and like the rest of the instruments, they do not all work in the same way. And a prudent craftsman, skilled in his art, finds for himself the appropriate instrument according to the operation and the ailments of each.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For the ailments of which the ancients did not speak, there are instruments appropriate to each.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, the jawbone is fractured from the tooth, or from any other bones of the mouth, or if it is putrefying: then one must look closely into the place itself with the instruments and forceps which I mentioned in the extraction of roots, and handle with care, as its form is like this
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	It is there in some degree of length, so that it may be tied up or held with the bone, and not flee and break, until the bone is extracted: and restore the place with the physicians who are accustomed to this
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If there is only a small amount of pus in the bone, then drain it from its pus, and care for it, until it is healed.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	As for the elevation of prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 2.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth are prominent not according to their natural course, a wound is made by that shape: and especially when this happens in women and girls, because of their gums.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	One must therefore consider this
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	Because if a tooth has grown after another tooth, and is not located, or if it is possible to suture it, or to smooth it: then extract it: and if it is joined to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, which has this shape
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small knife, made of iron, with acute extremities blunt.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be such as that which you make on many days, on account of the hardness of the tooth, and that it does not cause damage to any other tooth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, the exposed edge of the limature is prominent: then limate it with the same limate which has the form of this
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	Let the whole edge of the limature be grasped by the lesser points of the handle, like a limate which is made for a needle: with which the tooth is slowly pared away in many days with ease, without causing damage to the tooth, and falling out: then soften it, finally smooth it with some rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If the tooth from which a part has broken away, and which hurts the tongue: then it is necessary to limate it also, until the asperity of that fracture has been removed, and it has been made even: and it must be flattened, so as not to hurt the tongue, or corrupt the speech
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Concerning the restoration of teeth with gold wires.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When it happens that the front teeth are cracked and bruised by percussion, or in any case: and the diseased cannot be held in place by the bite of the food which he habitually swallows: and when treatment with medicaments has no effect: then the wit is in this, that they be bound with gold wire: for gold is white, and does not putrefy after a few days: but silver never changes
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the middle wire be in thickness and breadth as much as it can grasp between the teeth
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of the restoration is that you grasp the wire, and pass the loop through between two healthy teeth: then you twist the two extremities of the wire between the teeth which are moving, whether one or more, until you have reached the healthy tooth of the other side
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Repeat the process until you reach the part from which you commenced: and grasp your hand with care and wisdom until it does not move forward: and let your constriction be such as to bind the thread at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip away.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Repeat the process until you reach the part from which you commenced: and grasp your hand with care and wisdom until it does not move forward: and let your constriction be such as to bind the thread at the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip away.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it is dissolved or fractured, string it with another thread and stabilize it as before for the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the form of teeth, and the figure of the rotation of two sound teeth and two moved teeth, as with water
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And when it happens that one tooth or two have fallen out from their places due to an injury, they must be returned as we have described, and they remain: and this does not happen except by a skillful, prudent, and experienced artificer
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when some piece of bone or cartilage has been adjusted: and it is made like a tooth in shape, and is placed in its place, from which the tooth has been extracted and is bound, as we have said: and it remains, and serves for a long time
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Regarding the incision of the ligament that happens under the tongue, and which hinders speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When this ligament under the tongue occurs naturally, as it does in the birth of a human being, or accidentally due to an injury which has consolidated.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation in this is that you open the mouth of the sick person in his cheek, and elevate his tongue: then cut through that nervous ligament along its width, until the tongue is freed from its retention
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is anything hard or knotty in that area, and it comes from the consolidation of the wound: then project into that tissue and find it by its breadth, until you cut the ligament, and the knot will be resolved.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Take heed, that there be no fracture in the depth of the flesh, and cut the artery there, and the flow of blood will increase.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then it is to be bound in a wet bandage with rose water, or with vinegar, or with cold water
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then put under the tongue a cloth of linen, which shall hold the patient throughout the night: so that it does not consolidate in the second place
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	If, however, the flow of blood increases, then put over the place a soaked compress of alum.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If blood boils, then cauterize the place with a blunt cautery, which agrees with that: then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	On the extraction of the ranula which is under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 5.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Whenever there occurs under the tongue a swelling which assimilates the small ranula, hindering the tongue from its natural operation: and perchance it increases so much, that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation in this is, that you open the mouth of the patient before the sun: and consider the swelling.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If therefore you see the same dark, hard swelling which does not have any sensation in the infirm: then do not touch it, because it is cancer
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it inclines towards whiteness, in which there is humidity: then project into that tissue and cut it with a fine scalpel, and free it from all sides
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood flows upon thee in the hour of thy operation, then lay upon it a dry sponge, until the blood be separated: then return to thy operation, until thou hast extracted it with its complement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply vinegar and salt: and care for the rest with such treatment as is suitable for this, until it be healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	On the treatment of the wound of two almonds.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 6.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When they happen between the guttur godad, that is, the glands which resemble almonds, which happen outside: and they are called two almonds: which when you cure with that which we said in the discourse, and they do not heal, then consider it
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If there is a hard wound, of a dusky colour, with little sensation: then do not touch it with iron
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if it is of a red colour, and its root is large: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather let it go, until it is healed
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either perforate it: or it will rupture by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is of a white colour, round, and its root is slight: then you must cut it off
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation in this is as you consider before your operation, if the wound has calmed down completely, or if it has diminished somewhat: then do sit the patient with his head towards the sun: and open the mouth, and take out the tongue with your hands, and grasp the lower lip with an instrument, which has such a form.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Do it from silver, or from air, which is subtle like a knife
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When therefore the language is spoken, and the apostema is shown, and the latter falls upon the former: then take the hook and grasp it in the belly, and draw it out as much as is possible, except that you draw out with it something from the tunics.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut the wound with the instrument whose form follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	Like scissors: truly the extremities of these are curved, so that the opening of each is directed towards the other at an acute angle: from which care must be taken lest there be iron or blood soaked into the wound.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then cut with the sponge, which has this form.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Be acute from one side, not from the other side.</start_of_turn>
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you have cut the belly once, cut the other following the same kind of incision.</start_of_turn>
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision the patient shall gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.</start_of_turn>
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If however blood flows from it, gargle with water in which are pounded coriander seeds: or leaves of myrtle, or things like these from the sponges, until the bleeding stops: then care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there appear in the belly other apostemata, besides the two in the tonsils.</start_of_turn
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Cut these therefore equally according to what I said in the incision of the two tonsils.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I myself have treated a woman with an apostemate which was born between her ribs, which was drawing towards the loin, little sense, because it was almost strangling her: and the woman was breathing from meatus strictus, and I forbade her from eating and drinking: and she died within one or two days.</start_of_turn
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The after-tooth shall ascend only as much as it emitted two branches, until it reaches above the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	The after-tooth shall ascend only as much as it emitted two branches, until it reaches above the two nostrils.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then draw it [the after-tooth] out, and from that there is a large piece [of tissue].
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then cut off what is beyond the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then make that which projects from the other nostril retreat inwards
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then open its mouth, and press its tongue: and afterwards fix the tooth in the after-tooth: then cut off from it a part of it, and there will be no blood there: it is absolutely like the gut of a woman, and immediately drinks water, and then eats food
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	It is not right to continue cutting into that after-tooth for a long time: and the after-tooth will remain in the place where we cut, until it is prolonged excessively and with it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I devised, and cauterized the after-tooth between the gut.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	It stood from the addition [of the after-tooth]: then I went away from that side, and I do not know what God did with it after me
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the incision of a toothless after-tooth
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 7.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When a catarrus descends to the lower jaw, and the after-tooth is long: then it is called a perpendicular: and if it is in the lower part large and round, then it is called a toothless
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is cured with that which we said in the explanation, and the cure does not confer: and you see that the after-tooth is soft and quiet from it: then it is necessary to cut it off
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And whatever is aggregated in a round shape, which has no length, is either blood, or of a dusky or black colour, and has no sensation: in such a case it is necessary to make an incision of it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	And in such a case there is fear over the sick person.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	It is necessary therefore when you are treating it according to the method which I have mentioned from the white colour and the length, so that you make the sick man sit facing the sun: and you grasp his tongue with an instrument of which I have spoken previously: then fix the thumb of your hand in one, and draw out the other: and cut it with one of the two instruments which I have mentioned in the incision of two caruncles
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And it is necessary that you do not cut from it except that which adds to the natural limit without addition
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you cut from it more, you will damage the flesh and the bone.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after the incision make use of what we have mentioned in the incision of two caruncles: and care for it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the sick man returns from the incision: then it is necessary that you use your skill in cauterizing it without fear and haste.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the mode of cauterization in this is not except with acute water: and it is that you place the head of the sick person in your lap
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	And then grasp his tongue with the instrument which we mentioned before.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	And then take from the water which I mentioned before, and mix it with burnt charcoal which has not been extinguished, and put it on it not thick, neither thin, and press from it the concavity of this instrument
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	So that the extremities of it on which the medicine is placed are like the concavity of the radius of a conch shell
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	Place the instrument with the medicine above the vulva: and the patient lies with his side open, so that the fluid may flow out from his mouth from the medicine inwards, so that it does not descend into his gut, and it causes him pain.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.</start_of_turn>
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first keep your hand above the vulva for the quantity of half an hour, until you see it is becoming dark, and give the patient a sedative dose of the medicine.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take the limb, and fold it over the end of the radius, and fold the limb with the medicine inside, and bring the radius with the limb into the cannula above, until the limb is fixed over the vulva.</start_of_turn
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you follow that which you wish concerning the cautery of the vein.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then remove the medicine: for it itself will dry and fall off in three days, or four.</start_of_turn
