Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If however you think that you must go again with the medicine, go again: and after the cautery, remove the surrounding fat of the vein with the limb and soak it in butter, and massage it with that which is around it from the medicine: and wash it with cold water.</start_of_turn
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And care for the outside with stitches, and for the inside with gargling, until he is healed.</start_of_turn
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus is this sort of treatment safer than an incision and longer lasting in respect of fear.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the vulva is healed even with that which is subtler than cautery and incision: it is healed by fumigation, according to this method.</start_of_turn
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, hyssop, origanum, rue, sassafras, chamomile, abrotanum, and similar herbs: gather them all together, or some of them in a vessel, and immerse them in vinegar. Let them boil: and the vessel should be covered with a layer of earth in the center. There should be a hole in the middle of the vessel above which the instrument is composed in this manner.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Make it of silver, or of brass: and insert the extremity, in which is the pomegranate seed, into the bone of the patient, until the vapor reaches the upper lip above the cannula, until the lip is darkened very much
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat over it many times, until it heals.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful, do not perform this treatment at the beginning of an attack of apostematis.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Praiseworthy are you for adding this in apostemate: and it is not proper to do this except when the apostematis is cool
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If, however, this instrument is not present with you, then take a needle and compose in its extremity bark or resin: so that it does not burn the bone of the patient: because the bark or resin of the resin prohibits the vapor from burning the bone: and this is from a good treatment with health
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	About the extraction of thorns, and bones from the gullet.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times there adheres in the gullet bones, or thorns of fish, or something else.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore that you extract what is apparent from it which falls from the tongue with the instrument at the angle of the jaw, and it is declared to you that it is in the gullet
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what is not apparent to you and is hidden in the gullet, you must make the patient vomit before the food is digested in the stomach
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps then the adjacent thing will depart through neglect.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the sick man may swallow down a piece of bread, or a radix of lettuce, or swallow down a dry lump of barley: or he may take a dry sponge of sea-foam and bind it up with a thread, and then swallow it down.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it has reached the place where the bones or spines are, and is drawn out, then it departs.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not depart with it as we have said: then use an instrument of lead according to this form
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius of a bean, and at its extremity there shall be a curve which will enter the gut without difficulty: and let it have its head elevated upwards
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And take care of its touch upon the epiglottis, so that it does not cause it to cough, and drive it down with the bone or the spine, or let the physician drive it in with his hand
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But that the sick man may drive it down himself is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the annexed thing: and he drives it downwards, or pulls his hand with the instrument upwards, all of which is according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it departs
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the extraction of blood clots.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the blood clot is treated with that which I have said in the previous section for the treatment of wounds with the physicians, and it does not yield, then consider in the belly of the sick man under the sole or at the base of the tongue, after having drawn out the tongue with the instrument which I have mentioned.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your hand should slip over the blood clot, draw it out with a small hook, or with fine fingers that are withdrawn from the middle.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with the fingers: then take a curved cannula and introduce it into the belly of the patient up to the guttur: then introduce into the curve of the cannula a burning iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the patient abstain from all water for the whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then take a full treatment of cold water, and open his mouth with it: and close his mouth with it, and do not swallow anything from it: and drink water an hour after each meal with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The bloodsucker is like him who feels the water falling from his hand.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not go away with that which we have told you, then fumigate the patient with aromatic herbs, or with an asa with an instrument which we mentioned in the fumigation of the wounds
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, because it itself goes away
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the mode of operation in fumigation is that you take all the vessels in which there are dates with fire: and the vessels are covered with a cover, in the middle of which is a hole: and make in that hole the extremity of the instrument
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation, and put the patient's mouth on the extremity of the cannula, and close his mouth, until you know that the fumigation has passed to the bloodsucker
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the bloodsucker immediately goes away.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not go away, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient can tolerate sitting, and eat garlic and onions, and does not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he goes away with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	This is the form of the instrument with which bloodsucker is extracted from the gut, when it falls upon its belly.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like forceps, thus like a wound: for it has the curvature which intrudes into the gut
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the beak of a stork, which is called ciconia, in which there is the roughness of lime: when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	About the opening of the apostemata, and their section, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.</start_of_turn>
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of apostemata, of many kinds, according as the recollection of their matter: and they are diverse in their perforation and their section into two modes.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of them is a kind of apostematum which comprehends humilities.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	The other is because of the place where it occurs in the body
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	For indeed the apostemata that occur in the head are different from those that occur in the belly: and those that occur in a fleshy place are different from those that occur in the joints: and each one of them has its own judgment from the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	There are also apostemata which do not need to be perforated except after the perfection of health in the body, and the completion of their matter: and there are those which must be perforated while they are raw and have not matured according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Such as apostemata which are close to the joints
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	For when an apostematum occurs near a joint and persists, it may putrefy because of the surrounding parts, perhaps corrupting the ligaments or nerves of that joint: which is the cause of the closer contraction of that limb
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	The swelling is at the main limb: for if you delay the perforation of it until it ripens, then it will bite you or become infected, or through that main limb.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	The swelling is close to the limb, perforate it therefore while it is still immature: and it must not be perforated as a raw swelling, without complete digestion, except that it is close to the limb, lest it putrefy deeply, and extend to the inner parts, and make a fistula, or remain in its termination without healing.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of perforation of the swelling, for it is matured according to the completion of its complement: and it is at rest in soothing of pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness, and pulse, and elevation of the head of the swelling: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	It is necessary that you make the perforation in the lower part of the swelling, and more elevated: and let the perforation be wide in length of the body, if the swelling is in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of laceration, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all the places that do not have a reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those things which reflect, be cautious with the perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When the swelling is in the places of carbuncles: then it is better that you delay the perforation of it until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to the complement
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate it before that, the course of the poison is prolonged, and there is much dirt and pus, and perhaps the lips of the wound will be inflamed, and its depth will be increased
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some swellings are perforated according to the width of the body for necessity: or according to that which the limb requires
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	It is necessary to perform a small perforation in the small apostemata and a large perforation in the large apostemata: or multiple sections according to the size of the apostemata.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	Some apostemata require the skin to be sutured: when it is made like a piece of cloth and is completed at the end, when it is dead. This is like what happens in many cases, such as with wounds from a dog bite and abscesses
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	There are also those which are sectioned with three angles
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	Like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like the heel apostemata.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	There are also those which are sectioned in a circular shape and those which are sectioned like a half moon: and those which are similar to these sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	This is true of those which do not have a head, such as the superficial leninous apostemata: it is necessary to perforate them with a superficial perforation, or only planely.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when the apostema is large, and when many stitches have been gathered together, and it is perforated, so that the pus does not spill out immediately: extract a part of it from that very moment
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then anoint the apostema until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree of the case: especially if the patient is weak in spirit, or a woman in childbirth, or a young child, or an old man: for the spirit of the animal is dissolved with the discharge of the pus: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not know it
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take great care with this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have made the perforation, concerning which perforation you have made the after-effects, it is necessary that you should drain the blood: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a little blood after the perforation, or if it is a flat section, then administer a ligature from linen, or from an old coat
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if there is great bleeding and many holes of perforation, then it is necessary that you should introduce a ligature into every hole until they reach the belly.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have cut off a part of the skin in the after-effect, or if you have circumcised the area: then it is necessary that you should put on an old coat, or as when a garment is being taken off, or be covered with wool without moisture: and bind it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it and take care of it until it is healed
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If, however, bleeding occurs during your operation in an hour, then administer cold water and vinegar, after which soak it in a cloth: and put it over the site of bleeding many times over
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If bleeding persists, then it is necessary that you should administer regimen and care, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this book, and from experience.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is in the winter and the site of the after-effect is of many nerves: then it is necessary that you should infuse sponges with wine and oil of warmth: and put them on the place.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer and the place is fleshy: then it is necessary that you should put on sponges soaked in water, or oil, or both with wine and oil, and keep it cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must dissolve the after-effect, and drain it, and administer care which is suitable for it, until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is indeed necessary for the knowledge of the treatment of wounds in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the nature of the wound, indeed I have spoken of every wound in general, how it is necessary for its treatment to be considered individually
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	Concerning the section of wounds that occur in the head skin.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small wounds occur on the head skin, and they are of the kind of nodules which contain tunics, which are like small bags: as if they were chicken eggs
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	There are many kinds of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	There are those which are fat: and those which contain moisture like slime: and those which contain moisture like wet earth and gravel: and similar to these, and those which are hard stones
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and in their extraction, there is no fear, as long as during their section no artery is injured.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their section is to learn how to use the instrument which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then dry it with the superficial section: in this way.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin with the incision from line b to line g. When the moisture has been evacuated, then remove the sac which contains it, do not leave anything behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Many times it returns, if anything remains of it
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then soak the wound in Egyptian unguent if it is there: or in water and salt: and apply with it a willow, and remove it on another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The wound has eaten away what remains of the bladder.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Repeat the procedure above on the wound with the second and third aegyptio, and if you still do not see that anything remains of the bladder, then indeed take care of the wound with unguent until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the wound still contains a pimple: then dry it out in this way, making a cut having the shape of a cross: and remove the nails between the two layers of the cut, and scrape the wound from all sides: and try your skill in extracting the membrane which contains it.</start_of_turn>
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, it makes resistance, the artery must be dealt with as I shall tell you later.</start_of_turn>
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	Proceed in the same way with a stone abscess, by cutting it open and treating it in the same way as before.</start_of_turn
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	The cutting open of a stone abscess is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some of these bladder abscesses which are in the head of some men, in whom there is no moisture at all.</start_of_turn
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I have cut open a bladder abscess in the head of a woman who was old, and I found the abscess to be like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if I pierced it with anything, it burst open.</start_of_turn
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other abscesses of the head, however, except for those which happen in the heads of young children and near the roots of the ears, the incision should be made on the surface.</start_of_turn
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make an opening at the lower part of it, so that the course of the healing may be downwards.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for that which agrees with this from the treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Then care for that which agrees with this from the treatment of the tonsils in the neck
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many swellings occur in the neck, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes in other parts of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over these which occur in the neck, there is one, and many: and they are generated from one: and every tonsil is within its own sheath, as in the nodes and swellings of the head, as we have mentioned
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the species of these tonsils are many
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these there are fatty ones: and those which contain humors: and malignant ones, which do not obey treatment
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In this way, as the good humors are expelled from the touch, whose mark is the proximity of the color of the skin, and which move towards all parts, and are not connected with the nerves of the neck, neither with the windpipe, neither with the arteries, neither is it deep: it is necessary to cut it off with a superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body from the line b to the line g. and to remove two lips of the skin with one stitch, or with many stitches if necessary, as we have mentioned in the swelling of the head, and to extract it gradually
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is necessary to be cautious so that no bone, or nerve, is injured
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the sponge be neither too acute nor too blunt: so that it does not add to your hand with the incision, or cause discomfort to the patient, and cuts only what is necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut a vein or an artery, or are hindered by the operation, then put in the wound a bit of alum or some powders which absorb blood, and bind up the wound, and leave it until the swelling subsides, and the wound is softened: or begin to putrefy it
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	Blood is severed by the clamp Redi until completion of the operation.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then inquire with your index finger whether anything remains from the other small trophlets: if so, cut easily and wash it away.</start_of_turn>
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If anything is in the groin of the large trophlet: then it is necessary that you do not cut that trophlet from its root: rather it is necessary that you bind it with a doubled strong thread and let it go down naturally without stitching.</start_of_turn>
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then put a sponge soaked in Egyptian unguent under the wound.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum.	Take care of yourself.</start_of_turn>
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the whole trophlet is cut, then it is necessary that you join together the two lips of the wound: and hold them in place immediately, after which you should wash because there is no remaining excess.</start_of_turn
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If, however, you wash and there remains some excess because of the size of the trophlet, then it is necessary that you insert your finger under the root of it and extract it: and administer the suture as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And whatever contains moisture from the trophlets, perforate it with a superficial perforation: so that you can see the place of its maturity: and put the perforation from this which follows below the body as we have said.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation lint with unguent, and the like, so that it may consume whatever remains from the corruption: until when you wash the wound will be clean: then take care of yourself with the generation of meat, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Of the excision of the epiglottis from the apostemate within the gut.</start_of_turn
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients say that this part of the epiglottis was made by none other in our land, and this is the writing of their speech.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in cases of swelling of the joints, it is necessary to make an incision of the epiglottis: since it will not receive any benefit from it, because all the veins and lungs are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	And in those who have a soft swelling in the mouth, or the gullet, or two glands of the tongue, when there is no inflammation of the windpipe, it is necessary to make an incision of the epiglottis in order to escape from the destruction which is caused by the accumulation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore, when we wish to cut the epiglottis, to cut under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small incision in the middle of the two circles, as in the case of the epiglottis of a hare: for this place is suitable for the incision, because it is bare of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are long
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	And if the physician is timid, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the throat with one finger.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then find the skin, until it reaches the windpipe: there will be blood in the wound.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the soft tissue which we have mentioned: and it is signified above the incision of the windpipe by the phlegm which comes out of it, when it is ruptured, and the cutting of the vocal cords.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And withdraw the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When an hour has passed since the inflammation has subsided, gather together two lips of the wound of the skin, and sew them up alone without cartilage
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer the medicines which make the flesh grow, until healing is accomplished.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis writes: Then administer the medicines which make the flesh grow, until healing is accomplished.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Thus we have learned from this discourse that the exposition is not to be delayed, except when the patient has fainted from pain: for the patient has perished while breathing, and wishes to interrupt his breathing: the epiglottis is split, that the patient may breathe through the wound in the throat, and he recovers from death. Therefore they command that the wound be closed, until the harmful cause of the disease has passed away. And the harmful cause of the disease is in most cases three days, and almost like the disease itself: therefore they command that the wound be closed again when the disease has passed away, and that it be cared for until healing has taken place.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that is what I myself have seen: a handmaid took a knife and put it into her own throat, and it went into the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to care for her, and I found her foaming at the mouth, like one who is dead.</start_of_turn>
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw that the wound had burst open, and blood had flowed out of the wound of the handmaid.</start_of_turn
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I was amazed, for she did not bleed to death, nor did she guide the blood: the wind was coming out of the wound.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I cared for her, and I closed the wound, and cared for her until she was healed: and nothing happened to the handmaid except that she coughed up blood: and she recovered after a few days to a better condition.</start_of_turn>
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Hence it is clear: there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the section of the hernia of the gutturis.
Caput XLIIII.	On the section of the hernia of the gutturis.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This chapter is entitled 'On the section of the hernia of the gutturis', and is a large apostema according to the colour of the body: and it is frequent in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	It is classified into two kinds: either it is natural or accidental
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	The natural hernia is certainly not caused by an injury
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental hernia is, however, classified into two kinds: one is like a swelling of fat nodules
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other is like an apostema which arises from the swelling of an artery
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is danger: it must not be presumed that it is small just because of its appearance: and you must prove it and investigate it with an instrument called the Intromisso.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find that it is like a swelling of fat nodules and is not suspended with any other parts: then you must dry it out, just as you would dry out fat nodules: and extract it with that which contains the contents of the sac, if there is one: or if not, then examine the whole of it.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place from which it was extracted until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	'On the section of the super-species of nodules'.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLV.	'On the section of the super-species of nodules'.</start_of_turn
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of nodules, and I have already mentioned all of them in their division: and it is necessary to narrate here the difference between the Node and the Exitus, in case of doubt.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, therefore, that when the Exitus is hot, and there is fever and pain which arise: until the ebullition of excess has passed and the putrefaction is completed: then the fever and heat will subside.</start_of_turn
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the node is not hot, neither feverish, nor painful, it contains blood clots, which is their own sac, and is according to the colour of the body: and it begins like millet and becomes like barley, being greater or less.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	There are two kinds: either fatty [blood clots] or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colour of moisture is various, as I said in the previous section
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary, therefore, when you are dealing with the treatment of the Node, to examine it and inquire about it at first with the instrument called Intromissum, according to the shape which will be shown in the subsequent chapter
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The way of inquiring about the abscesses, and of all Nodes, is to take hold of this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the abscess: and withdraw your fingers gradually until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then you will take the last part of your hand according to the measure of the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum, and consider what comes out through its opening.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If indeed blood runs out, whatever its colour: then dry it with a superficial incision, as I said in the other abscesses
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no blood runs out through the opening of the Intromissum, then you know that it is fatty: dry it therefore with a section having the shape of a cross, as we have learned: and suspend it with stitches, and scrape away the skin from all sides with ease: and keep the clot close to it, until you have extracted it whole with the Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the clot ruptures during the operation, and it is not possible to extract it whole, as often happens in this case, then extract it piecemeal until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	If anything remains from it, a little or a lot, it returns to Node according to its majority.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If anything remains from it, a little or a lot, it returns to Node according to its majority.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large Node, then two of its lips must be sutured, and it must be cared for with that which is contained in it.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If, however, there is a pulsating or non-pulsating vein, then it must be sutured, and its place must be properly cleansed, and it must be bound tightly for two or three days, until the vein has putrefied and the blood-clotting has ceased: then return to the incision which remains from the Node.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Of the instruments outside which are used for cutting and perforating.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	These are the forms of the instruments which are introduced, and there are three kinds of them.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	There are three kinds of these instruments: the large, the medium, and the small
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be of iron, rounded at the ends and flattened in the middle, so that they may hasten the entrance into the abscess
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of the perforators, and no, that is, for piercing: and one of them is called the beris, which is a piercer, and there are three kinds of them
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	There are three kinds of these: the large, the medium, and the small
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They meet, so that they may investigate through these abscesses, and exits, and fistulas, and bubbles from that which is between the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, third, linear, like a large needle which follows under the skin, from citrine, or air, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best of them are those which are made from citrine.</start_of_turn>
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	Experiences also arise from black lead, which unite so that through them fistulas are formed, the cavities of which reflect like lenities themselves with those reflections.</start_of_turn>
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are three kinds again.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For some are long, some medium, and some short, according to the quantity of the size of the fistula and the tightness of it.</start_of_turn
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shape of veins, and there are many kinds.</start_of_turn
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For some are simple, that is, those which have only one curve: and there are three kinds like rivers, great, medium, and small.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And blind veins are three kinds.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And those which have two curves are called haemae: there are three kinds of them: and those which have three curves are called quinary: and all of these are necessary in their place.</start_of_turn
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of scalpels, which cut and scrape nodes and abscesses: there are three kinds of them, for some are large, medium, and small.</start_of_turn
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which make the cut are acute, the other extremities are not acute: and they are not put together except when there is an attempt to make an incision in the tissue of a node near the fear of a vein, or nerve: and so that the patient may recover more quickly from the pain caused by the incision than from the pain caused by the excision of the abscess.</start_of_turn
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magda, and there are three kinds of them.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	These are Magda, and there are three kinds of them. They are made of air, and are similar to Radium, with which alcohol is made: and at the wide end is a hidden Spatumilis point: and in it runs inwards and outwards whenever desired, like water.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of Spatumila which go between the fingers at the perforation of the apostematum: and they are not perceived by the sick: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The winds of the veins when the blood flow is broken: and there are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made of air, or lemon-yellow, round, to the length of a palm, like water: and are subtle.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of veins should be large and small with you: in order to break the blood easily when necessary, and then when there is no physician present
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use these in the breaking of blood in any part of the body, and do not use them except in places where there is carnation: such as wounds of the leg, and hip, and wounds of the arm, and breast, and belly, and groin, and similar wounds, from carnation, humors.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when they are made of these small things which are similar to the knobs of fists, according to their shape: with which the blood is broken when it flows out of the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or artery: and when they are made of these things which are round according to this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	About the care of the breasts of men which assimilate the milk of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some people swell during sleep (that is, when they begin to emit urine in sleep), they become like those of women: and they remain soft after urination.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes this must cut across the breasts with a lunar section according to this shape from the ridge, to the ridge, and then scrape off the whole fatness.</start_of_turn>
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then apply alum from the medicine of incision.</start_of_turn>
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join together the two lips of the wound with stitches, and take care of it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If however the breast hangs downwards and becomes soft because of its size, as often happens with women: then it is necessary to make two similar lunar sections on the two upper sides of it, each containing the other at the limits of each, until one line is greater than the other. According to this shape, from the ridge to the ridge. Then scrape off the skin which is between the two lips and remove the fat, and do what has been said concerning the stitches and powders, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however one does not wish to perform the incision because of the patient's anxiety or because of bleeding: then it is necessary to apply a poultice soaked in corrosive unguent under the breast and let it go, until that which remains of the fat has been eaten away.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Concerning the perforation of the apostemas, which happens under the nipple.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These apostemas which happen under the nipple are of the kind of hard roundworms which contain vesicles, and from these are the humilities which proceed.</start_of_turn
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Whatever is contained in the humors which are exuded by the moon must be cut away with a lunar section, according to this form, from the line b to the line g, as when all that is in the apostemate from the uterus is evacuated, then immediately fill up the cavity with wool and dismiss it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	The cavity must be filled with wool and dismissed until the next day.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the uterus were of the kind of cluster of knots of Strophulas, then cut above it, as we have said in the section above the Strophulas equally
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, a vein extends in this place and emits pus, then administer cautery in it, as we have said above in what precedes
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Concerning the section of the uterus which happens because of the artery and the vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.</start_of_turn>
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is ruptured, and the skin above the womb is consolidated, then much blood flows out from the uterus: and in the same way blood flows out from the veins also, as in it from the uterus and swelling
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the uterus and swelling are because of the artery and the vein, are these: for when the uterus is because of the artery, it is long, gathered in the depth of the body: and when you press on the swelling with your fingers, you feel as though there is a crackling sound in it
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is because of the vein, is round in the belly of the patient
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section above this uterus is dangerous, especially under the ribs, and in the groin, and the neck, and in many parts of the body: and it is very harmful
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is necessary therefore that the care of it should be taken with iron, and that which is also in the extremities or in the head, must also be taken care of.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	For indeed that which is from iron is from the swelling of the artery, which is found in the cut section along its length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with hooks, afterwards the artery: and liberate it from the tunics, until it is detached
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce under these the point, and make the vessel penetrate until the other side, and bind the artery with a double thread in two places, as you have been taught in the extraction of two arteries which are in the intervals
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then cauterize the place which is between the two ligatures with a spatula, until the blood which is in it all has gone out, and the clot is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the treatment which generates pus, until the ligatures fall away: afterwards care for this with suitable unguents until it heals
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	For if there should be a clot on account of the section of the Vein, then you must be careful not to do any damage to the skin with your hand.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce under the place where you held your hand the point, and make the vessel penetrate: and there be in it a double thread, until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with the same the clot with a good ligature: according to what I have told you concerning the ligation of the vein, from two parts with two extremities of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then introduce another point with another thread under the whole clot at the incision of the needle: before that, and bind your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the swelling in the middle of its course, until when it departs what is in it: then cut through the excess of the skin, and discharge what is bound up from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then apply above the swelling the piece which you submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply treatment, which is done with liniments and unguents, until it is healed
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	As for a swelling that comes from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Head L
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as it happens with a swelling in an artery and a vein, in the same way it happens with nerves: that which happens by percussion in the body, or by excessive labor, and in a similar way: and it is most frequent in the armpits, or the calves, and in all the places where the nerves are joined together: and it is a serious swelling
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to that of the rest of the body, and it is found in various positions without pain: and when it is squeezed with pressure, it feels in it a weakness similar to that of stupidity
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	It is not a swelling that is gathered in the depth of the body, but rather under the skin, and it moves to all parts, and does not go forward or backward or to the rear
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Since it comes from the body in the joints, it does not need to be sutured with iron
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps there will be a contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which comes from the body in the head, or in the front, find the skin with a swelling like a bubble
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small swelling, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off from its root
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If it is large, then suspend it with a thread, and scrape it off: then take it out, and gather up the blood with a suture: and care for it until it heals
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Concerning the excision of the apostematus, which occurs in the groin.
Caput LI.	Concerning the excision of the apostematus, which occurs in the groin.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Certain people suffer from multiple tumors in the groin, and in other parts of their bodies, such as the testicles, which are called Fungalia because of their resemblance to fungi.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their root is tough, their head is large, and they are covered with skin.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	They are excised from small incisions, and they grow large in size.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	I myself saw a man who had two of these tumors in his groin, which were larger than any others. There was no difference between them in color, size of root, or in their covering, and they bled profusely from their bases.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore I advise you to excise them, and you will find in one about X and eight ounces, and in the other about six ounces. The operation for their excision is as follows: if the patient is bleeding excessively, and the color of the tumor is white, bloody, and tough of root: then excise it with a broad knife, and be present with cautery in the fire
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Much blood is expelled from their excision. Therefore, if you are overcome with blood, cauterize them immediately
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the patient is weak and timid from the incision with the knife, take a lead weight and make a hook from it, and string it with thread: whose manner is as we have said, and dismiss it in two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead tightly.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease stringing the lead until it is fractured, and falls away without labor
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If, however, the root of the great vessel should be affected, then in its incision there is something fearful and small: especially that which is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	It is true that it is possible to cut through the middle of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then burn it, so that it does not return
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it until the wound has healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not presume to cut through the little one which is of a dusky colour, little sense, and foul aspect: for it is a cancerous tumor. And I shall come back with a reminder of cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Regarding the care of the umbilical cord.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The umbilical cord becomes prominent from many wounds
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Either from cuts on the skin which are above the belly: or it comes out through an opening in the intestines, according to what happens in other ruptures
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, as mentioned before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the clotted blood in it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it is because of a cut in the skin, and the opening of the bowels: then its colour is similar to that of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and it appears in various places
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the discharge of the intestines, then its place is as we have mentioned, with an opening of various sizes
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you touch it with your fingers, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it: and it swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and it causes great pain
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If, however, it is due to humidity, it is soft, then it does not conceal itself when you touch it, neither does it tighten nor add anything.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then at that time the swelling appears with these signs against the black mark of the nail
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If it is due to a broken bone: then it is a swelling that is grave, large, hard, and appears according to the quantity of one
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to a wound, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in this case is as you consider, if the prominence of the navel is due to blood of an artery or vein or a wound: then it is necessary to prohibit the treatment of it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in this case there is fear and danger, as you were taught in the chapter where I said that swelling due to an artery or vein is dangerous
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the navel is due to an intestine or a tumor: then it is necessary to expel the patient, as long as he holds his breath, and to keep him standing extended
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then the signs with encasement all around the navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie down between your hands over his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a bandage slightly wider in the circumference of the navel over the place where you indicated encasement
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the swelling upwards with a large loop.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind it firmly around with thread or silk thread: and make the knot of the ligament well bound.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the swelling extended above the ligament
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find that the finger is caught by the ligament: then draw out the splinter of bone which is projecting inwards, and introduce it into the finger-index, and press the intestine inwards: and if you find a bone, then grasp it with a single hand, and break off its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, on the other hand, the artery or vein is affected: then surround it with much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your work./li>
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And grasp two needles, and introduce them through two strong threads: and introduce two needles around the circumference which you made around the swelling in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the swelling in four places above the needles: and if you wish, remove the needles and leave the place, until the extended flesh putrefies: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it off when it softens and putrefies.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound as it should be until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	Which if the navel-mark is raised from the flesh near it, or from moisture: then it is necessary that you make the swelling concave, as we said.</start_of_turn
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And remove the blood, or moisture, which you find in it.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for the wound as it solidifies the place.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura CANCRI.	§ Care of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.</start_of_turn>
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already said concerning the species of cancer, and how it is to be treated by physicians: and caution must be taken with it when treated with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and we have said that cancer is generated in the matrix, and must be cautiously treated.</start_of_turn
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said, when Cancer is in a place where its extirpation is possible, as in the breast or the thigh, or in like members, from parts which can be excised entire: especially when it is in its beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is great and advanced, it is not proper to approach it directly
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I am unable to cure anyone from this: neither do I know anyone who can do so before me
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in this case, when it is located as we have said, is to proceed as before, and to evacuate the morbid tumor from the black bile several times
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then let us perform a phlebotomy if you find it with the swelling fully developed.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for the operation, in which he is placed alongside the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then join the Cancer to the nails which are convenient to him
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.
