Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then extend the skin which follows the skin towards the upper parts, and dry the whole scrotum thoroughly along its length
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fix in two points of the incision the intestines which are opposite to each other, according to what is necessary to open the section with the intestines: and the incision should be made according to the quantity which is possible, that it may escape from it all things
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then strip the fat and what is under the skin of the testicles, until when the white fat is detected, hard throughout: then insert your finger into that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white fat which is under the skin and the white fat which is between the fats.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move with your right hand towards the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with this extend the white fat upwards, with your left hand: and elevate the gut with the fat towards the part of the incision: and command the minister to extend the gut upwards: and you shall solve the adhesion which is at the complete solution
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And seek with your fingers that there be nothing left of the intestine in the white fat or hard
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If however you find anything there: then push it downwards into the lower belly
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then grasp the clamp, in which is a thick thread made of ten threads: and insert it at the end of the white fat, that is, the tunica which is under the skin of the testicles which follows the incision: then cut off the extremities which protrude from the thread, until there remain four threads.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then form some of the edges over some others in the shape of a cross: and bind with silk thread, as we have said, because it is under the skin of the testicles that the ligament is firmly fixed, until it cannot bear any of the uses which nourish them to send anything to them: so that it does not happen that after the abscess becomes cold.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And put the ligament again outside the first ligament, long enough to be less than two fingers from it
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after these two ligaments let go from the testicles, which are under the skin of the testicles, in the quantity of the magnitude of a finger: and cut off the rest entirely according to the roundness, and take out from it all.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then dry the lower part of the skin of the testicles by cutting, from which blood runs, and heal: as we have narrated before.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply soaked wool under the fat, and put in a wound: and administer the ligament which we have mentioned.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the white fat which we mentioned has been cauterized, after cutting it out with fear of the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Many times this happens.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And let go of the ligament, until it falls down by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If, however, its case is delayed, then it will be embroidered with warm water: and put over that which we have mentioned, until it falls down
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	Then care for the wound with the rest of the care for wounds, until it heals.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Of a swelling that has a root.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In the case of a swelling which has a root, no one should be allowed to handle it with a knife.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And first of all, they say, it is like that which we have narrated in Ramice which is with Vite.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	And first of all, they say, it is like that which we have narrated in Ramice which is with Vite. That is, as a limb hangs loose after its section above it is easy to dry out in the middle, and care afterwards with that which opens it until the limb falls away: and care of the wound, as we have said, until it is healed.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	Of the disruption which happens in the groin.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter LXVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture happens in the groin, as we have said, and the place hangs out, and does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, it is little and returns in every hour: truly if it is prolonged with that time, a tear is added in the groin until the intestines descend into the groin
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens from the extension of the groin, which is in the groin, as we have said
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	That is, because the groin is extended: then it is softened and the place hangs out, and it hangs out.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its care is with cautery, as it was mentioned before
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And when it is cured with iron, in this way: and the patient lies on his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture after it has hung out, and cut across the breadth, according to the quantity of three fingers wide
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then bind the intestines and those which are under the skin, until the fat is revealed which is under the skin following it
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a needle and put it over the place that hangs out from the fat, and press it into the depth of the belly.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then take two points above the extremity of the radius from the sutures, and join them with a suture one with the other: then extract the extremity of the radius.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not perforate the gut at all, neither draw out any strings or anything else, like I told you in the treatise on intestinal branches
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then take care of this cure of wounds.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When you have cut the thread, soften it, and restore the wound until it is consolidated
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Do not pull against each other, and do not add prominence of the rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the marrow.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	Of the softening of the skin of testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of testicles is softened in many people, because the meat which is between them is softened, and its aspect is improved
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is treating him to make him urinate on his back, and to cut away the softened skin over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then join together two lips with a suture: and if you wish, make a surplus of the softened skin by means of three or four sutures, and tighten the suture
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then take care of the cure of the remaining wounds until they are healed, and take out the stitches.
¶ De Castratione.	Of castration.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LXIX.</start_of_turn
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that Castratio has been excluded from our law: therefore, I am permitted not to recall it in this book. It is not necessary to recall it except for two cases.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	For one thing, it is necessary that it be mentioned in the science of medicine whenever Castratio is inquired about: and that one know its treatment when it happens.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	The other is that we often need to perform castration on some animals because of the stench they emit on account of our perfumes, such as asses, hircuses, and cats, and similar animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that Castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by cutting off.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision and division
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the former method, however, the operation is as follows: we make the animal sit in warm water until the testicles become soft and limp, and then we cut off the testicles with our hands until they are completely severed and no longer perceptible to the touch
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration by incision and division, it is necessary to hold the animal firmly and grasp the testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie off the surrounding area, and cut through the skin over the testicles only as much as is necessary: when two testicles have protruded, then cut through them after you have scraped away everything except the fine fat, which is above the veins.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that by attrition: for it perhaps leaves something of the testicles, which the animal desires for coitus.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it is healed
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	There are two methods for caring for Hermaphrodites.
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	The hermaphroditic condition originates from two sources.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of these is that it appears in the space following the testicles, or on the surface of the testicles, between two testicles, like the shape of a female vulva, which has hair: and sometimes urine runs from the area on the surface of the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	There is another kind among women, which is like a female vulva resting on the abdomen just like small testicles, protruding outwards: one is like the penis of a man, and two are like two testicles
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	The treatment for all three types, two of which are hermaphroditic and one which is female, is: to cut away the added flesh until the imprint of the condition has disappeared.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then care for the remaining wounds
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	In the second kind of hermaphroditism from which urine comes out through the testicles on the surface, there is neither operation nor any treatment for it
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	As for the incision of the tenticle and the protruding flesh in the female genitals
Caput LXXI.	Chapter 71
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The tenticle may perhaps be added upon something natural, until it becomes deformed and unsightly: and sometimes it swells in some women so much that it expands like that in men, and persists until coitus.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is therefore necessary to remove the supernumerary tenticle, with or without a vein, and cut: and do not hesitate in the incision, especially not in the deep root: so as not to cause the flow of blood
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound itself until it heals
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	The belly is that which is born from the matrix until it fills itself: and sometimes it departs to the outside according to the shape of the tail: and for this reason they call the disease of the tail.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	Therefore we must proceed thus as we proceed with Tentigin and cure it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	Of the care of the fistula, which is the swelling of a woman which is not perforated.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXII.	Chapter LXXII.</start_of_turn
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The fistula is, as it is a swelling of a woman which is not perforated, or as it is a small opening.</start_of_turn
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental.</start_of_turn
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	The accidental one is from the disease which preceded it: and this itself is either from the native flesh added, or from fine sand, or from pus: and it is either in the depth of the matrix, or in the flanks, or in the upper part of it, or in the lower part of it: and it hinders coitus and impregnation, and delivery, and perhaps hinders menstruation.</start_of_turn
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And the knowledge of it is by the aspect of the obstetrician, if there is an apparent prolapse of the opening.</start_of_turn
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If however it is not apparent, then inquire with your fingers, or with an X-ray.</start_of_turn
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If however the prolapse is from fine sand, and is close to two teeth: then proceed carefully, and break it.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is like putting over two lips two little pillows.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then put your two index fingers of both hands together, and the woman sit with her back expanded and her knees spread wide.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then extend two lips with force, until the delicate sac is ruptured, and the opening is revealed.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then grasp the lip, and soak it in oil, and place it on the place: and let the woman drink every day, so that it does not solidify in another place.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If, however, the sac is thick and tough: then it is necessary to cut it with a knife like the blade of a myrtle leaf
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If, however, the opening is natural from the flesh: then suspend the lip with hooks, and cut it: and there be with you medicines which flow blood without causing harm, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus it is aggregated with alum or white powder.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then administer a wide lead cannula, so that it does not solidify too quickly, keep it for a few days: and administer vinegar from dry lino, then care for the rest of the treatment, until it is healed
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when it is born in the matrix of other flesh: it is necessary to cut according to this manner: while there is no cancerous tumor in the matrix, do not oppose with iron in any way
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	Regarding the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red ones in women's veins.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter 73.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are a swelling of the veins near the opening of the rectum, because of the great flow of blood in them.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When hemorrhoids are thus lessened, they become little; and I have already spoken in the discourse concerning the species of these and their signs: and here I will tell you what is useful for their treatment, and what is not
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, that hemorrhoids which are in the matrix opening, and which do not appear to sense: then there is no need for treatment with iron
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Whatever exists in the cavity of the uterus above which sensation is lost, is to be cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore that you immerse the woman in a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then extend the lobe with forceps, or with a rough cloth, and cut away the roots from them.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powder over the roots above the flow of blood from one incision without causing damage: like acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus, and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then press her feet against the wall for an hour
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then put her to bed in cold water
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the flow of blood persists: then make her sit in a decoction of rue, and nutmeg, and gall, and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on her back
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If blood is therefore separated with it, that is good: and if not, make it adhere to the swellings, and blisters, without incision
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool, and soak in the juice of tarth, or the juice of arnica, or the juice of elderberry leaves, that is, aloe, wine of Ponticus, and make it adhere to the wound
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the swelling has subsided, then care for the place with unguents, until it is healed
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Though it is white in colour like hair, and has a rough appearance
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut away what appears from it, according to what I have said above: and care for it, until it is healed
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	On perforation of the Exitura [a vein] which happens in the matrix.
Caput LXXIIII.	On perforation of the Exitura which happens in the matrix.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Various kinds of abscesses happen in the matrix, such as cancer, stone abscess, ulcer, foreign body, alekilati, herpes, aestiomemus, fistula, hemorrhoids, ragus, thelil, and cold abscess.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I shall say concerning all these ailments and their kinds, their signs, and their treatment in general: it is necessary to speak in this treatise of the cold abscess which happens in the matrix, when it is caused by other abscesses which join health, and to know how to open it with a knife.</start_of_turn>
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary to consider this.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	If the pain of the abscess is acute with percussion, flame, and fever: and you see it turning red: do not attempt to open it immediately: take care of it with something which promotes its maturation, until the acute inflammation subsides.</start_of_turn
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then it is necessary to make her sit on a seat which supports two seats, and she should recline, or be laid across her back, and rest her feet on the lower part of the belly: and let her hips be spread out, and put her arms under her knees, and bind both straps conveniently to that.</start_of_turn
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then sit on the right side the obstetrician, and administer the instrument with which you open the orifice of the matrix.</start_of_turn>
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Which has the shape of the things which are after.</start_of_turn
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary when you administer this instrument, to hold the liver with a deep grasp of the matrix of the woman: so that it does not go deeper into the matrix than is necessary, and does not harm the lower part.</start_of_turn
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	If, however, the instrument be more shallow than profound, it is necessary that you place plugs over the covering of the profound matrix: in order to prevent the entrance of the entire instrument into the profound matrix. And it is necessary that you place a plug, which runs in the instrument, from the upper side: and that you hold the instrument, and that you turn the minister of the plug until the profound matrix is opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When the exit appears, and the hand grasps it, and it is soft and yielding: then it is necessary that you cut it off at its head with a broad spatula.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When the healthy parts have been evacuated, then it is necessary that you place in the wound a cushion soaked in rose oil: or in olive oil, in which there is some astringency: and place the cushion, and withdraw the section from the profound matrix.</start_of_turn>
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place externally over the matrix, and over the wound a bandage of wool soaked in water, in which there are bulges of evil.</start_of_turn>
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then care after two days with an unguent which agrees with it, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the matrix and the wound are washed, it is to be plastered with water and honey: then with water in which there is a radix of lily, or longwort: then return to the unguent.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If the wound has been hidden inside the matrix, then it is necessary that you hinder its treatment with iron, rather treat it with that which we said in the instruction.</start_of_turn>
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Concerning the doctrine of midwifery, how to treat the embryos of women, according to an unnatural figure of egress.</start_of_turn
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter Lxx.</start_of_turn>
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to know in the first instance the figure of natural birth.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to know in the first instance the figure of natural birth.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When therefore you see these signs, you must immediately grasp the uterus so that the embryo may descend more quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it descends over the head, it descends with the second [part] also, and is delivered with those [signs] which are above-mentioned.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever does this for another part is unnatural and harmful.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the fetus comes out feet first, and the body comes out before the head, and the feet and hands together, or the head and hand: or the belly comes out: or perhaps the head strikes against the collarbone, and similar things happen from unnatural figures.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary therefore for the Obstetrician to be prudent and cautious in all these matters, and to be wary of error and excessive force. I show you all the figures of these things and how they are performed, and I explain their significance, and I stand over them.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus comes out head first at its natural delivery, and if it is delivered over the woman, and if it is difficult for her to part, and if the water breaks: then let her sit down, or let the women hold her up. And let her breathe slowly with a decocted vinegar solution and with oily unguents.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the Obstetrician introduces his thumb between the toes of the fetus and finds the second [finger], and grasps it with his finger, until it is freed from the moisture: and press the woman's belly until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not descend, then it is necessary to instill a woman from the fenugreek mucilage with ole of sesame.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to supinate after instilling, that she cover her belly with the palm of her hand, and keep her mouth and nose closed for one hour
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will immediately come out.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus come out at once, then it is necessary to reduce them gradually
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not yield inwards, then place a woman upon a seat, and elevate her feet above her head: then press the seat against the earth: and the woman should be kept steady, that she does not fall upon the concussion
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If therefore the hands do not come out, and the fetus dies: then cut open the abdomen, and extract the fetus: and bind the hand with a cloth, and extract it with an equal force: for it will come out itself.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The emergence of the fetus through the feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus comes out through the feet, then it is necessary to push it upwards: then gradually turn the fetus: afterwards equalize it
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then take hold of one foot and extend it gradually
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they come out up to the hips, then command her to cover herself, and make her lie down: they will come out by themselves, if God wills it.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if they do not come out as we have said, then gradually reduce the fetus until you place it according to the natural figure.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For it will come out by itself when its time comes.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it be forbidden with all that we have said: then take from the slime of elderberry, and ole of sesame, and gum dissolved: and pierce all through in the mortar by a good blow. Then line with it the vulva of a woman, and below the entrance of her belly.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make her sit in warm water, until the jaundice follows.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When the lower parts are relaxed by the heat, then make for her a sieve of myrrh: and support her
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When she has held the sieve for an hour, then make her sit on a seat.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make her expectorate: and bind her jaw and nose: and press the lower part of her belly with pressure from below.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the urine will immediately come out.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The fetus comes out over the knee and hand
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it comes out in this form, then it will enter inwards gradually putting out its hand.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies down on her neck, and hangs her legs down to the lower parts: and she lies lying on a bed, and she covers her hand with her own hand
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	And press above her belly gradually
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	And draw out what is under her feet from the nails, until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not come out, then take hold of her feet, and move them towards the navel.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then press what is above the jaundice gradually, until the fetus ascends to the upper parts
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then put out her hand gradually, and equalize the fetus slowly: and command the woman to bear down, until the fetus comes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The fetus hangs laterally from the hands.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	The fetus hangs laterally from the hands. Reduce the hand
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If it is not possible to reduce the hand, then elevate the woman and make her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is unable to walk, then make her lie on a stretcher: and beat her thighs with a blunt object until she feels pain
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then administer the unguents which you have prepared from mucilages.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she feels relief in the part, then make her sit on a chair
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then study the reduction of the hand, and equalize the fetus according to its natural form: and make the woman groan and instruct her to compress herself until she is delivered.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus has emerged over his collar, with his hands spread out, and his face is towards the back of his mother.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	The obstetrician must grasp the fetus's hand and gradually rotate him, aligning him with ease
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When he is aligned, then place on his navel the unguents which we mentioned from wax and mucilages
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then instruct her to move slowly
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then make her sit on a chair and instruct her to lean towards her right side
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then instruct her to compress: and make her groan with effort.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The fetus is ready to be born on the right side
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it has descended through the birth opening in this way with the second foot, then break the second foot with your thumb until it is expelled from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If the fetus hangs suspended over the face and the neck, then cut the cord from the navel: so that it does not remain and die.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus inwards, until you have placed the cord according to what is necessary: and command the woman to press her hand lightly: for he will himself come out through the easy birth opening.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The birth of twins, or of many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born multiple: and sometimes three or four are born together.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	It is true, but it is rare.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five things indeed are outside of nature, and do not live long: and they are retained together, although multiplied, by one: and they are separated by the navel-string of each of them
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they come out like a single fetus through the natural birth opening, easily: and they come out through the difficult birth opening, as we have told you.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If, however, some of them are difficult at the time of birth, and remain until they reach the figures which we have mentioned as unnatural, then care for them as we have told you: and let the midwife be gentle, and do what she does with ease and with delay, and adapt herself to every figure as she is prepared for her from the ingenuity leading to safety
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that they are formed in the womb from embryos, and are aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and more are formed in the womb: and I have seen a woman give birth to seven and another to fifteen, all of them formed
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	Which is done by the measurement of the glorious learned man
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	This therefore all must be in the science of Obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	It is perhaps like that: it opposes it just as it must oppose that which is necessary
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Concerning the extraction of the dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you care for a dead fetus with medicine as I said in the discourse on medications, and it does not go out, and you must perform an operation with the hand, then you must consider it.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If a healthy woman is virtuous and there is no risk of losing her due to any accident, then you must cause the woman to recline over the lectum, over her back, and let her head be inclined downwards, and her legs elevated: and the minister should hold her from both parts, or she should be bound to the lectum, so that her body is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the os matricis with oily substances with high mucilage, and sponges of aloes, and linseed seeds.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then let the Obstetrician wet his hand with these oils and mucilages: then he will introduce the hand into the matrix with ease
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then he will feel where the ribs are fixed to the fetus, and the convenient place for that.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider then, if the fetus is prepared to descend over its head: then fix the ribs in the eyes, or in the neck, or in the mouth, or in the palate itself, or under the beard, or under the hyoid bone, or in nearby places to the ribs, and under the hypochondria
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If however the descent is over its feet, then in the groin and the middle ribs
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary that the hook grasp the thumb with the right hand: and place the curve of its arch in that which is between the digits of the left hand: and insert it with the hand with ease, and fix the hook in some of those places which we have mentioned, until it reaches the desired thing.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	And then fix the other hook opposite to it, or the third, if necessary: so that there is an equal contraction, and it does not incline to one side
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	And then extend it evenly, and it should not be extended only in a straight line, but rather move towards all parts, so as to alleviate its emergence: as it is done with a tooth when extracting it.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it is necessary in that which is between these, so as to soften the extension.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	That if it be retained from that, then the Obstetrix must grasp any digit with wax, and insert it from the side, so as to rotate it with that which is retained
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If, therefore, a part of the fetus goes out, then change the hooks to another place which is higher: do this until the fetus comes out whole
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If, therefore, the hand goes out before the other, and it is not possible to reduce it because of its coarseness: then it is necessary that it be covered over with the thumb
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	And then draw out the hook until when it comes out whole, cut it either on the joint of the thumb or on the nail, or in the heel: and it is necessary that you make the hook in the other hand, and in the two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If, however, the head of the fetus is large, or if there is a constriction in its exit, or there is water gathered in its head: then it is necessary to insert between the digits the Spatumile spinous, and grasp it with that, and draw out the water: or break it with the instrument which is called Almisdac: whose form comes with the forms of the other instruments in the chapter which follows
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Similarly, if the fetus is of great head size, then it is necessary to remove the afterbirth: either by extracting it along with the placenta, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then grasp the bones with forceps.</start_of_turn>
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	If the head comes out, and remains at the vulva: then it is found, until the moisture that is in the chest is discharged.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If, however, it does not become complicated, and does not yield to extraction: then cut off the head as best you can, as is possible to you.</start_of_turn>
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If there is an afterbirth below the belly, or in swelling: then it is necessary to perforate it, until the moisture from it comes out.</start_of_turn
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If, however, the fetus is above its feet: then its traction is easy, and its direction towards the maternal bone is gentle.</start_of_turn
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If, however, it is caught at the abdomen, or the chest: then it is necessary to extract it with the cloth which you have placed over your hand: and find the abdomen, or the chest, until the moisture that is in it comes out.</start_of_turn
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If, however, the rest of the limbs are removed, and the head returns: then let the obstetrician insert his left hand.</start_of_turn
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If, therefore, the maternal bone is open: then insert your hand deeply into the womb, and grasp the head with your fingers until it reaches the maternal bone: then insert a single hook, or two hooks, into it, and grasp it with them.</start_of_turn
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If, however, the maternal bone is closed, because of a thick afterbirth that has happened to it: then it is not necessary to toil over it, but it is necessary to administer an effusion of liquid and fat: and administer plasters: and sit in waters which soften and moisten.</start_of_turn
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is above its normal size, it is possible to equalize it: then the usual remedy is administered for the fetus which is present.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to equalize it, then it is forced out and extracted.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary that you do not leave anything remaining inside the body.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed the operation, then the usual remedy is administered for the postpartum chills which occur in the womb.</start_of_turn>
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there is a flow of blood, then descend in slippery substances, and administer the remaining treatment.</start_of_turn
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have seen a woman in whom there was a dead fetus: then she was impregnated above that liquid again, afterwards another fetus died also.</start_of_turn
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	It happened to her after a long time that there was an abscess in her belly, and it became inflated, until it was opened: and pus began to flow out.</start_of_turn
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called to her care and I treated her for a long time: but the wound did not heal.</start_of_turn
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I placed over it some strong adhesive plaster: and it came out of the place.</start_of_turn
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then a few days passed by, and another bone came out.</start_of_turn
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I am amazed at this, since there is no bone in her womb.</start_of_turn>
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I thought that there must be the bones of the dead fetus.</start_of_turn>
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I inquired about the wound and I extracted many bones, the woman being in better conditions: and I treated her for a long time, and she stopped emitting pus.</start_of_turn
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment.
Caput LXXVII.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment. Here below is the shape of the Strictor, with which books are equalised, to which are equal two handles at the ends of two sticks.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment. True to this, these vertigo must be made subtler than the strictor: and to do this, either from ebony or from seasoned wood.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment. And the breadth of every stick is like two fingers: and the margin of each of them is like one finger, and the length of each of them is palm and a half: and in the middle of the two sticks are two additions of the same kind of wood, which are fastened in both, of whose length is half of the palm and a little, and whose breadth is like two fingers, or less
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment. And these two additions are introduced into the matrix bone, so that they open when two Vertigines are turned together.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	And I have not fixed this foreign matter until I have ascertained that there is knowledge within it, and an aid for that which the artful physician administers with his hand from the care of the ailment. The shape of the Vertige which opens the matrix.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form like that, subtler and smoother.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	It may be made from seasoned beech or horn, according to the resemblance of the forceps.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	Two appendages are to be added at its extremity, as above: and the length of each appendage is like the palm of the hand, and the width of each is two fingers wide
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you wish to open the matrix with this, then make her sit over a bench, with her feet hanging down, and open that which is between her thighs
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then introduce these two appendages joined together into the matrix: and you are holding the lower extremity of the instrument between her thighs
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like when you are using forceps, equally according to the quantity that you wish to open the mouth of the matrix, until the Obstetrix has done what she wishes
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	Another form of Vertigo which the ancients called the Impelling Force which drives out the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The Almisdac form which counteracts the large head: and is assimilated to the forceps which have teeth at their extremities, like the teeth of the forceps
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is oblunged, like the forceps following this form, like the teeth of the forceps which have teeth like serrations, so that it incides and counteracts
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The Almisdac form which counteracts the small head
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The Vncini form which has a spine like a single thorn
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The Vncini form which has two spines
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The forceps form which has teeth like serrations, with which the head of the fetus is countered
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of the spatumilis has two extremities to cut off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two spatumilis also has two extremities
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are all used, and the more numerous the species are that are prepared by the artificer, the swifter will be the operation and the greater its height among men, on account of their quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	There is no need to despise any of these instruments, because they are all prepared for you.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is not excusable to omit any of them
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	About the extraction of the second (tooth)?
Caput LXXVIII.	Head number 78
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second is retained in the part, then it is necessary to split the lower incisors in order to retain the breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make a groove with the forceps: and grasp the hand over the bone, and restrain the breath of the patient.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it comes out through this, that is good
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then grasp the root firmly, and perforate at the junction of the bone: and place in it savory herbs such as calamine, rue, and chamomile, and saffron, and rue, and cassia twig, and centaury: grasp all of these herbs, or some of them, and immerse them with water, and place them over a fire
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then place a bundle of reeds over the hole in the pot, and the other extremity in the bone: and keep it held until the vapor has reached the cavity of the bone
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make a groove as we said before
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The second will then come out easily
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If, however, after this treatment, he still remains and does not depart: then command the Obstetrician to immerse his hand in the brim of the olive oil or in the thick mucus of the elder.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then he shall insert it into the anus and seek with it the second [part].
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When he has found it, then he shall grasp it and draw it out gradually.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If, however, there be an appendix in the depth of the belly, then he shall insert the hand again, as we have said, until he has found the second part. And he shall draw it out gradually following the rule, so that the belly does not tear at the time of drawing out: it is necessary, therefore, to shift it with ease to the right and left sides: and then add in the quantity of the drawing out.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	It will obey him then, and will be healed, and will depart from the adhesion
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	As for if the belly-wall is closed, as we have said before: treat it with vomiting and with a medication of oil with herbs
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If, however, it does not depart with all that we have said, then beware lest you tire yourself out in the process of drawing out.</start_of_turn>
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	It is true that it must come out at the os of the belly towards the woman's hipbone.</start_of_turn>
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then anoint the belly with unguent of four herbs.</start_of_turn
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	This will make the belly putrefy after days, and will dissolve, and will depart.</start_of_turn>
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	However, when it has putrefied, it will emit a bad odor from the belly and the head, and will cause pain in that place, and make the patient weak.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is necessary therefore that suitable fumigations be administered for that.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancients are experts in fumigation with asphalt and powdered ochre.</start_of_turn>
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The manner in which a woman is fumigated at the second and menstrual retention.</start_of_turn>
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let there be an opening like a cauldron, or from a horn: and let the outside of the instrument be placed over the fire: and let the fumigation be placed upon the branches: hold it until the fumigation is consumed: and do it again.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	Regarding the care of an unpierced animal.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter 79.</start_of_turn>
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born with their navels unpierced, and whom I have seen oiled with subtle saffron.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	It is necessary therefore that the midwife pierce that with her finger: and if not, pierce it with a sharp needle: and be careful of the tear, lest it touch it.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put upon it infused wool in wine and oil.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with nails, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If indeed it is to be oiled, then put in the hole a lead cannula for many days, and remove it when the boy wishes to urinate.</start_of_turn
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And indeed the oiling of the navel also takes place from the consolidation of the wound, or from the afterbirth.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary therefore that the consolidation be dried up, and then care for it as we have said concerning care and lead.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	On the treatment of fistulas which occur in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Of the treatment of fistulas that occur in the lower part.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas which occur in the lower part are of two kinds: Nodation, and Grossitudo, which occur close to any deformity: either in the space of one part or in several places.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When thus the Nodulation is treated, it is opened up and white aqueous moisture or subtle pus runs out of it
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes these fistulas are penetrating.</start_of_turn>
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Therefore penetrating fistulas are recognized by the evacuation which proceeds from them, and the swelling, when the patient evacuates with pain: and sometimes it issues from worms also.</start_of_turn
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And there are fistulas of the kind when they are penetrating right up to the bladder, and right up to the marrow of the bone.</start_of_turn>
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating right up to the hip joint, and right up to the node of the buttocks.</start_of_turn>
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	And thus it is known that a penetrating fistula right up to the bone, even if not penetrating, is that you introduce your finger into the part, and introduce something subtle into the fistula from the air, or from iron: when there is no distortion.</start_of_turn
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	When there is distortion in these, then introduce into the part a subtle lead weight, or a hair from a horse's tail, until you feel the weight, or until the hair enters your finger.</start_of_turn
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	When you do not feel the sensation of the tip, neither is there any evacuation from the wound, neither swelling, nor worms as I have said: then you know that it is not penetrating: proceed therefore to the treatment.</start_of_turn
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	When the fistula has penetrated as far as the bladder or the meat of the urine: then its significance is the discharge of urine from that point, and the prohibition of that from this point in order to consolidate the place with the physicians.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	When the fistula has penetrated as far as the hip joint or the hip bone: then its sign is that it extends up to that point, if there is no curvature of the fistula up to the bone: and the appearance of pain in the surrounding area, and that pus always escapes from that point: and that there is no benefit in that from the medicine, neither is it consolidated with the unguent
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	In all these penetrating fistulas there is no complete cure: and the cure of them is toil and constancy, from the stupid doctors, over whom they are formed.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in those which are not penetrating and are not old, hope of recovery is expected with rest: as I have said above, and as I have proved: and it is that the patient should lie between your hands over his back: and lift up his legs up to above his hips, and his hips should be inclined towards his belly
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead or air, if there is curvature of the fistula, until you know where the tip has gone.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If, however, the patient feels pain around the part: then it is necessary to insert your finger as a sign into the part
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If you feel in your finger that the fistula is penetrating by itself without you having recognized it, besides that you feel between your finger and the flesh, or bone: then you know certainly that it is penetrating: for there is no benefit in that, because it is not its cure, as we have said
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that in some men the wound heals by itself, and from the medicine which is expected to be given to him, it is that you should apply a subtle cautery according to the breadth of the fistula, as it has been said before, and introduce the flame into the fistula until it has gone round the part
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then repeat that twice or thrice until you know that all the added flesh has become softened like the pennae of a bird.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then treat it with softened butter until the flesh comes out: then treat it with unguents which generate flesh and consolidate it
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it is healed, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, then it will not be healed with any other treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if the limb comes out and does not reach up to your thumb which is in the groin, and is between the thumb and the thick hair of the flesh, or if there is a fistula there: then make an incision in that which follows the surface of the skin, then dry the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and you dry with the thumb which is in the fistula until the cutting reaches the end of the thumb, and the thumb comes out.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then soften those softened flesh which have become like the pennae of a bird, so that nothing remains of them
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however blood comes between you and the operation, and separates between you and the operation as you cut those flesh: then it is better that you cauterize with fire, or with acute medicine.
