Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For indeed cauterization with fire unites good habits, adds the adulation of those added flesh, and cuts blood, and dries moisture
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then treat it with softened butter or poultices until the place emits pus, and the softened flesh comes out in the pus
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then treat it with a wound which is consolidated with unguents which generate flesh: and these are medicines which have stypticity and drying power
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	When restoration is complete, then healing takes place: and not by repeated efforts.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	When, however, the fistula persists even to the depth of the bowels, and is prolonged by the excess of bodily humours: then insert your finger into the rectum and inquire concerning the extent of the fistula.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If you feel resistance, and between you and the fistula there is soft swelling of fat or flesh, and there is proximity to the penetration: then there is no operation in that place, except with great trust and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	For in such a case one must use three methods: or else cauterise the fistula itself, as we have said: or dissect it, until you have reached its cavity, so that you can afterwards introduce remedies and achieve a cure from the next moment
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed too much with the dissection, lest you lacerate the wall of the rectum, and cause excessive discharge of faeces without will
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for it as we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will heal by itself: or stretch out the swelling and dry it when it is almost close to the rectum, as we have said, or by means of a hook or other sharp instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then wipe clean the tissues which are left after the dissection, until where the mark of the incision disappears.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	And try to restore the entire wound with the incision, and the upper opening where it is consolidated: and the fistula will remain open in the inner part of the rectum, and will be less painful
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	When you suture the fistula in this way: and that is when you insert your finger into the fistula: and it is at the side of the rectum around the surface of the body with skin and the margin of the rectum: then grasp the perforated extremity, which is like a needle with a head, that is, prepared for the skin, according to this shape.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And insert within the loop of the thread which is bound up from five threads, and round about it.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	And insert the needle with the thread into the fistula, until it follows the curvature of its opening.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If, however, it has pierced the inner margin of the anus near the opening, then withdraw the thread from that hole: so that you may insert your finger into the anus, and withdraw the end of the thread, and join the two ends together: and bind both of them, and let it go on one day, or two days: and the more the thread has penetrated the flesh, the more tightly you should bind it, until those parts of the flesh which are between the two ends of the thread have become soft and fallen away: then take care of the wound, until it is healed, and the fistula is cured
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not pierced: then make it pierce in whatever way you consider suitable, except that it be too deep
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	And do not make it pierce too violently, lest you damage it
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	And do as we have said above, until it is healed
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	Make the sponge of spicery which is found in the fistula, the curvature of which is acute above, and the part which is not acute below, so that it does not damage that which is not necessary, like water
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	As for the stitching of hemorrhoids, from which blood runs out of the incision of them: and the care of the wounds.
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter 81.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids of two kinds.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	Either they are inside the anus, like the stones of a bean or a plum: or they are like the seeds of an olive tree
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And they are small and large: and blood runs from them always, and there is one, and there are many of them
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And there are outside the knee, and at its extremities.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	And those which are outside the knee are mostly few in humidity, from which yellow urine or somewhat thick blood flows: and they are of the colour of the body itself.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	The treatment of that which is inside the knee is, to give the patient something to stimulate the bowels: and to express, until the anus comes out, and the other parts appear.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore also suspend with hooks: or hold with your thumb.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut through at the roots of these things.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If, however, they do not remain in the grasp of the hook, because of the humidity of these things and their softening: then cover them with rough cloth, or with a coat of coarse wool, and draw them out with your fingers
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut through, and powder over the cut whatever fine powder you like, so that it stays in the place of the burn.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or burn them according to what has been said in the chapter on burning
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the knee with the rest of the treatment, until it heals
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	And if the anus does not come out spontaneously, then instill the patient with a small enema, so that it be urged out along with the urine, and comes out quickly when the patient expels it.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	And if the other parts are outside the knee, then the matter is easy, and is like that of a hook: you can grasp them with your thumb, or grasp them with the hook, and cut through them
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for the knee as we have said, until it heals
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	Whoever abhors incision with a knife must administer suture accordingly.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take the thread and pass it through the point.</start_of_turn>
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw out the needle to the upper part, and make it penetrate with the needle at the root from the opposite side: and pass through two extremities of the thread, at the lower part of the needle, and make them lateral: and tighten the knot firmly.</start_of_turn>
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and draw out the needle.</start_of_turn>
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the knots, and let go of the needle: neither do you retain it, lest you cause excessive bleeding.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then put over it a soaked bandage of linen in rosewater, or alum, and put the latter over it: and command the patient to rest.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let it go, until it drops off.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When they have dropped off, take care of the wound with unguents, and leave the treatment until the wound is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	¶ On the Treatment of Incisions.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many of these are caused by the excessive evacuation of feces, and the constriction of nature.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When these have ceased, and they do not yield to medical treatment: then it is necessary to ligate with a sponge or with your finger, until they become soft, and the outer layer is removed from the wound which hinders consolidation.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for the wound, until it consolidates as it should.</start_of_turn
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If, however, they do not consolidate: then repeat the wound with more force than before, until they bleed profusely, and then care for the wound until it heals.</start_of_turn
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	Concerning the treatment of the swelling of the marrow of the teeth and not of the teeth: and of the swelling of the gums, and of the ants.
Caput LXXXII.	Concerning the treatment of the swelling of the marrow of the teeth and not of the teeth: and of the swelling of the gums, and of ants.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You know that Almirmar is not anything other than a round node according to the color of the body, like the head of a nail: and it is found throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and the fingers: and it arises from inflammation of pain while walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is necessary therefore that it be cut off which is around the nail, and be held with forceps, or with a needle, and be eradicated from its root
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for this: and if you wish you can cauterize it according to what is written in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	As for ants, one of them is a small, rough, filtered, rounded elevation above the surface of the body
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they appear in the hands of children many times
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its treatment is that you extend the ants and cut them off: or you tie them up with a silk thread: or with hair, until they fall off.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what is stated previously with fire, or with acute medicine: and thus the inward ants are eradicated, and not the outward ones with the instrument which I say
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	And as for ants, it is also a small, filtered elevation, large, above the surface of the body, which extends inwards downwards: and when it meets with cold, it feels like the bite of an ant, and it occurs throughout the body: and most of them occur in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its treatment is that you take a thorn from the claw of a cat, or a strong bristle: and put it on the ant, until it encloses the circle of the bristle from its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then withdraw your hand with the cannula until it severs what is around the Formica: and place it in the depth of the flesh, and extract the Formica from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	Or if you wish, do this with an air or iron cannula, according to this fashion.</start_of_turn>
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the cannula reach the thickness of the surd which is being pulled, so that it may support the thumb during its withdrawal and its own withdrawal.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	Or if you wish, cauterize the Formica according to what is mentioned in the chapter on cautery of the Athelil.</start_of_turn>
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	And concerning the forms of the instruments which are administered to the Clisteria in ailments of the Ani, and the solution of the belly, and the colic.</start_of_turn
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the Clistera is formed from silver, or gold, or from blown glass, or hammered metal.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when they are formed from these instruments, small and great, according to those in which they are administered.</start_of_turn
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	This is what is administered in the treatment of young children with loose or painful lungs, as well as those clistera.</start_of_turn
Clistere magnum.	Large clistera.</start_of_turn
Cistere paruum.	Small clistera.</start_of_turn
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The cannula, that is, the upper part in which the uterus is tied, should be broad according to this manner: and should have a distinction so that the uterus is tied like water, and the lower part which goes into the belly should be solid, that is, not open, soft, flexible, drawing towards smoothness: and on one of its sides there are two holes, and on the other side a single hole.</start_of_turn
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	The diameter of the opening should be according to the length of the rays; more so the larger, and less so the smaller. And let there be a space within, in which the instruments are placed from the belly of the animal: either from parchment or from skin, which is according to the shape of a small ass. And its root is a single palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	The opening should be perforated with many holes as it is turned, and there should be space between each hole equal to the thickness of a finger
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into the holes a strong thread from raw silk, which is from ten threads, or thereabouts, and twist it together like an ass's hair
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	And when it is placed in this space, it is strung in the head of the clips between two distinguishing constrictions of strength.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	And then clip it with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the shape of the circle which is here depicted, and of the holes
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the clipping with it is: to grasp the belly or the belly from the medicine, which is warmed according to the quantity of the patient's tolerance: and take care that it is neither too hot nor too cold, nor too cold
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	And then the patient is laid upon his back, and raises his legs towards the upper parts: and place under it a cushion, that is, skin over which men lie, or linen
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	And then apply the extremity of the clips with oil, or with alum, or with barley mucilage, or with things of a similar kind.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	And then introduce it into the hole with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	And then grasp the belly with both hands and press it out until it evacuates all that is in the clip into the intestines
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then extract the Clistere, and elevate the patient's limbs towards the side.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the physician thinks that he should remove it, then he should retain as much as he can
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps throughout the night, this is the most important thing in healing.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If, however, you apply the Clistere to the inner parts of the belly, and it brings about the evacuation of its contents: then repeat the Clistere until it is healed
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the rectum, then let the Clistere be gentle and soft, from the Clisteres that are given to children
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of the gentle Clistere which is above that which is strict of the skin.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of wounds of the head without fracture of the bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head wound number 84
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have said in the discourse about the treatment of wounds that it agrees with the book, and I will say here the treatment of them with the hand and also with the help of physicians as a supplement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore that wounds are varied according to the thing which causes them, and according to the place where the wound falls
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	So also the wounds which are made by many things are like the blows of a stone: or the cutting of a sword or knife: or the percussion with a lance, or wood, or arrow: and like these from many things.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds, however, which are caused by the place of the body are like a wound which falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or the limbs: and like these from many parts of the body
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	I am reporting on the treatment of certain wounds, so that I may present a ratiocination and regulation concerning the remaining wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	I shall begin with the simple head wounds: for the recollection of compound wounds is at the beginning of the third chapter
Dico ergo.	Thus I say.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When there is a simple wound on the head and there is no fracture of the bone: consider then, if there is discharge of gravel, or like substances, and if the wound is only superficial: then it is a great wound, and the parts surrounding it are liable to become inflamed because of the heat: then take off the part immediately, and perform a cephalic phlebotomy without delay: and do not delay: and extract from it as much blood as is in its power according to the quantity of its virtue: if there is nothing to prevent it, especially if there is little blood flowing from the wound
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the opposite side of the wound
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient be warned against repletion, and wine, and coarse food.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If however anything prohibits diminution [of the wound], then let him abstain from food, and not approach flesh or drink wine.</start_of_turn>
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And apply to the wound if it happens to him a soft swelling, a poultice of fat bound up in rose-colored earth, or with wine in which there is styptic matter.</start_of_turn
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are secure from the soft swelling, then apply to the wound, if there is blood clot adhering to it, and has not changed its colour, the powder which I will tell you of later: and if it has changed its colour, then apply over it some unguent until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If however the wound is great, or is from a cut of a knife, and like these: and the edges of it do not adhere by means of little hairs, then adhere them together with a suture, according to what I shall say concerning the sutures of these wounds.</start_of_turn
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If, however, a vein is detected to be hanging loose, and it is not possible to retain it, except in a small suspension: then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Care for the vein with the physicians, and restore it in the place of the skin, and command the patient to eat food which is solid in the stomach, such as heads of garlic, and barley boiled, until the pulse is restored: and such things are similar to it.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find in the flesh putrefaction, which does not adhere to the bone: then cut off the putrefied part entirely, and throw it away: then care for the wound
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If, however, in the wound there is an artery, or a vein from which blood flows: and it is not severed by the physicians, then inquire concerning the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If, therefore, you find it not severed, cut it off with sponges, or ligate it.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity compels you when it does not conform to what we have said: then cauterize the vein, until the blood is severed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If, however, these wounds are small and simple: then the matter is easy and light: so that it is sufficient to sprinkle upon them this powder: because it will consolidate them before they change from air.</start_of_turn
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of application of the powdered dressing.</start_of_turn>
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Recipe: mix one part olive oil, two parts dragon's blood, and three parts burnt lime: mix them all together thoroughly, and sprinkle them over the wound, and bind the wound securely, until it adheres well to it and coagulates with the blood.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then stretch it out over feathers, and send it away, and do not keep it until it has become dry, for it will spoil.</start_of_turn
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine.
Caput LXXXV.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Until it is healed, it does not vanish from this medicine
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If indeed a wound is deep, or occurs in that sinus in its lower part where pus is gathered, then perforate it in a depressed spot in that place.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If indeed a wound has incised an artery, and blood flow has ensued: then separate it, or dry it up, and ligate it: or cauterize it if need be.</start_of_turn>
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If indeed fragments of cartilage have fallen out, or all of them, and the surrounding tissue is soft: then gather the edges of the skin together with sutures over the opening of the gut, and do not touch the gut itself, but rather equalize it, and reduce it to its natural shape.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it tightly with a bandage, and discharge it in a few days.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with poultices which have astringency and drying qualities, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If indeed a wound has made an imprint in the bone, then uncover it: then if there are fragments of bone in that place, extract them all, or whatever can be extracted from it: and what cannot be prepared, leave it, until the wound has healed, and the bone has separated and discharged its pus.</start_of_turn>
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If indeed the wound was recent, then powder over it the powder which I have mentioned.</start_of_turn
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If indeed bone is seen in the wound, and a fistula has formed: then care for it as is mentioned in its chapter.</start_of_turn
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	<p>On Surgery in Spatulas.</p>
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.</start_of_turn
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is percussion of a lance or a knife, and you see its depth, then consider.</start_of_turn
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If any fluid proceeds from the wound when the patient breathes, then you know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it does not reach great depth, and it is found with its blood: then do not put in it from the first hour any powder, neither string it, lest the blood remain in its depth and be lost, but return to the heart and kill the patient: but put in the wound a strong absorbent, and dress it twice daily.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If indeed the wound is not present at the place, then put in the opening of the wound a thick wool cushion, that it may absorb what proceeds from it from the humilities: and cause the patient to sleep upon the wound, that the blood which is gathered in it may be cured.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If indeed more than three days or more have passed from the wound and the patient has neither spasm nor bad tremor of the heart nor bad constriction of the breath, nor other symptoms: then you know that the wound is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Care for it also with medicines and with care, and with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed the healing is excused, and it always opens: then you know that a fistula has been made.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Care for it from its head to its tail
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a cut of a sword or a knife, and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then care for it as for that which has been sutured, if it is large: or with powder if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if indeed it has made an imprint in the bone, and there is a fracture from it: then inquire about the wound, and properly remove that fracture, if it is separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If indeed they are not separated: leave them alone, until the wound putrefies, in order that the extraction of them may be easier
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The remaining wounds of the other members must be judged in their curation.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Concerning the wounds of the belly, the intestines, and the bowels
Caput LXXXVII.	Concerning the wounds of the belly, the intestines, and the bowels
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The disruption that occurs in the belly is great, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From the great one, therefore, whenever the intestines or a number of intestines come out
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore, there is an inward displacement of them, and their suture is more arduous and difficult
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small disruption is also difficult in another way
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore, it follows that the reduction of them is more difficult if you do not promptly restore them to their place after their inward displacement: for they swell, open, and become thickened: and thus their passage becomes difficult
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	For this reason, therefore, the medium disruption is better: for with it the reduction of the intestines is not difficult, as it is with the great and small disruptions
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You know that the suture of wounds is done in four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common for the suture of the belly, and for the suture of the remaining wounds of the body: and two other sutures are proper for the remaining wounds of the body.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, there are other two which are more proper for the suture of the belly: and I will narrate both of them with their exposition and their declaration
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say therefore, that when a wound is small, and something from the intestine comes out of it, and it is difficult to reduce it: then that is because of one of the two methods.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Neither because of the proximity of the disruption [of blood vessels] nor because of the inflation in the intestine due to the cold of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When such things are present, it is necessary to heat it [the affected area], as with oil or to immerse a sponge or bag filled with moist material in warm water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil in water a little barley, some cypress and saffron, and embrace with them the intestine until the inflation subsides
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When such a drink has been made which has a styptic power: it is better than plain water in resolving the inflation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When the inflation has subsided, then moisten the intestine with the warm water in which it has been boiled, or with vinegar.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For in this way its entrance will be eased with little things.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If, however, its return recurs after this treatment, then one will find a small disruption, with the instrument used to remove hemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	The first treatment is better when it is prepared beforehand than when it is performed hastily: and it does not cause injury to the instrument after it is necessary and defective
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be acute and the other not acute, and the outer part not be as soft as that of Spatumilis, rather let it be rather blunt: and such is like cheese, as in the drink
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When the vessel has been strengthened and the intestine has been introduced, then it is necessary to reduce it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible: for this is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When, however, the disruption is wide in the lower part of the intestine: then one must make the patient lie on his belly with his head raised higher than his feet.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	If it is in the upper part of the belly, then place its head above and its feet below.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	If there is a disruption in one of the two parts of the belly, then place your intention and consideration on this, that the part in which the wound is be above the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	It is like this with great wounds and with medium wounds also
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make it present between your hands, which hold the disruption whole: and join its lips together.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then remove from it what follows the suture something after something: and this is the manner of common suture of one.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, that you take the needle, or the number of needles according to the quantity of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go from the extremity of the disruption the quantity of a finger-width, that is, the doctor: and fix the needle once beyond what you introduce into the flesh in two extremities of the skin, when two extremities of the fat are made to penetrate from the other side, and when you have brought together two extremities of the skin, and two extremities of the fat: and there are four orders
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then draw with a double thread around the circumference of the needle several times from two parts together, until two lips of the wound are aggregated by a descent.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go the length of a finger also, and fix in the flesh another needle: afterwards pass the thread back with the needle, as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease to do this until you have completed the constriction of the whole wound
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And the needles of medium size are between the length and the breadth: because the fine needles easily slip through flesh, and the large ones are difficult to pass through the skin: therefore it is necessary that the intermediate sizes be between the length and the breadth.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	It is not permitted for the needle to be placed at the two nearest edges of the skin: lest it slip through the flesh too quickly, and open up a wound before the tissue has solidified, and remain extended even after stitching, thereby hindering the healing of the wound
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut off the extremities of the needles, so that they do not wound the patient in his sleep: and place upon them little cushions of wool from all around, which hold the extremities of the needles: and let them go, until you know that the wound has solidified
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this is the kind of suture which is most suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For a small wound, one or two needles, or even three or four, suffice
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second common suture is that in which the extremities are four in number: two of skin and two of fat in one wound, with a needle through which the thread is passed, equal in length and breadth.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then, when you have pierced with the needle the four extremities, reduce the needle from the part from which you began, so that the thread is taut from the upper part of the wound: so that the suture will be like the stitching of cloth. Place between every suture as much breadth as the little finger
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of suture is known to men
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And when I performed this suture upon a man who had suffered a wound from a knife in his belly, which had been disrupted by the intestines up to the amount of two palms from the middle of the intestines, and there was a disruption in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	The intestines stood outside the wound for forty-four hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound closed after remaining open for fifteen days: and I cared for it diligently, and it healed: and afterwards it remained closed for many years, in its original position.</start_of_turn>
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	The physicians judged that it would not heal.</start_of_turn>
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And indeed, I did not treat it with unguents.</start_of_turn
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where unguents were not to be found, and there were no medicines available.</start_of_turn
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I placed above the wound a bandage of wool twice a day, and I bathed it frequently with warm water until it healed.</start_of_turn
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	Two other kinds of sutures I shall describe according to the narration of the sermon.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is thus that you begin with the acute suture: and you enter the hook from the outside inwards towards the interior.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When you have thus penetrated the skin, and in the tear you have made according to the length and breadth of the whole body: let go of the outer extremity in the side from which you introduced the hook, and make the hook penetrate through the opposite extremity from the inside outwards at the opposite end.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have thus made the hook penetrate, then make it penetrate once more in the same place outwards from the outside: and let go of the outer extremity which is in this side, and make the hook penetrate through the opposite extremity from the inside outwards at the opposite end. Make it penetrate just as you did when you made the first penetration in the outer extremity which is in this side, until it penetrates through the whole.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then commence also from this side from the same edge, and draw out the same with the extremity which is from the heel to the edge on the other side, and extract the point from the skin which has penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then withdraw from that skin and draw out the heel which is on the other side with the edge: and extract that which has penetrated from the skin from that side, and make that part one with this and that: and make this part one after the other until its edge is altogether as in this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of all these sutures is as for the sutures of leather: thus as you draw out one extremity from one part of the skin: and as you let down the other from the other part, until you complete it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture which Gale has said.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is the way in which he has said it, that you must join each part according to its likeness, as certain physicians do with some things: and you must apply the heel to its like, and the edge to its like.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And that is done according to what I have told you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you insert the point at the heel close to the outer side, and make that penetrate inwards only in this place: and draw out both extremities of the suture.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then withdraw the point and make that penetrate from the outer side inwards through both extremities of the suture, that is to say on each side
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then withdraw both of them, and also make them penetrate both from the inside outwards through the other two edges which are on the opposite side
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this is the best way of stitching which is remembered.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is indeed the word of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	Some have said this.
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The gut suture is corrected with two squares.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, insert in both guts a single thread: and begin with the needle that is with thee, and make it pass through until it reaches the other side, following the suture that is between the two layers of skin
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	Know that when a disruption is in the middle of the gut: then the suture of that is more difficult than that of the rest of the gut.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgement of the violent wound is the judgement of the other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you follow a wound with its blood, before it changes itself by swelling: and you reduce the intestines, and hold them together: then you put over the powdered meat.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already changed the wound: then put over it some unguents, which are in your presence, until they make pus: and the thread will fall out, and the wound will be consolidated, and will heal.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for this as for the care of the other wounds, until it is healed
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if there are not present to thee medical men, then put over it immediately, from which it begins to emit pus, soft cotton: and change it twice a day, as I have taught thee, until it is healed
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For thou shalt not use any other medicine in many cases, when wounds are simple
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If however thou fear that the wound communicates with the principal members in the lesion: then thou must plunge wool wool of the finest kind into lukewarm oil, or into rose oil: and put it about the parts which are between the buttocks, and under the armpits
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or swelling, or putrefaction in his intestines (for this often happens to him), then he must anoint himself with a mixture of wine and black, warm unguents: especially if putrefaction has already penetrated the intestine, and an opening has been made through to its cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that that which is from the great intestine is easier to heal: and that which is from the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The small intestine, however, which is called Ieiunum, does not suffer healing from the wound which happens to it throughout: and this is because of the multitude of its veins, and the greatness of their numbers, and because of the subtility of its body, and for the proximity of its nature to the nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If, however, that which proceeds from the wound is a clot, and you follow it up, reduce it according to your reduction of the intestines which you equalise
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If indeed it has passed beyond that space, and is black or dark: then it is necessary to tie it up with a thread above the place which has been injured so that the flow of blood does not occur
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in a clot there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut through that which is beyond that ligament, and place two hanging threads from the lower part of the wound outside it: so as to support above its attraction, and extraction of it in the case of a clot, and the emission of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the wound which happens in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a disruption occurs in the Intestine, and it is small: then it is possible, in some individuals, that it will heal: because I have seen that which was wounded in the belly with a lance, and which was from the right side of the stomach, and which was old: and a fistula was formed, and it went out of it egestion, and swelling
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I hold fast this treatment until I am relieved from the patient's condition: neither will I cease until he is healed and his place is firmly restored.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	Once I have placed the treatment in its proper position, I fear no harm to the patient, for no harm has befallen him from this treatment.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	I remain in a better state of health, eating and drinking well, fasting and sweating, having bathed, and exercising regularly in my diet
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some experimenters have said that when a wound occurs in the intestines, and it is slight: then it is necessary to bind it in this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is like taking large ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then join together two lips of the wound, and place an ant on one of those which has an open jaw over the two lips of the wound
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When you have placed the head over them, and tied its jaw, cut off its head, and it will adhere to it, and will not be dissolved.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	And place another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing this until you have completed the wound to the amount of the entire wound
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	And then draw it down, and close the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	And those heads remain annexed in the intestines, until the intestine is healed, and is not harmful to the patient
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	It is also possible to bind the intestine even with a fine thread: which has been taken from the intestine of an animal, and is annexed to it when it is introduced into the belly
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And take the extremity of that thread from the intestine, and cut out a great deal of it.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then the ligament at its extremity is bound by a subtle thread of linen.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into the edge, and with it the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it to disruption.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And in this manner of stitching with hooks and intestine, it is not without reason that it should be done with trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You know that which is great, spacious, especially if it is in a graceful intestine: then it is not wit without subtlety, neither is its healing altogether
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	About the care of ulcers, and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You know that every ulcer, or swelling when it grows old and hardens, and becomes an ulcer, and does not consolidate, and emits pus always, and does not burst: then it is called universally in any part of the body a fistula, and we call it Zuchemen.</start_of_turn>
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is indeed according to truth a filtered nodulation, hard, white: with which there is no pain, which has the consistency of a bird's wing feather: and for this reason they call some of them Risati, that is, feathers.</start_of_turn
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And sometimes in certain hours it is moist, which emits pus.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps it bursts in some hours.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes when this moisture is much, and is little, and is great, and is fine.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I say beforehand in the explanation, that every ulcer which does not heal, neither is born in this body, is not that except for one new cause.</start_of_turn
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	When one is in want of life, either because of the scarcity of blood in the body: or because of its malice: or because between the two there is a hard substance covering the lips, hindering the birth of flesh: or because there is an abundance of pus and phlegm: or because there is a putrid ulcer in itself, and the matter that issues from it is of bad quality: or because the medicine is unsuitable for its treatment: or because corruption is falling in the region, being a kind of pestilence: or because of the property of the region itself, as it often happens in Caesarea, where digestion is difficult and healing is delayed after a wound by nature: or because there is only one bone, or a number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	I have also mentioned all these causes and signs, and the cures for them with the doctors in discussion. And it is proper here to tell you the cure for fistula and swelling, which is done by one operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You know therefore that fistula occurs in all the members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	There are indeed fistulas which arise from great veins and arteries, or nerves, or fat: or from the intestine, or the bladder, or some of the bones: or from some parts of the back, or from some of the joints.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Since these fistulas are of this kind, they are caused by difficult diseases that do not receive treatment, and are accompanied by hardship and ignorance.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If, however, any fistula does not reach such depths as those which I have mentioned, and if you hope for its recovery and trust its treatment, and wish to recover your health, then attempt to grasp the air or iron if the fistula lies according to its rule, and inquire about it with the thing itself.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, in the fistula there is tortuousity, then you must investigate the same with a weight that is subtle.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For the weight is gentle of its body, it will flow around the tortuousity.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If the fistula has many openings, it is not possible to do this with the weight alone
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore grasp from the inside out of its openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture which you grasp will go out through the other openings and run from the inside.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire diligently in what manner it is possible: that you may know whether there is bone or nerve, and whether the fistula is of long or short duration: or whether it is a fistula which has many openings and rests upon the whole of it, with the sum of your force: with your interrogation of the patient, and the finding of pain upon compression with your hand in the place, and similar signs and symptoms following
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have rested upon all these things, then proceed to the cure according to your confidence: and it is that you consider then, if the fistula is apparent in a nearby place, or in a remote place from the junction, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or one of the places which I have mentioned: then dry up the fistula according to what is said above from the narration, and remove what is in it from the filtration, and corrupt blood, which is born from the opening of it from the flesh, or pus, and similar things: and care for it until it is healed
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the fistula is of great depth and is according to right angles: then it is necessary that you cut through the depth as much as is possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then remove from it all the corrupt blood from it
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer the roundels of lead involved in acute medicine: and introduce them until they reach the depth of the fistula which you have grasped with the iron: do this as many times as necessary, until the acute medicine has eaten away everything that remains in the depth of the fistula from its corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore the cavity with unguents that generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If indeed it does not heal through this, then cauterize it according to what we have said
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If indeed the cause of the fistula is bone, and you have confirmed that for me: then inquire about it, and dry it up according to what I have told you: if it does not impede you anything from the bone, or nerve, or major limb, as we have said
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If indeed it is detected that there is bone in it, and there is some corruption and blackness: then burn it, until the corruption of that is completely removed
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which nourishes it, until it is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	Which if it does not heal, and pus is emitted as it did before: then you know that you have not achieved the entire eradication of the corruption
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Investigate further concerning this, and inquire diligently about the reason for it, and the purification of it with your utmost ability.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If indeed it heals, it is good: and if not, then you know that that corruption is in a profound depth of the body, which you have not been able to overcome
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not in your power to do anything in this matter, except to yield to the nature of things.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If indeed the small bone is corrupted, and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps which are suitable for that purpose
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then make a strong traction of them all, and do not let anything slip from your hand with your skill.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If, however, there is anything slippery from the humors, and there is no fear in the incision, or error: then incision them humors and flesh, if there are any, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If indeed you are not prepared to extract the bones from this hour, then place over it something which will putrefy it: and let it go, until it putrefies what is around the bones from flesh and humors
