Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the limb so that it does not swell
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And be careful of the section which you made in your operation.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And put over it, if you will, sulfur pounded with oil: or immerse it in Egyptian unguent, or in some other unguents of your choosing.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when these humors putrefy, and are separated from the bones, the wound will be soothed by the removal of the pain, and their traction
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If indeed there is a large bone, such as the femur or the tibia, and the like of these, which is corrupted: then take it out cautiously, until the black spot and the corruption are removed
Deinde restaura uulnus.	And then restore the limb.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If indeed what is corrupted in it is a large part, and the corruption has reached the marrow of the bone: then it is necessary to cut it through, and to open it up to the very place where the corruption is: then care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you, what happened to me in my leg: that you may take it as an example and an aid for your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age suffered pain in his leg, because something had moved above the middle of his body inwards, that is, from within, until it reached the leg, and there remained a great swelling: and there was no external cause for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	The swelling had persisted for a long time with an error of the physicians, until the swelling was opened, and many substances accompanied it.</start_of_turn>
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after the dressing was placed, until the leg was bandaged, many holes were made in it: which all discharged pus and moistened the body.</start_of_turn>
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	The multitude of physicians treated him for two years, and there was no knowledge in their art concerning this matter until I came, and I saw his leg and the matters which issued from those holes in great quantity: even all the men in the city were astonished, and his color became pale.</start_of_turn>
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	They tried to pierce one of the holes in one place, and the attempt reached the bone.</start_of_turn
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I inspected all the holes: and I found that they all led inwards from all parts of the leg.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I treated it accordingly, and I cauterized one of those holes, until I found a piece of bone: and I found that it was corrupted: for it was rotten, discoloured, putrefied, and perforated, until it had penetrated even to the marrow.</start_of_turn
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw that which had been detected by me, and prepared from the corrupt bone.</start_of_turn>
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I declared that there was no soundness in the bone except for that corruption, which I excised and cauterized.</start_of_turn>
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I extirpated it.</start_of_turn
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I order the restoration of the wound along with the physicians who are firm in their space for a long time.
Et non est consolidatum.	And they are not consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I will attempt, and I have found above the first detection: and I have found continuous corruption with the bone: and I have seen that even this corruption has appeared from that corruption.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempt restoration of it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it is not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I have found thus above it again, and I have not ceased to cut the bone piece by piece, and to attempt restoration: and it is not restored, until I have cut from the bone almost a palm's breadth, and I have extracted that with its marrow
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was quickly consolidated and healed: and there was no need for this repetition of the operation on it, and the section of it, except because of the weakness of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him, for it was dying in every hour from excessive evacuation of its syncope.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He is thus healed completely: and he was born in the place of the hard bone, and a good disposition was made in his body, and his strength returned to him: and he conversed with his fellows: and he did not make him lame in walking at all
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to support it, according to this method: that you take a ligament and bind it to the extremity of the prominent bone: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament of a greater size alongside the first ligament.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the ligament over the flesh, which is upon the bone: and extend its extremity, so that you pull the flesh downwards: and you will discover the flesh over the place where you wish to saw, so that it does not damage the flesh
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone in the center: for when you do this, it does not hinder that it will cut through rotten flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	It is necessary that the suture be placed above the corrupted part, so that there is no depression of the corruption: and that it does not appear to the sense, and that it compels the patient to make a new suture
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and does not protrude, continue the part of it with the part itself: and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in the part itself: then remove the flesh from all sides entirely
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood under it.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards suture that part first from which the corruption is, until the suture reaches the other part: and let the suture be as far from the corruption as possible, as we said before
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is at the junction, cut through the corrupted junction and suture the bone where the other part continues.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions, then there is no wisdom in it except for abrasion
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the palm of the foot: then matters are difficult there
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary to inquire what kind of corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And abrade the flesh, and cleanse it as much as possible according to any possibility, and with any ingenuity: when it does not make the vein or nerve worse
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You know that the saws and the sutures for cutting this bone are many, according to the position of the bones, and the preparation of them, and their length, and their thinness, and their size, and their hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherever necessary, it is appropriate to prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	You also know that these operations are significant in relation to the kind of instrument which is suitable for them, when you have studied for a long time.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the methods of treating diseases: for then you will find for each ailment that which instrument is suitable from among the instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am confirmed in the last chapter of this book concerning the number of instruments, which I have placed as examples of the instruments that you will experience, and the test which you will make on other things.
Forma Serrae.	The Shape of the Scalpel.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The Shape of the other Scalpel
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Shape of the other Scalpel again
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Shape of the other Scalpel once more
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the Scalpel is depicted with the middle part made off-center
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Its arc is on the upper part, the point of its sharpness on the iron: and its handle is of boxwood, and it is made pyramidally off-center
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The Shape of the Scalpel with a Joint.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	The head of this Scalpel is in the shape of the head of a star: and its points are in the shape of the points of a fishnet
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable except when it is grasped with the head of the javelin, when the head is broken, or when the bone is fractured, and it is large
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The Shape of the Greater Scalpel.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The Shape of the Middle Scalpel
Forma Rasorii lati.	The Shape of the Broad Scalpel
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of the wound in which there is concentration.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Shape of the wound is milder in this case.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Shape of the wound is more curved at the extremities in this case
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Shape of the wound is small and mild in nature
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Shape of the wound as when bones are fractured
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Shape of the wound is large in this case
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to the radio [radius of a circle], and the extremity is like a saw: it appears in many places because of the reason for the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Shape of the wound agrees with the cause of its perforation by bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its extremity is triangular, and the extremity is acute
Fit ex Indi.	It is like that of India
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And it should be as it has been said concerning wounds, incisions, and saws in general
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Regarding the incision of the extremities, and the closure of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy either from an external cause or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When you have treated the cause of the corruption with medical remedies, and the corruption does not cease: and if you do not cut away the corruption of the limb, without which recovery will not take place: then you must cut away that limb until the corruption has ceased, so that the sick person may recover from the limb rather than from the limb itself, or from the harmful affection which is greater than the defect of the limb
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this has happened is that the limb is blackened, until it is burnt: or it becomes putrid after blackness: until that putrescence has gone out of the limb until it has reached that which follows the limb, and has spread throughout the body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Properly therefore when the incision is made, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from a blow of some venomous creatures: such as the scorpion of the sea, and the viper, and the spider, and those of a like nature.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If there is corruption, or the blow is at the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption, so that it may reach right up to the other hand
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut off the hand from the root of the bone, and do not leave space for the corruption, until it is carried away in the bone of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it occurs in the forearm, then cut off the forearm at the elbow in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption has passed, and you see it round about the elbow: then that is the death of the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And as for the treatment of this, the quantity of the remedy is important.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And do the same with the foot, when corruption occurs in the finger, then cut off the finger at one of the joints: and if it reaches the heel, then cut off the whole foot
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	And if it reaches the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	And if the corruption has gone above the knee, then it is not in this that the limb is preserved, except for amputation, and leaving the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the manner of cutting off the limb, or preserving it, is that you bind the ligaments below, which you wish to cut: and bind the other ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one ligament downwards: and extend the other ligament upwards
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is torn away
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it occurs, or it returns.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	Then it occurs, or it returns. It is necessary that you place all the layers of the membrane around the gut, and do not touch the healthy tissue: and it comes to pass that the sick person's wound is added to, and the swelling is cold.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, blood flows inwards during the operation, then cauterize the place quickly: or put upon it some powder which absorbs blood.</start_of_turn>
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your medicine until it is completed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind up the wounded limb with a bandage suitable for it, and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I say to you that this is what happens in my foot, for this is what I say to you.</start_of_turn
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happens in your foot black, with the soot which is assimilated by the fire: and the corruption first happens in your finger, until it affects the whole foot.</start_of_turn
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Thus did this man recover from his ailment, after he had cut away the corruption which was in the limb with its pain: and he found that the pain had gone away, and the soot had disappeared.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And when some time had passed, the same corruption happened in his thumb.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to recover the uselessness with what I had learned from the physicians after the purification of his body: and the uselessness did not return, but it began to go away in another finger: until the corruption spread to the whole hand.</start_of_turn
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to cut off his hand: and I did not do it, hoping for the return of the uselessness: and I was also afraid of the death which would result from the cutting of his hand.</start_of_turn
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the patient was above the case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When he had recovered from me, he was brought back to the earth: and he came to me because he wished to, and he struck his hand entirely: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I do not approve of this narration, except as an aid to that which falls from the kind of this illness: and as a sign that signifies, and according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	About the care of bones, and the quality of blistering with doctors.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When swelling occurs in some limb with carbuncles, and the space of the swelling is prolonged until the collection of pus has taken place: then it is burst, or pierced, and the pus which is in it is ejected, and what remains is like a wound: and the skin which is over it is like a thin veil: and it does not reach the end of its corruption, neither does it affect the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it is called a sinus, and not a fistula, truly, until its space is prolonged, until corruption affects some part of the limb, then it is called a fistula, or swelling
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you cut away the entire skin as it returns: and especially when it is thin, and done like a veil: and trust that it does not adhere to the place, because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you hope that the skin will adhere, and this does not result in the last consequence of corruption: and if there is hardness in the skin from the flesh, then care for it with blistering: and consider it as a sinus
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus which comes out of it has a foul odor: then blister it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and alum, equal parts, which are gathered in a vessel: and they are boiled over a fire, until the medicine turns red: and then they are applied to the swelling
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from this what you need: dissolve it with water and honey, and instill it with oil into the sinus: and bind up its orifice, and send the medicine in it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then draw it out with pressure: do this every day until the sinus is healed, and the stench is gone.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is instilled with water of cinnabar, when it is not present with this medicine: then take cinnabar from the wood of the willow, or from the wood of the ilex: and sprinkle it over the water.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then remain quiet, and instill with it until you are confident that the sinus is softened.</start_of_turn
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine, neither the water of cinnabar, then instill it with water and honey, to which something of ground cinnamon has been added.</start_of_turn>
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or instill it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey to soften and loosen: and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in it.</start_of_turn
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has passed away: then instill it with something which makes the flesh grow in it.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from alum of diaphanicon: and dissolve it with rosewater and wine of astringency: or instill it with some medicine, and anoint with others, of whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents.</start_of_turn
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the orifice of the sinus is narrow, in which the catheter for instillation will not pass: then widen it with iron tongs: or put in it a piece of lint soaked in Egyptian unguent, or in castor oil, until it is widened.</start_of_turn
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	If the orifice is large, then join its lips together with sutures and discharge from it the quantity which entered without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	If the orifice discharges pus, it is elevated towards the higher parts: then dry that in the lower place which is in it, so that it flows downwards: for pus, when it is congealed in depth, prevents the generation of flesh in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible to dry the sinus below downwards, then attempt to prepare the limb with the preparation which facilitates the discharge of pus easily as it is prepared
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Attempt to retain nothing of the pus at all in it: and take solidifying medicines which are placed over the sign, suitable for this purpose
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the edge of the bandage.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the bandage be of such quantity that it makes communication of the entire sinus possible.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then with forceps grasp directly at the orifice of the sinus and widen the opening of the sinus slightly
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the soft tissues above the other bandage, according to the size of the opening: and place it above that in a distant position from the orifice of the sinus, so as to facilitate the discharge of the pus from it: and do not tighten the bandage too much, except after a few days when one has become accustomed to it
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	Whoever is above the orifice of the sinus should constantly move in every hour, so that what is aggregated in it from the pus may be discharged: and you will know whether it is much or little, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this consider again the place of the sinus itself, whether it feels any pain in it, or whether there is no pain in it, and whether there is swelling in it, or whether there is no swelling in it
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When, therefore, the remedy is extended like this towards the mother of the sinus, then you will know that the sinus is already adhering, or is approaching adherence: then you must solve it in the mane, or on the third day. And when you have solved it, then change the bandage and renew the unguentum.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	When, however, it [the sinus] comes out from the sinus after a long space of time with a subtle discharge, then do not despair of its adherence, for its healing approaches, because there are men who are late in the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are some who act contrariwise to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	When, however, it comes out from the sinus after many days with undigested pus, then you know that the sinus is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	When, therefore, the adherence of the sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then physicians must join in the care of the patient, for they make the medicine both moist in substance and dry in action: like alum, when it is added in excess.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last of these things which are done for its care, it is, that you take alum and dissolve it with rosewater, and apply it over the old wound equal in amount to its substance
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then join it with this, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the like of this, when there is no alum present, honey, when you dissolve it, until it has solidified, and you apply it with that.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloes, and balsam: mix them all together, and grind it over honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then apply it over the bandage, and bind it over the sinus: and apply with the honey which you have boiled until it has solidified: and sprinkle over it the powder of these things, and put it over the bandage and bind it again.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	When such a long aristolochia is administered, along with radix lilii coelestis, lilium, herba flour, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	When such long aristolochia is administered, along with radix lilii coelestis, lilium, herba flour, and centaurea, use either simple or compound preparations. Crush the mixture with honey as described previously and use it immediately.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the sinus persists and does not improve with treatment, you know that there is corruption in its depth: either an impression is made in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or in the ligaments. In such a case, treat the fistula according to what has been stated previously.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Concerning the treatment of panaritis and the retracted nail, and the addition of incision of the digit and section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 101.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a swelling that occurs under the nail of the thumb or toe, or perhaps in the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When such a condition persists and is neglected, and the swelling becomes painful, pus is emitted, and the root of the nail is corroded: and perhaps the whole nail is broken, and perhaps the corruption extends to the bone, which gives off a foul odor: and the digit becomes swollen, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you have treated it as we have said, and the condition does not improve: then it is necessary to cut away the whole remaining part of the nail with a knife
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Cauterization is better with cold.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound and the nail is also sound, and the addition of the nail has caused the flesh to swell inwards and to bleed: then you must place a fine radium under the nail at the angle where it is biting the flesh, and press the nail upwards: and cut away the flesh easily with the knife, and place over it what remains of the flesh which has been burned by the doctors, corrosive, until it has disappeared completely
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, corruption has already set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away the bone and extract it: for it will not heal while it remains in that corrupted state.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If an ulcer or corruption approaches the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, as has been previously mentioned
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, attrition or percussion should occur to the nail, and there is pain in that area, then it is necessary to bleed the diseased part at first
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the wound with a sharp spatula from above downwards to the end.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful, lest the incision should reach the flesh under the nail, for you will thereby cause additional pain and a risk of gangrene in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which rests the pain
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger which has been added which was born in the hands of men, perhaps is entirely fleshy: perhaps also in some of its bones, and perhaps in that is its nail: and some of them are born in the root of the joint, or is the origin of its nature in some joint of the finger
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some joint of the finger does not move: and he who is born beside the joint of the finger, perhaps moves
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is fleshy from bone, his cutting is easy
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, as you would cut it at the root with a broad spatula
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	As for him whose origin is in the root of the joint, the care of him is difficult
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Caput XCII.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then string the thread of the patient from the upper part of his thigh to the lower part of his knee with oil.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry one, or two, or three sections wide at the place where it is needed
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then lift up, that is, draw out the blood in your hand from the lower part of the leg up to the upper part, and from the upper part pour it down as phlebotomies for the patient at first
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the wound until blood stops flowing: until the quantity of blood which you have drawn out is equal to the amount which is sufficient for the patient, and as much as the patient can tolerate of the pain.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie up the wound: and command him to abstain from foods which generate black bile: and repeat the emptying and phlebotomy when the veins are full, and this will be good for the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of the limb is done in this way.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	The thigh of the patient, if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then insert the limb into a bath: or embroider it in his leg with warm water, until it turns red, and makes the veins swell: or perform an exercise forcefully, if there is no bath for him, until the limb is warmed up
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin along the line of the vein section: or at the end of it at the knee, or at the lower part of it at the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with needles, and remove the vein from all sides, until it appears sensible: and it is at the appearance of it that you know that the blood has returned to its normal colour
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it has gone out of the skin, the blood is like white thread
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce from beneath the edge of the Radium, until it rises up and departs from the skin: suspend it with one finger, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry out the surrounding area near that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape away the skin from the upper part of the nail, until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise up the skin with the Radium as you did before, and suspend it with another finger, as you did at the beginning
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry out the surrounding area, or the surrounding areas, if necessary
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then raise up, and cut through the last section at the heel
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull out the skin up to the section that is above it
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have pulled out the skin from the higher section, or from all the sections, until they have all come away: then cut through the skin
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not yield to pulling and raising: then introduce a sharp needle with a strong thread, and bind the skin, and pull it out: or introduce from beneath the edge of the Radium: and move your hand over the whole thing, until it comes away
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Take care not to tear it
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it tears, it will be difficult for you to raise up the skin afterwards, and it will enter through the wound to the bone.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have pulled out the skin completely: then place over the wound a lanolin pad soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for it until it heals
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist which involves parts, and is not as we have described according to the rule: then you must find over the skin all the parts of the twist of that twist.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the part with the hooks until the entire limb has been raised up: and take care at the section above the part that you do not cut through the vein or wound it: for it is difficult to raise or extract the part above.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of the wound that heals life itself.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of the wounded limb becomes blind
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It has no curvature like the rest of the limbs, neither is it acute at the extremities, so as not to wound the vein: and it is thick and flexible: because if it were slight, it would cut through the vein by its softness: indeed it has such excessive thickness that it is like we have said.</start_of_turn>
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.</start_of_turn>
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.</start_of_turn
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in warm lands, like Alizegi and Arabia, and in dry and warm lands, with little humidity, that is, in which no herb or tree grows.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is also generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.</start_of_turn
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from the decomposition that occurs under the skin, like that which occurs within the bodies of serpents and worms, and the worms that are generated between the skin and the flesh.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the commencement of this vein is that which occurs in the thigh inflammation and swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is to be dried.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein is to be extracted from that place of drying, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When the swelling appears from that extremity, then it is necessary to immerse the finger over the leaden weight, which weighs from a drachma to two drachmas and a nodus: and let go of the suspended lead.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	When anything proceeds from that to the exterior, immerse it in lead and bind it there.</start_of_turn>
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it persists for a long time, then cut off a part of it, and immerse the rest.</start_of_turn>
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	Do not cut through the root before all of it has come out.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through it, it contracts, and enters the flesh: and causes the swelling to become more acute, and gangrene in the place, and a bad ulcer.</start_of_turn
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary to handle it gently, and extract it slowly, until all of it has come out of the body: and from this vein proceeds in some men as far as the tip of the thumb and the little finger.</start_of_turn>
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And I have seen it happen to me that it has come out whole from the hand of a man who had been bitten for twenty palm-widths.</start_of_turn
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If however it happens to you in the hour of your treatment: then introduce radium into the cavity of its wound, and perforate the wound with a long needle, as with the body, until all that is in it from the matter be evacuated: and administer antiphlogistic treatment to the place with physicians for a few days.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the aftercare of the wound.</start_of_turn
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein often has many branches, especially when it appears in the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and there are many holes in it, and it proceeds from every hole a branch.</start_of_turn
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there.
Caput XCIIII.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	Care for her accordingly, as we have said previously, and when that which has been promised is there
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If indeed the aid has reached him already in the head near the eye, then tighten under it over the eyebrow a good fold.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the patient should be treated with attention to the restoration of his body, with physicians extracting harmful humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that cause putrefaction of the body.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	And concerning the section above the eyebrow Nakir
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCVI.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This pain is called in our land Nakir: and it is a pain which occurs in some limb: then it is transferred from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have seen it happen, as I have told you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some village
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm swollen, and I saw an inflation of pus in the groin of the arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw that there was another inflation going up like a worm, ascending up to his shoulder more quickly than is possible: like silver when it runs from one place to another
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore departed from that place and settled in the shoulder
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	And after an hour it went round the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	And she told me that it had passed through her whole body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I am amazed at the speed of its passage from limb to limb
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed I have never seen such an ailment of the eye like this, in the way that it is described above
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	Many people suffer from pain that changes from limb to limb: and not from the eyes, as with a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe that this is the case, except perhaps in those instances where women have been afflicted by the swellings of the lower parts of the body: from which it follows that the pain is transferred from one limb to another
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, and in whom the swellings are hidden
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore he has received his cure, and the patient feels this pain: then, if it appears to him through the eye, as we have said, then bind above and below in the same place: and dry above the same, until the swelling is discharged: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not see it with your eyes: then cure him with the evacuation of the body, and with that which drives out the swellings, and carmine them with poultices of rue, and with saffron pills, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The text continues with a section titled "On the Extraction of Arrows.")
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.</start_of_turn>
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are varied according to their kind and the places from which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	There are various kinds of arrows: because some have large cusps and others have small: and some are concave and others are convex
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And those that have tongues
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And those that have stars
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those that are according to the limbs from which they fall are in two ways
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	All limbs are either principal limbs with concavities, such as the brain, heart, liver, lungs, kidneys, intestines, spleen, and similar structures.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When any limb has fallen into any of these positions and their signs of death appear, as I shall afterwards narrate, it is necessary to remove that arrow from there, for death follows its trajectory in various positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these signs of distress do not appear, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When the arrow has fallen into the brain and has pierced the bone, and has emerged above the brain, these are the signs: because of its impact, there are swelling, bruises, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, and mixture of the senses, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And possibly blood will be expelled from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And possibly speech will be lost, and the voice will be destroyed
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there will be discharge from the wound of a white moisture resembling pus
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there will be discharge from it like the moisture of meat
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs appear, abstain from treatment and remove the arrow if it does not emerge naturally
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that has fallen into the heart are: that it is close to the left breast: and that it feels as though it is fixed in something hard, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And possibly the arrow will move like the beating of a pulse: and blood will flow from the wound black
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following that, there is cold at the extremity, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know therefore that death approaches uncertainly.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	When the arrow wounds the lung, the sign is the bloody foam that comes out of the wound: and the swelling that follows the neck, is raised and changes the colour of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the great and high spirit departs: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the chest, that is near the ribs: then there is a great pain in the back with deep breathing: and a movement of all the arms and shoulders
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	If the arrow falls into the stomach, perhaps it comes out of the wound with some undigested food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	If the arrow falls into the belly, and it lies there: something of stool or bile or intestine which has been broken comes out of the wound
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in its cure, neither in the extraction of the arrow
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is greater over the patient: then you know that it is deadly
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	As for the rest of the members, such as the face, and the neck, and the chest, and the gut, and the hand, and the foot, and the back, and the buttocks, and the hip, and the thigh, and the like of these members, when it does not find the arrow in the artery or the nerve: and there is no venomous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	I tell you that I have seen many such arrows, so that you may know that there is no hope for your cure.</start_of_turn>
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	What is this, because the arrow of care has struck the pupil of his eye in the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extracted it from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no document remained in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from him which had struck him in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was hidden, and I did not find the tip of it in the wood: and it was a great arrow like those of the Turkish archers, with a lead weight, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed therefore, and no evil happened to him in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the Christian's belly.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabian arrow, which is the one with ears
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	And thus I found it between two ribs: and it was submerged in his belly
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I handled it cautiously with them until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from the belly which had struck him in the flank: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	When thirty days had passed from that, and no change had occurred in his condition in regard to the arrow, we considered that the arrow had ceased to exist: so we extracted it from him: and he was healed, and no evil happened to him
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And behold the man to whom the arrow had struck in his back, and the swelling had subsided from him over the arrow.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	And after seven years he recovered from the arrow which was in the root of his thigh
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And the woman whose arrow had gone into her side had the wound consolidated with a woul [bandage] above it, and the arrow remained inside her: and no alteration was made to its position from its natural disposition, and the woman did not discover any document in relation to any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And the man whose arrow had gone into his face had the wound consolidated with a bandage, and it remained, without causing him much pain: and similar things happened in many cases.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from the King's servant, which had gone into the middle of his nose, and it had bent towards the right side below: and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to care for him after the arrow wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the arrow wound firmly bound tightly
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I questioned him carefully with a gentle touch, and he did not feel any pain: and he himself discovered the puncture and the pain from his right side
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that this was the cause of the puncture by the tip of the arrow
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I plastered the place with a firm plaster in which the painful swelling had arisen, confident that the wound would heal, and that the sign of the arrow would disappear: and it did not happen in a place where the arrow had followed its course
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I remained with the plaster for many days: and no accident happened, and the wound consolidated in the meantime: and he felt the arrow on the day that the arrow was extracted from his nose
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I put on him a sharp and corrosive medicine for several days, until it opened: and when I grasped it, I felt the tip of the arrow adhering to the wood
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then did I add in the opening of the wound for the acute physician, until it appeared to us with certainty the extremity of the arrow: and I passed over with it the space of time for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	When the wound had been enlarged, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into it, and to move it, and it did not obey my orders to come out: then I did not cease to work subtily, and devised means above the ordinary, until I had finished on the following day with forceps which I had made with my own hands, according as the form of the matter would permit, until I had extracted it from the body.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore, and the wound was consolidated, and the patient was healed completely: nothing further was known of it.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of the arrows: so that you may know the rule and the significance of it, that which I have not mentioned
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended by narration: neither does this book comprehend them, nor does a prudent artificer compare them with little to much: and with that which is present, he overlooks that which is absent: and he finds a new operation and an new instrument among the descent of things of this art when they arise
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed, except according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Either by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by means of the other part being reversed
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or that is an arrow proceeding in the fleshy part: it is attracted and comes out
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not yield to the outlet within the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you discharge it for a few days, until the flesh that surrounds it has putrefied: and the attraction of it will be alleviated, and its egressio.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And in like manner, if it is found in bone, and does not yield to you at the outlet, then discharge it also for a few days: and do it again every day with attraction and motion, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not yield to you at the outlet after days, then you must perforate the entire circumference of the arrow in the bone with a fine thread, until the arrow is enlarged
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out, and extract it.
