Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If, however, the arrow is fixed in the head of the bone, and has already progressed into one of the cavities of the brain, and some of its accidents appear externally: then abstain from the attraction of the arrow, and discharge it, until it is equal to it again after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow persists at the fracture, the death is not prolonged for it.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except in the body of the bone only, and does not penetrate to the fracture: and remains sick for a few days, and nothing of those accidents happens to it: then proceed to the attraction of the arrow and its extraction
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is fixed firmly, and does not yield to you at the attraction: then administer oil in the circumference of the arrow, as I have said before: then care for the place, until it heals
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow has already vanished from its place in the body, and is hidden and concealed from sense: then inquire about it with care.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel pain, then draw out the pain with some instrument which is suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If it is impossible to remove the pain above, because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow in depth: and there is no bone, no nerve, nor vessel there: then find above the pain until the wound has become larger, and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are any ligaments which hold the flesh fixed in the wound, then release the flesh fixed in the ears from all sides, with all skill which you can, and with ingenuity, if it is not possible to remove the flesh from the fracture of the ears, and to twist the ears, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you perform the extraction of the arrow in whatever place it is, then use the twisting of your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you make the wound evacuate: and lower the last fragment, so that the arrow does not break, and that its extraction be difficult, and itself.</start_of_turn
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If it is not possible to remove the pain within an hour, then leave the pain for a few days, until the things which are around it have decayed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the pain: for it will make the flow of blood worse. Then perform what we have said in the chapter about the care of wounds: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or chord.</start_of_turn>
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And perform wisdom in every way that you can in order to facilitate the extraction of the arrow: and be quick, peaceful, or slow, and firm, as I have said.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do the same when you draw out the arrow, so that the sick person is in accordance with the figure, as it was with the arrow itself in the case of the arrow.</start_of_turn
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	How great is the benefit.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible to do this, then do what you can according to the figures available.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which goes out from the opposite side, or which proceeds from that to the outside: or it makes a bulge of the extremity of the arrow at the sense of the superior part of the skin close to it, and it lets go what is above: dry it therefore above, and make a section according to the quantity that they grasp in that pair of forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the gut: for itself it becomes easy to go out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until you press the arrow into the bone, and expand it for itself: then draw it out
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then do it again, until it comes out on its own.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow is in the limb, then push it out with that itself
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If indeed the limb is fractured, and you wish to administer a push: then introduce into the gut an instrument which is concave, so that the concavity of the instrument is against the concavity of the limb: then push out the gut with that itself.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then push out the gut with an instrument that is entering into itself.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be released by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisonous, then it is necessary to remove all the flesh in which the poison is, if possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for the gut as it befits
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling in the chest, or in the belly, or in the belly-button, or on the side: and that which you touch with your finger is close to it, and it is possible to cut above the gut: then cut above, and burn from the navel, or nerve, and draw out the gut
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then, if the wound is deep, take care of it and keep it clean until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the form of forceps by which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The extremities are like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not slip from it
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	There are many kinds of forceps, great, small, medium, according to the quantity of the arrow, the thinness or thickness of the wound, and the constriction of the wound itself
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of the hooked implement
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	The shape of the blunt implement
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremity like a radius, so that its entrance into the hooked arrow is alleviated, and it is driven by it
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This extremity of the forceps is hooked like the beak of a bird: so that the entrance of the arrow into itself and the driving force are alleviated
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On Phlebotomy of Veins
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 125
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins which are to be phlebotomized, which abound in the body, are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these there are six in the head: two pulsating veins which are behind the ears, called the Herbae: and two arteries which appear in two temporal regions: and two veins which are in the two tear-ducts of the two eyes, called the Aspicientes: and the vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and the vein which is at the extremity of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi which are in the neck
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	For the veins which are bled from the arms, there are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and it is from the side of the shoulder: and it names the common vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Media vein, and it is composed of the branches of the Basilica and the Cephalica: and it names the common vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called the Titillicaris
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it names the common vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Funis brachii, and it is placed over the elbow: and it is that from which the blood is drawn, and that which appears above the thumb in a clear mark
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is the vein which is between the wrist and the little finger: and there are two branches to it
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the side of the shoulder
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its place is beside the calcaneum from the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the knee: and its place is beside the calcaneus from the side of the heel.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg are three knees similar to these
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Concerning the cutting of the two veins behind the knee
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The cutting of these two veins which are behind the knee is useful for ancient cataracts, and for migraine, and for safra, and for a bad head wound.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the cutting of the vein is according to what is narrated
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is like removing the head of the patient: and you break the scalp of him in the place of the two veins with rough cloth in good friction
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	And then bind up the patient's neck with a bandage until two veins appear
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their place is behind the knee in two low places of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek therefore easily with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there is the sign with the scar.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	And then make the cutting of the vein with a knife, and that is called Incidens
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	And then insert it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	And then lift up your hand with the vein and skin towards the upper parts, and cut the vein with the incision in its place
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And the length of the incision should be as long as two joined fingers, or thereabouts: and let blood flow out as much as you want
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	And then bind up the patient with sponges, and let go of the patient, until he is healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And in the beginning of the book, the incision of the ears and their cauterization are mentioned.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	And concerning the incision of two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	And indeed two arteries which are in the two temples are to be opened (phlebotomized) for an old headache: and for a severe edema, and for excessive discharge of sharp points to the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the incision is easy as you shall learn from what I shall tell you
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Let the patient grasp his neck very tightly, until two veins become perceptible to the touch: and it is shown that their pulse is under your finger
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then indeed with the cautery.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	And raise the skin above the vein with your index finger, and make the incision beneath it, and raise the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut the vein, just as you did in the two veins before: and let the blood run out according to the quantity you need
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then close the patient's incision, and place your finger over the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	And afterwards put on a bandage over the wound and the nails, and tie it tightly: and leave it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And thus the recollection of the ears, and their incision, and their extraction is mentioned at the beginning of the book
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	And concerning the incision of the vein of the front after the incision of the Cephalic vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	And indeed the incision of the vein of the front after the incision of the Cephalic vein is useful for ancient headaches: and for the hemigraines, and for redness: and for wounds and ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And what is the quality of his phlebotomy, according to what I have told you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient should raise his arm until the vein becomes prominent.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then grasp the instrument which is called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	What is its shape?
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the sharp point of the Fossorium on the vein at the top, and pierce through it with the handle, or in some other way: and let the blood flow out in the quantity that you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close the perforation of the patient, and bind it up, until it is healed
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with a wide phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	It is not proper, however, that the phlebotomist should be of acute temperament, like the rest of the phlebotomists, but rather of a calm and tranquil temperament
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	The phlebotomy must be performed cautiously: because the bone is close by; and perhaps in this place the phlebotomist will break the bone if it is too thin.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the phlebotomy of the veins in the two lacrimal bones.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The purpose of the phlebotomy of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal bones of both eyes, is for the eye from scabies and redness: and for the swelling in the eye, and the itching of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that they should raise the patient's arm until the vein becomes prominent
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you will be standing over his head
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And perform the phlebotomy cautiously at a moderate length, with a small phlebotomist, wide and not deep, for in this place there is no bone
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the vein is slight at the extremity, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let him run from the blood as much as is necessary for him.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put over it an easy cushion, and bind up the limb at night once, and make it whole.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the phlebotomy of veins of the nose
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose, however, are phlebotomized for acute fever, and for excessive sweating, and for facial ailments, such as a migraine, and redness which occurs in the face: especially when it is old
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of its phlebotomy is that it tightens the diseased limb
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take hold of his left nose with your left hand, and make a slight incision, long: and hold it in the middle of the nose itself, between which is the part which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary, that you should take away your last hand with the phlebotomy: and make run from the blood according to your need
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind up the limb at night once.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The limb itself will restore itself soon
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the phlebotomy of veins of the groin
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Indeed, however, Guidegi phlebotomy is useful for constriction of the cough, and for the inception of leprosy, and for melancholy ailments, and for the itching and ulcer of the groin, and for swellings, that is, herpes of the belly
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that it tightens the diseased limb under both cheeks with a ligature: and let the artificer stand over the head of the patient, and let the patient sit on his seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the puncture of the vein is one to the length of the wide phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw from the blood the quantity which is appropriate, or according to that which is required for the case at hand
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other vein
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then close the ligament and bind the two veins with a middle knot: so that the patient is not injured
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And dismiss the patient until the next day
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The patient will be cured.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the phlebotomy of veins according to Algeberich
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Algeberich are phlebotomized because they cause swelling in the mouth, corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers, and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, even those which are in the nose, and in the vicinity of it
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that you make the patient sit before you: and bind his neck with a belt
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then pull down his lip, and look at two veins: one of which is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side of it: and the sign of both is by their blackness.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because around them are small veins, black ones
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Incise therefore each of them at the juncture of the incision
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt to you, and you do not know which of them they are: then you must make an incision of the greater of them, and of themselves make their mark
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do the same with the two veins which are in the upper lip: and most frequently runs with it: and incisions two veins which are in the lower lip
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Of phlebotomy of the vein under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	Of phlebotomy of the veins which are under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy: for it is necessary for the evacuation of the cephalic phlebotomy towards the gut, the tongue, and the mouth diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And as for the quality of the phlebotomy, let the patient sit between your hands facing the sun: and elevate the tongue and see under the tongue from one side a vein and from the other side a vein: and the colour of both of them tends towards black.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	The phlebotomy must be done on both of them: and the doctor must not put his last hand to the phlebotomy
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps blood will flow from them.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the cubit
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	For in these three veins which are phlebotomized in the cubit, phlebotomy is customary in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their phlebotomy is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Or by cutting with a curved knife: or by cautery with oil: or by drying with a knife, and this is Alnesil
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is, because it agrees with the section
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from these there are wide and narrow kinds according to the breadth of the veins and the tension of them. The form of phlebotomy with the knife is wide, like water
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it agrees with opening wide veins, full, bursting, apparent, large, and those which contain thick blood, turbid
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomus is of smaller width and finer extremity.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is suitable for the phlebotomy of thin veins which contain thin yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	Concerning the phlebotomy of Albucasis.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	Basilicae, however, which is one of these three veins of phlebotomy, is an instrument of great value
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the humors which are below the throat and the collar, from that which follows the breast, and the belly: and it is suitable for the phlebotomist because it causes no pain, and is above the vein.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, it err, and the puncture of the phlebotomy adds to it, it will reach the artery, and there will be a flow of blood
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary not to perform phlebotomy with the phlebotomus which is already punctured: rather let it be dry as with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If indeed it does not appear by a clear sign, then it is necessary to seek it out; and change to another one, or ask for another branch of it: or perform the phlebotomy in another place, such as the elbow
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is itself evident, and is dry with the phlebotomus of Alnesil, as we said before
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to make a phlebotomy of it itself, then it is necessary before the tension of the arm, so that you may reach the place, until you know the place of the pulse
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then take a sign over the place with the nail, afterwards the arm, and dry the vein with a concave section of the phlebotomus, as we said before.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	Take care that the percussion does not fall outside the space of the artery
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	When you draw the string of the ligature and inflation occurs in the place which you marked with the scar, then that inflation is an inflation of an artery: it is therefore necessary.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	When you draw blood at the phlebotomy and it flows like the urine of a child, and it is pale red: then you know that it is from an artery
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Therefore you must take care, and place your finger on the space that is longer, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If blood is shed (for it is shed in abundance), then tighten the arm and let go of it: and let the patient be still, for fear of movement: and be over his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Do not move him for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If however blood is not shed, and you perceive that it is not there at the present time: and that there is no physician present at your moment, then cut the artery if you see it.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities recoil, and blood is shed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of the skin of the buttock, and find the vein: take half of it, and tighten it over the place where the swelling is decreasing, with the ligature and the strings until tomorrow.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is shed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of him as the one from whom the recollection of the bleeding of the wound is remembered: and the cutting of blood in him is not difficult in many positions, because of the smallness of the wound, and the possibility of tying the artery from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the vein of the buttock.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The vein of the buttock is suitable for phlebotomy, because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because it is composed of the branch of the basilica, and the branch of the cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the phlebotomist to be above fear of his phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If, therefore, he adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy and finds a nerve, there occurs in it a stupor, and his healing becomes difficult, and perhaps does not heal at all
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears to be connected with sensation many times
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people, and is slight, and is not seen: then you must know that you must perform the phlebotomy as you would perform the ligation of Alnesil, and divide the nerve with your skill.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	And if there is one between two nerves, then find the one in length
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the nerve of the head
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	Phlebotomies, however, of the cephalic nerve are dangerous, because they draw blood from the head, and confer to the eyes ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper in this nerve to make the puncture with the needle only, or with the hook of the myrtus: because it is safer for all the nerves, because there is neither an artery nor a nerve under it
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	It is indeed fitting for you to seek out a gentler location with regard to the phlebotomy, and inquire about a place where there is less danger: and it will not harm you, if you do not find it at the first percussion, as you will return over it with the phlebotomy several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps indeed it will happen in some people when it is not punctured at the first time, but it does not harm them that.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	Of the usefulness of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be taken in its performance.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy and its accidents require your attention.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	The quality of phlebotomy and its accidents require your attention.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And as for the vein in the cubit, there are three that are useful for phlebotomy, namely the cephalic, the cubital, and the basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And as for phlebotomy at the beginning of spring after fasting, in the summer, and in the autumn and winter after a meal, when there are signs of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	It should be done on the first or third hour after the three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy for ailments does not have a fixed time: but when it is necessary and convenient, day or night, at any hour and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not permitted to perform phlebotomy on children until they are at least fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should it be performed on a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh month
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor on the elderly who have passed their sixtieth year
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wants to be bled for any reason: it is necessary to clear the intestines beforehand with a laxative, if there is much stool retained in the intestines: so as not to bring about the contamination of the principal parts by the putrefying matter of the intestines.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither should it be performed on a patient who is suffering from acute pain, or who is nauseous or vomiting from drunkenness until these symptoms have subsided from the body
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Neither the sick nor the infirm are immune to hydropathy
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then the phlebotomist is laid down.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If, therefore, a vein opens from the vein once, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it with another vein under that place slightly, or over it with some restriction: if the place does not recover
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	Which if it recovers, or if the patient becomes faint, then let him go today, or tomorrow: and do not tighten the ligament.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps he will then draw out the clot gently.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Do not put in the poultice.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood runs too slowly: and take care that blood does not escape from the vein more than is necessary: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the rule, and add a little more to the operation
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	Do it with restriction, before the place recovers: for in many people the place recovers during the operation itself.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If you see that the clot has already gone, then do not repeat over it at all, for it excuses you from that thing
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put over it something of the residue of oil: because it will soothe the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than pure oil, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And in the same way administer the residue of oil in all your phlebotomies, which you do in prohibition of the course of the blood: and make them become tyriaca alfarach and sage, when you put one of them over the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood becomes thin and resolves when it is gross
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If the large abscess occurs at the site of the phlebotomy, it frequently happens, especially to those who are not phlebotomists except in the case of a small opening of the vein, then cleanse the area and place above it a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed up: and bind for an hour: because it will dissolve.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	It is also necessary to do this after the blood has been drawn from the vein itself, with the addition of its complement, or from another vein.</start_of_turn>
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or purulent remains in the place after a few days, it does not harm: and if it does, place above it something of aloe, or myrrh of solutes: or something of the juice of mint, that is, camomile or something similar.</start_of_turn>
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And frequently indeed abscesses and swellings occur at the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Place your hand over it [the abscess], then if you feel softness under your compression of it, then that swelling is bad.</start_of_turn
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Because of this, put upon it something of what we have mentioned.</start_of_turn>
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps it will flow from the artery.</start_of_turn>
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster of it with something that has styptic power, that it may stop the bleeding.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw from every man from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue.</start_of_turn
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the color of the wine on the blood.</start_of_turn
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then send it away until it becomes red: and in the same way if you see it thick: then send it away until it is thinned: and in the same way if it is acute: until its sharpness is gone.</start_of_turn
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	He who is full, strong, and requires extraction of blood should do so with one, so that the phlebotomy may be extensive: and on him who is bilious should be done contrariwise to him.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	He should withdraw it in veins and make the puncture narrow: and it is better that the puncture be transverse than pointed in phlebotomy
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	This method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood and from the nerves: and is more laudable and safer than phlebotomy through its width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And for those who are accustomed to faint during phlebotomy, it is necessary that before phlebotomy he be given a spoonful of pounded bread soaked in pomegranate juice: or barley, if he is feverish: and let him draw from him from the blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is pale, then before phlebotomy he should be given bread soaked in honey syrup or in scented honey syrup with spices, or in scented scented syrup
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncope should happen during phlebotomy, and the cause of it is excessive bleeding: then it is necessary to give in the pot water of meat and fragrant syrup beneath the tongue: and to mix it with caraway and sweet galega and to touch his chest with these: and to do the rest which we said in the chapter on syncope from emesis
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to bring about evacuation of his arm, and to resolve his blood slowly: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is because of excessive evacuation, and whose temperament is bilious, that he should gradually resolve blood by the amount of his temperament in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to bring about evacuation of his arm, and to resolve his blood slowly, and his body is strong: then let him do this after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from the body towards the opposite side of that from which it hangs down must do so on the second or third day
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that it allows the diseased hand to be introduced into warm water until the swelling subsides and the joint becomes visible once more.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound over itself with a bandage of moderate constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then the phlebotomy should be performed in a transverse direction gradually, not too deeply or too superficially: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be as high as that which is above the wrist joint
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the blood is prohibited from flowing out, then put the hand once more into the warm water, and allow the blood to flow in the water until you have achieved your purpose
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the summer days, then you are excused from the repetition of the hand in the warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And most of all, the flow of blood in the warm water is to be set in the cold days.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the phlebotomy of this joint is safer than all the others, because there is no pulsating vein nor nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	The phlebotomy of the right hand of Salvius is equal to the treatment of the diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that you bind the hand with the bandage or your own hand after you have introduced the hand into the warm water until the swelling subsides and the joint becomes visible once more, and the patient should be asked to feel whether the pain has disappeared
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomy should be performed transversely.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein completely, it will not cause any harm to him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And take care not to cut the hand too close to the phlebotomy
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under the edge of the nail are nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then again, wet the hand in warm water, and stop the blood flow in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not wet it in warm water, the blood solidifies in the opening of the nail, and is hindered from running.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have drawn out the quantity of blood necessary, then put oil and salt on the nail: so that it does not solidify too quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way it is necessary to do with every fractured limb.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The bandage of a left-handed person is: because it is equal to the spleen in respect of ailments: and in like manner do it in the phlebotomy of a right-handed person, as you did in the second [instance] equally
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	As for the phlebotomy of the saphenae, the bandage is for ailments which are in the lower part of the body, such as ailments of the uterus, retention of menses, and kidney disease, and the ulcers of the groin and the ancient ulcers of the knee, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is that it lets the sick limb go into the warm water: and makes above it friction, until the nails break: and binds above the junction of the limb with a bandage.</start_of_turn>
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the nails are at the heel, appearing beyond the thumb: and they are pulled out from it in the front of the foot near the bones of many bones.</start_of_turn>
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore better in a wider limb, or at the heel in its mass: because it is better and safer.</start_of_turn
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If you do the phlebotomy on the front of the foot, then take care of the nerves that are under the nails on the face of the foot.</start_of_turn
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And establish your vein that you are cutting across as if you were making an incision: and let the phlebotomist be Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If blood flow is forbidden, then repeat the foot in warm water: and let the blood flow in the body until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the phlebotomist has erred in the first attempt, then repeat with phlebotomy to the upper parts, for the place is safe, and not because of any danger, when you fall from nerves, as we have said
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the other foot like the saphenous vein.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	As for the sciatic vein, its place is at the heel from the side of the cubitus.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the remedy for the pain of the ankle when it is because of cold blood is to perform phlebotomy.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is that it should include a diseased bag, and hurry: and bind the leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel four fingers, with a fine strip: it should not be visible except for that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then the phlebotomy should be carried out according to whatever method is most suitable to you, or according to the cut: and it is better to make an incision or to cut through the skin
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its place is safer, and in many men it is hidden under the hair
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and do not appear to anyone: then perform phlebotomy on one of its branches, for it is that which appears in the back of the foot, and is under the heel: and cause the blood to flow from it as much as you desire
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then solve the stricture, and place above the site of the phlebotomy the skin, and tighten the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	The stricture is to be solved, and the skin is to be placed above the site of the phlebotomy, and the place is to be tightened.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Regarding the treatment of the wound, and the quality of the dressing.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.</start_of_turn>
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Wounds are caused by bones, and by air, and by dirt.</start_of_turn>
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	The treatment of the wound is done in two ways.</start_of_turn
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	By scarification and extraction of blood: and the other is treatment without scarification.</start_of_turn
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this treatment which is without scarification is done in two ways.</start_of_turn
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or with heat.</start_of_turn
Aut est absque igne.	Or without heat.</start_of_turn
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the wounds which are treated with scarification and extraction of blood are in fourteen places of the body.</start_of_turn
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	These are the wounds which are treated with scarification and extraction of blood: Alnocrati is the most posterior wound of the head: Alkehel is the middle wound of the neck: and the wounds of Alhagdahim are two layers of the neck from two parts together: the wound of menti is under the jaw in the lower part of the mouth: the wound of two spatulas: the wound of Alachosos is over the end of the tail: and the wounds of two focilia are in the middle of the two arms: and the wounds of two crura: and the wounds of two caudae.</start_of_turn
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And the treatment does not draw out blood from small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of this does not cause the emergence of pus like that which happens in phlebotomy.</start_of_turn
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to administer the cautery with fire, nor without fire in any ailment that arises from excessive swelling, until the entire body be evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	Whenever the need arises on account of an ailment, or by custom, we administer it at the beginning, at the end, and in the middle of the month, and at any other time as required.</start_of_turn>
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For in man, when his blood multiplies excessively in him, until it requires extraction by cautery, it generates in his head a grievous swelling, and pain.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from this is that it appears in his face, head, and neck swelling, redness, and distension.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from this it appears on his face itching, and a rash, and shadows, and dimness in his eyes.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from this it is that the place of the cautery is scraped.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from this it is that his laughter multiplies.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from this it is that the taste of blood appears in his mouth: either the tongue swells and expels blood.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from this it is that his sleep multiplies.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from this it is that he vomits in his sleep blood, redness, and froth, and spots like these.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we see any of these things, or even two or three days after the beginning of the month: we then order the cautery to be performed immediately, after two or three hours have passed.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of the Ventouse of the Neck is: because it itself causes weight in the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	It should remain in place after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is indeed the Ventouse of the Cephalic Phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to use it on those who are pale-faced or in whom there is discharge from the eyes.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it carries great danger with it.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	It is not permitted to use it on the elderly or in whom there is cold in the head
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	However, if it is used constantly, it will cause a blackening of the face
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And therefore it is necessary to warn the Ventouse-bearer to remove his hand with the wet hand towards the lower parts, fearing the production of blackness
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Ventouse or Alkehel is in the place of the phlebotomy of the Vein of the Fusae, and of the phlebotomy of the Basilica, and because of this it causes asma, and constriction of the chest, and splitting of the instruments of the chest, and cough, and distension.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to support the Ventouse of the Alkehel downwards, because if it is placed downwards, it causes stiffness of the heart and stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The Ventouse indeed causes headaches, pains in the head and the temples, swelling, dizziness, perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is in the place of the phlebotomy of the Basilica
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary for the Ventouse-bearer to be cautious not to tear the vein with the hand: so that it does not cause the flow of blood to be stopped
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The windbag, however, under the chin, brings the saliva to the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and like these there are other diseases which are in the mouth: and it is in the place of phlebotomy that these are.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The windbag, however, under the chin, brings the saliva to the mouth, and corruption of the gums, which is caused by reflection and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The windbag, however, of the two cavities of the jaws, brings the saliva to the mouth, and corruption of the gums, which is caused by reflection and heat: because it attracts blood from all these small veins which are in the flesh: and it attracts these small veins from other large veins which are in them, until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary, as regards the main wound, not to make it too deep: because the place is denuded of flesh, and under that are nerves and arteries
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The windbag which fills the cheeks brings haemorrhoids to the anus, and ulcers beneath the lower lip.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary, as regards the main wound, that the windbag should be large and open to the air: because the place needs strong suction, and perhaps the fine windbags will break: and it is necessary to make a great incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The small windbags of the limbs grow in number: because they draw blood from the whole body, and cause old pains in the bones and marrow, and veins: they provoke menstruation, and cause swelling, and stiffness: and they are in the place of the phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and the popliteal region.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body much, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The popliteal windbag is close to the wound of the two veins of the limbs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the veins is such that you should place the full stomach in the first incision, and perform suction with a tempered degree: and do not prolong the position of the stomach, but place it quickly, and move it quickly, so that the humors come to their proper place equally: and do not cease performing this until the place has become red and swollen, and the redness of the blood appears: then you should scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who has a lean body, little hair and few pores, it is sufficient to make one incision, not more: so as not to ulcerate the place
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the surgeon to make the incision wider, and to deepen it slightly: and to perform the suction gently and quickly, and with little movement of the hand
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is any thickness in the blood, then it is necessary to make two incisions.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first place, open a small opening for the drainage of the blood, and its evacuation: and in the second place, perform a precise incision for the extraction of the thick blood
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If the blood is black and fetid, then make a third incision: so as to achieve the end result
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract the blood slowly and little by little, it suffices for us to make one incision only.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to extract a lot of blood, we will make several incisions
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure, that the blood is thick: then it is necessary to make a deep incision: and the end point of the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is necessary to be administered from the oils concerning the position of the veins, and what is the cause of the swelling?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	When the skin is large, hard, and tough, and its pores are narrow, it is necessary to anoint with open oils, soothing and resolving: if it is in summer, such as almond oil or olive oil, or sweet fennel oil, or pumpkin seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in winter, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or camomile oil, or ivy: and such like these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If there is excessive fat that is cold: then use bitter almond oil, or balsam oil, or white oil, or alum oil: and such like these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.
