Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply ointments and unguents which are customary with us to heal wounds: thus as unguentum of tetrapharmacon, and the like.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it is fitting that you soften the ligaments.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And consider the wound every day in the morning and evening, until it is consolidated and healed
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	It is fitting that the limb be prepared in such a way that the pus should flow downwards with ease
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If many days pass before the wound is consolidated, and the pus does not separate: then you know that there are small bone fragments there.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	For you must inquire about the wound cautiously.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of these small fragments are separated, remove them, and extract them themselves
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And what remains of them which are not separated, and which puncture the limb, and cause pain, try to cut them out, and remove them in every possible way
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If a wound occurs, or an ulcer, or swelling, or any other corruption and putrefaction: then it is necessary to oppose each with that which agrees with it in respect of its treatment, of which account has been given in its chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And thus in this in which it is necessary to oppose it, you must have in your mind that which you make present to me when you break a bone and it hangs out from the limb, like the thighbone, and the joints, and the like of great limbs, for you must not imagine that it will draw on its own, for much harm thereby accrues from that liquid, indeed I would rather expel it than that it should putrefy.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps indeed it will fall away of itself after twenty days, or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then therefore care for the wound, if you see it: and otherwise, expel it.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	Note: The provided Latin text does not include any information about the care of nodulation in the case of a fractured bone, so I am unable to translate that part of the sentence.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	Many times this Nodulation occurs in the process of healing of a fractured bone.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially that which is near the sutures: and it is nourished from that figure of the limb
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps it hinders the limb from its natural operation.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Therefore consider in this, if nodulation exists: administer in it medicines which have astringency, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and the like of these
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Thus, take from these some, or all of them: and mix them with wine that is astringent, or with albumin or with vinegar: and apply them to the nodulation covered in wax, and bind them over the suture
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	Release the tension and do not delay treatment for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Resume treatment and repeat until the swelling subsides completely.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Or bind over the swelling a lead plate slightly askew from the center
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	Lead has the property of driving out everything that is harmful from the limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If, however, the swelling has already gone into the stone and is tightly bound, and excessive tension results: then find above the swelling from the upper part downwards, and cut away the excess: or ligate the swelling with some instruments, until it subsides: and care for the wound until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	When restoring, and the limb remains somewhat under tension even after this, do not follow the natural course of things.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.</start_of_turn>
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When restoring a fractured bone, and some tension remains in the limb even after treatment, it is weak: then it is not done except for serious reasons.</start_of_turn>
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	There are several reasons for this weakness: the excessive tension of the ligaments, the tying of the ligaments in an unnatural way, the excessive application of ointment that hinders the supply of nourishment to the limb, or the scarcity of blood in the body of the patient, and the weakness of the patient.</start_of_turn
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	The treatment of this is to nourish the patient and keep his body warm, until the blood supply to the limb is increased.</start_of_turn
Et administra balneum.	And apply a warm compress.</start_of_turn
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and gladness upon it.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then place pitch upon the limb: so that it attracts much nourishment to it.</start_of_turn
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	He diligently applies the ointment with warm water until the nourishment runs its course, and it returns to its natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	Until the nourishment has run its course.
Caput XXIII.	When restoring fractured bones to their original position.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When the fractured limb has been restored after healing, and the protruding bone or swelling: then the limb is bound up in such a way as not to impede its natural action; for it is not necessary to break the limb again.</start_of_turn>
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there are many proud doctors and restorers of limbs who have done this in our land.</start_of_turn>
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	This operation is very dangerous, causing death or great fear, for it is mortal.</start_of_turn
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the fracture and swelling are recent: then it is necessary to apply the ointment with warm water, in which are boiled softening herbs, such as rue leaves, and the root of this, and mellilotus, and similar things.</start_of_turn
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make a plaster with a softening plaster, such as gypsum made into a center.</start_of_turn
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or take the mucus of rue root, and mix it with chicken fat, or beeswax: and plaster with it.</start_of_turn
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or take colocynth seed, and grind it with poppy seed, and things of that kind which are mentioned by doctors to reduce consolidation.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And when the swelling has subsided with persistent and gentle friction, as happens with wet hands.</start_of_turn
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And movement of the limb is administered to every part at all times.</start_of_turn
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	If, however, a swelling has preceded it [the pain], and has become strong, and has been converted into a lap [swelling], and has been provoked by the necessity of its cure with fire: then it is necessary, that the upper part be severed, and the continuity of the bone be dissolved, and that which has supervened from the node or bone with fine scissors: and it is to be administered with ease, with attention and care.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	If, however, a swelling has preceded it, and has become strong, and has been converted into a lap, and has been provoked by the necessity of its cure with fire: then it is necessary, that the upper part be severed, and the continuity of the bone be dissolved, and that which has supervened from the node or bone with fine scissors: and it is to be administered with ease, with attention and care.
Caput XXIIII.	If, however, a swelling has preceded it, and has become strong, and has been converted into a lap, and has been provoked by the necessity of its cure with fire: then it is necessary, that the upper part be severed, and the continuity of the bone be dissolved, and that which has supervened from the node or bone with fine scissors: and it is to be administered with ease, with attention and care.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the exit of some parts from their place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Because it is prohibited from its movement, and deforms the figure of the limb.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And causes the occurrence of greater pain, and wounds which are dangerous to health
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When, therefore, such a dislocation has happened, then it is necessary to hasten to restore it: and do not delay at all
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if it is delayed, the place is spoiled, and perhaps with it the reduction of the dislocation itself
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Therefore it is not necessary to move, or extend it in the hour of its displacement
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	For it makes many times the spasm, and painful aches.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when it has happened, then it is necessary to prepare for bleeding of the limb.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then it is to be let go, until the displacement has subsided
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	Then the limb is bound with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it is reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And the whole limb is cared for with that which reminds it in its place
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I command you to keep the parts of dislocation in their place, also as it has been said in fracture, from the upper part of the body down to the lower part of it.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	About the care of the dislocation of the lower jaw
Caput XXV.	Chapter XXV.</start_of_turn>
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	The two mandibles are rarely displaced except in rare cases.</start_of_turn>
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the dislocation of both is done according to one of two methods.</start_of_turn
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they are moved from their places with a slight displacement, and are softened gently.</start_of_turn
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they are displaced completely, without displacement, until they are softened to the chest, until the pain has gone away, and it cannot bear to be closed, neither can it close the bone, and the tongue is involved with the speech.</start_of_turn
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	When the displacement is small, then it returns to its places by itself with little attention.</start_of_turn
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If however the displacement is complete, the whole: then it must be immediately administered the reduction of it without delay: and it is necessary that the head of the patient should remain still: and the physician should insert a finger of his hand into the root of the mandible which is displaced between the bones of the dislocation, if the dislocation is from one side.</start_of_turn
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or he may insert two fingers of his hand at the same time, if the dislocation is from both sides.</start_of_turn
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And the remaining fingers of his hand are outside, where they are equal.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And command the sick man to loosen his teeth and bite down on everything evenly
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	The doctor equalizes the jaw and urges the jaw until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If its reduction is difficult, especially if both jaws are together: then apply heat with warm water and oil, until the reduction becomes easy of both: do not reduce them both at once, as we have said
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they return and are equal, and the bone of the sick man is closed, and not softened: then place over the teeth of the pulp the cerate made from wax: and rose oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	And it is bound with ease with soft ligaments.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And the patient should sleep on his back: and his head should be resting between two pillows, so that he does not move it to the right or left: neither should he be forced or urged to chew anything: rather let him take a soft diet, until when he moves his pain subsides, and the jaw is relaxed: then he can eat what he wants, and this is administered with ease
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He does not suffer from the operation of his mouth during eating and drinking, and swallowing, until the jaw is relaxed and healed
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	If the reduction of both jaws is difficult, when they are displaced at some time, and do not return to their places: then many times arise from this fever and sourness: and perhaps the sickness of the patient is relieved, and perhaps vomiting of pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	When you have done this: then you know that it is a loss, and many times a man dies for whom this happened in ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On the reduction of the dislocation of the Furcula and the extremity of the humerus.
Caput XXVI.	On the reduction of the dislocation of the Furcula and the extremity of the humerus.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The Furcula does not dislocate from the inside outwards, because of its continuation with the breastbone.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	It dislocates sometimes outwards: and this is recognized by sense
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is that the patient lies with his back on the bed, and extends his arms
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then cover the place with your strong palm, for it will return by itself
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then put over it a compress, and sponges, and bind it tightly
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities of it which follow the elbow, and continue with it, do not dislocate, except rarely
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	If it dislocates on some day: then it is necessary that it be reduced and made even according to what has been said, and that it be prepared for you
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then put over it a compress, and sponges, and bind it tightly
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And command the patient to adhere to tranquility and quiet, until he is healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And when the extremity of the humerus has been reduced by this treatment, even when it is separated from its place
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	And concerning the reduction of the dislocation of the humerus
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	You know that the humerus does not dislocate, except according to three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	The first is that it dislocates to the part of the elbow downwards.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is that it dislocates to the part of the breastbone.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is displaced to the upper part of the Humerus: and this rarely occurs.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	And it does not displace to the posterior, because of the splatter.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it does not displace to the anterior, because of the nerves
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	And mostly it is displaced and comes down towards the lower side of the elbow: especially in those whose flesh is little
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Since it comes out quickly and goes in quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	In those in whom the flesh is much, it is contrary to this, namely because it comes out with difficulty and goes in with difficulty
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some people by a blow or an accident, and the Humerus is displaced by a hot after-effect, and it is thought because of this that it is displaced already.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	It is necessary therefore to try this until you are certain of its displacement, and then you can proceed with its treatment.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	And it is recognized as displaced when it comes down towards the elbow: and you will distinguish between a displaced Humerus and a sound Humerus.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you will find between these two a remarkable difference, and in the head of the Humerus a concavity, and under the elbow at the touch of the hand as if it were bone itself: and you cannot reduce the limb with a gentle hand, neither can you move it in any way
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	Likewise, if it is displaced towards the breast or upwards: then you will find a clear touch, neither hidden
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	And in these cases the displacement is easily reduced when it is recent, or when the limb is weak
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	And its reduction is such that it elevates the minister's hand to the upper parts.
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	And then place your thumbs under the edge of its [wound] and elevate the connecting tissue with strength upwards to its place: and the minister will elevate his hand and extend it upwards.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	And then place the lower part downwards, and he himself returns quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	If, however, it does not return by that which we have said, and if many days have passed since the dislocation occurred: then it is necessary to bathe the patient in warm water, and to apply an embolus which softens and smoothens, like the decoction of wild roses, and fennel, and meadowsweet in water, and to administer these things.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	And then the patient is laid on his back: and under his edge is placed a sphere and a bandage, which is equal between softness and tension
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	And then the physician places his heel on the sphere, and elevates the upper part of the arm with force, and pulls the patient's hand downwards.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	And another minister holds the patient's head, so that it does not move downwards: he himself returns immediately
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	And if necessary, reduce it in this way: make the strong hand which is longer than the patient to stand at the side and introduce the arm under the edge of the patient: and elevate the edge upwards until the patient is suspended in the air
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	And another minister pulls the patient's hand downwards into his belly
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	If, however, the patient is slight: then it is necessary to suspend it with something else, so as to ease him: for the dislocation returns immediately.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	And it is also reduced in another manner: thus it is formed in the earth a long stick whose head is rounded like a mortuary glove: which is neither thick nor thin.
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	And then it is placed under the patient after the linen has been placed over the head of the stick: and the patient shall be standing in accordance with the length of the stick
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	And then the hand is extended downwards from the other side, and the body is extended from the other side with force: for the joining returns to its place with speed.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	If its reduction is difficult by all that we have said, then take care of it thus: take a stick whose length is the quantity of two arms, and whose width is the quantity of four fingers, and whose thickness is the quantity of two fingers: whose head is rounded, in order to facilitate its entrance into the depth of the wound, according to this form
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	And then the linen is bound over the rounded head, so that it does not damage the sick stick.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	And then it is placed under the wound of the patient, so that the hand, or the arm, is extended over the stick until downwards: and the stick is bound over the aid and the arm and the extremity of the hand.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	And then the arm is placed over the step of the ladder for its width, and the hand is extended downwards, and the remainder of the body is let go from the other side.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	The joining enters immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	When thus the entrance is completed according to any possible method: then it is necessary that you place under the wound a sphere of equal quantity from wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	And then place a prepared plaster from pounded wheat with oil, and white of egg over the whole arm, as it is turned outwards.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	Then string under the thumb a stricture of decency: and the ligament will be returned over the palm above: and its hand shall be annexed to its column, and it shall be let go, neither shall its hand move for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	It is necessary to provide the patient with food, until comfort the limb: because it is faster for its healing.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	Then put on a wider dressing after seven days, or five, and take it off when it moves.
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	If it is firm and is not softened, then it is healed.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	If indeed the suture is loosened many times, because of the humidity that has happened to it, or because of another cause: then it is necessary that there be administered upon it cautery with three holes, according as it is prescribed in the chapter on cautery
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	If thus you do all this, and the ligament is dissolved after seven days, and the suture does not hold, and the palm and the stricture above it are reduced, and do not harden, and fall away, and do not raise themselves up: then you know that the nerves which are at the head of the humerus are either cut, or extended, or softened: and you know that the suture will never be fixed in its place
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	As for a dislocation which happens towards the breast and the nipple, or towards the back, it is reduced with a push and extension with the hands: until it returns, and there is administered in the rest stricture and care, until it is healed.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	If after healing there remains a degree of stiffness in the limb, and slowness in its movement: then the patient is to be bathed many times, until that stiffness is softened, and it returns to its former state
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	(The text provided does not include information regarding the cure of dislocation of the cubitus, so I cannot translate this portion.)
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	Know that the dislocation of the cubital bone is difficult, and returns with difficulty: and it dislocates to all parts, especially to the front or to the back.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	Its dislocation is not hidden: for it hangs loose under the skin and under the touch, according to whatever figure it is dislocated in
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	And when you join the dislocated cubital bone with the sound one, it is declared that it is manifest
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	It must be united again, and must not double the arm, nor touch it with the other arm
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you should promptly reduce the dislocation before a cold swelling should set in
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	For if a cold swelling should set in, its reduction becomes difficult: and it may not be healed at all, especially when it is at the back
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	It is bad in all species of dislocation, and of greater pain: and it descends with great swelling.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And its restoration when it is possible to reduce it, is that you extend the limb with two hands: and the arm be extended, and the hands of the physician be above the elbow and below it, and he himself urges the union with the thumbs of his hands together, or with the root of his palm, until it returns to its place
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	Or if the dislocation is to the front: then it returns in such a way that it doubles the hand with the hand, until it reaches the root of the palm of the hand which is dislocated
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	Which if it does not obey reduction, then manage violent extension, strength permitting: and it is that two assistants extend the limb: and they must hold it also, so that it does not move during the extension
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	Then the arm is returned to its entirety after the thumb has been wrapped over the hand with a doubled long bandage or a wide ligament.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	When the physician grasps the hand, let him moisten it with oil: that it may be slippery and facilitate the procedure.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	Then he impels the bandage with force until it returns
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	And afterwards, when the reduction has taken place, it is necessary to place over it a dressing which has styptic properties and which will dry out with alum: and the wound should be bound securely
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	The arm should be suspended from the collar of the patient: and it should be allowed to rest for a few days.
Deinde soluatur.	Then it is healed.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	If the bandage remains firm in its place, then the ligament must be divided from it and the thumb be allowed to rest
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	If the bandage has not been bound firmly, then repeat the dressing, the ligament and the thumb: and allow it to rest for a few days until it is bound securely
Deinde solue ipsam.	Then it is healed
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	If, however, there should be pain after the reduction of the bandage, and the limb should be still: then administer moisture in the bath, and gentle friction, and compression, until the limb is firm, or put on an ilium above the bandage, that is, a piece of sheep's wool.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	Then it is bound and allowed to rest day and night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	Then take away the bandage and immerse the limb in a bath
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	When it is sweating, then gently friction the bandage
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	And repeat over it once, twice and three times with the entrance of the bath, until it is softened
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	If desired, place upon the wound a cushion of wool, moist, warmed with butter, and bind over it.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	If desired. Place upon the wound a cushion of wool, moist, warmed with butter, and bind over it.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	The wound itself is softened, and returns to its natural state.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	From the treatment of dislocation of Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	The limb of Mahassem is much dislocated, that is, the juncture which is between the arm and the hand
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	And the reduction of its dislocation is easy
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	Except for the remaining joints
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	Truly, speed must be in the reduction of its dislocation in the hour in which it is dislocated, before it settles in another place: or it will happen that in that settling it will become stiff
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	And the reduction of its dislocation is like this: place the lower limb of Mahassem upon a board, and extend the limb of the hand: and the physician places his palm upon the prominence of the juncture and urges it until it returns
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	Truly, it must be considered that if the palm has receded towards the belly of the hand: then the infirm person places the back of his hand upon the board at the extension and reduction: and if the dislocation is proceeding towards the back of the hand, then the position of the hand is inside the board, that is, the inner part of the hand is placed upon the board, so that the hand of the physician rests upon the prominence of the juncture
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	If it returns immediately, that is good: and if not, then bind the limb with a dressing while it is settling: and let it go, and do not do it again.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	If he will not tolerate it, neither will the flesh tolerate a reduction after these days; for truly the suture will remain according to the tortuousness of its situation: and it does not harm the sick man anything, except that it soothes the hand, and it is not possible to tighten anything: then you know that the nerves are severed, or bruised.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	There is no wit in that, except that it be tied with cautery close to the case of its situation.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	And perhaps it will not do anything at all.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	When the Almahassem does not return, then place above it a covering, as we have narrated
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	Then it is to be tied, and let go in five days: afterwards it is to be dissolved and let go, and the hand is to be exercised.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	If however its movement is prevented in it, and anything heavy occurs in it: then soften it with warm water, and with gentle friction, until it is softened
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	Of the treatment of dislocation of the fingers.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	When the finger is dislocated from the bone towards the whole part, or from the bone towards the back of the palm, or towards the belly of the hand: then extend the finger, and push the dislocation gently with your thumbs, until it returns
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	Then support the head of the finger, and suspend it over the part from which it is dislocated, and let it go in two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	Then suspend it, and extend it, until it is equal to its proper position in that day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	When night comes, bind it according to the account given: and do not cease to loosen it daily: and exercise it with movement: and bind it at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	Do it for a few days until it is strung together.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	Do it in like manner for a few days until it is bound together.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	Do it in like manner when it is displaced to the other side.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	From the treatment of dislocation of the cervical vertebrae.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1.
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	When it happens to anyone that the cervical vertebra is completely displaced, or many of them are displaced from their places: then it is not in this treatment, for the moisture favors the sick person
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	And the sign of it is that the sickness goes out without being willing, neither can he keep it: and many times they soften a part of his body from that, or two limbs, or two arms, or one of them: or they displace one vertebra from its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	Many times they displace it because many times there is displacement of them to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	That which is displaced to the back is called gibbosity
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	The treatment of it is, indeed, that they are united together again when the gibbosity happens from infancy: then there is no healing from it at all
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	However, what happened in the case, or by percussion, or in a like manner, the ancients said of ancient methods of treatment in a long speech
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	Of which many do not return when they are proficient
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	I myself, however, have abbreviated from that, because of the many things that are close to me in this matter: and the exposition that I have made which exposes this thing, and the instrument that I have composed in a diverse way from that which they have shown.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	I say therefore, that which happens in the body from the anterior part, is neither ingenuity nor healing.
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	Likewise, whatever happens on either side is also not ingenuity or healing.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	It does not heal from the outside, except that which happens in its own depth, as I have said: that the sick man be extended over his face towards the equal ledge near the wall, and that there be applied over him a moist dressing, so that his chest is not injured thereby.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	Then let a fixed rod be placed in the fire in the ground, at the foot, round about the head: and let another rod be placed round about the feet at the other foot: and let the minister hold the rod, and let it not be fixed in the fire
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	And let the other minister hold the other one.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	Then stretch over the head of the sick man, and under his toes, a soft ligament, firm: and extend the extremity of the ligament to the rod which is at his head: and bind it in that place
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	And bind another ligament above his shoulders, and above his knees, and at his hips.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	Then gather up all the ligaments and bind them to the other rod which is at his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	Then let all the ministers extend to the part of the limb of the ligaments, and do not move the two rods from their places where they are fixed: indeed they are not fixed, as we said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	And the doctor places his palms upon the spine with strength, until he recovers: or places them upon a board.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	Then he connects upon the board his feet until he recovers
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	But if he does not recover by this treatment, then take a board whose length is about three arms long.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	And the cavity in the wall from which we have spoken, which is close to the patient, is the place where the extremity of the board enters.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	Then place the middle of the board over the Spondilem.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	And let the physician put his feet on the other extremity
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	And bind firmly, until Spondilis is taut, and return to his place.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	And if you wish, work with the ankle which is involved with your hand: and it is that the heel of the patient lies in the earth between two boards which are as long as an arm at the shoulder: and at the head of these two boards between the heel and the two boards is the heel of the ankle itself
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	And the length which is between all the boards is the palm of one hand: and thus it is made in every place where there is a passage of the bone: and fix all the boards firmly to the earth, so that nothing moves at all
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	And insert a round board: and it is the bone which revolves the ligament in two holes of the two boards.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	And at the extremity of it is a hole in which the board is fixed, which is as long as the palm together with that which revolves: and in two other boards it is like that
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	And bind the ligaments which you have bound in the chest of the patient around the ankle which is at the head of it: and the ligaments which you have bound in the thighs of the patient around the ankle which is at the feet of it
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	And remain at every turn of the minister who is turning his hand with a wrench, with which the bone is revolved: and the physician will equal Spondilis, as we have said
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	This is the form of the turn which follows
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	Then, when Spondilis has returned and the place is evened, it is necessary to apply a plaster cast with albumin or urine.
Deinde stuppam.	Then, apply the plaster cast.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	And place above the plaster cast a bandage of three fingers' width, or thereabouts
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	And the length of it should be as much as to cover the part of Gibbositatis and above the healthy part of Spondilis
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	And it is bound with the bandage we mentioned above
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	And the patient should be given a nourishing diet until he has recovered.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	If anything remains swollen in the place at the end of healing: then it is necessary to administer medicines that soften and soothe, with the use of the plaster cast that we mentioned previously for a long time
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	And in that layer of lead is administered
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	And when swelling occurs in the posterior Spondilium dorsi: and it is believed to be dislocation, and that is the bone that is now protruding
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	Therefore it is not right to assume for it any medicine: for perhaps thereby it will cause death
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	¶ On the treatment of a dislocated Anchae.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter XII.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	Know that dislocations of the Anchae, and of the humerus, do not occur except for a violent dislocation: neither do they occur except for a slight displacement and a concavity
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	And the dislocation of the Anchae is divided into four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	That is, because it is displaced forward and backward
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	Most often, the dislocation is inward: slightly less often, it is forward, and least of all backward.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	The treatment of such an inward dislocation is: because when you unite the limb of the sick with the limb of the healthy, the latter is longer: and the knee of the sick is more prominent than that of the healthy, and he cannot double up his foot at the ankle: and this is the place which follows the ankle after the heel has slipped over the heel of the other limb, because the head of the thigh has already gone there.</start_of_turn>
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	The sign of such an outward dislocation is that there are injuries to the limb which are contrary to these injuries.</start_of_turn>
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	The sign of such a forward dislocation is that it expands the healthy limb along the whole extent: truly, it does not double itself without pain at the knee: and if he attempts to walk, he cannot go beyond this forward: and he retains his urine, and his heel slips over his ankle, and there is swelling in his walking.</start_of_turn
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	The sign of such a backward dislocation is that neither the knee nor the ankle expands: neither can he double up his limb before he doubles his ankle: and his limb is even shorter than the other: and his ankle is soft, and the head of the thigh is at the level of the hip.</start_of_turn
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	The reduction of such a dislocation is a difficult thing, so that if the dislocation is old, which has been there for a long time, it becomes fixed with the limb itself.</start_of_turn
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	Then if you perform the reduction and it remains in its place: then there is no longer any treatment in that case.</start_of_turn>
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	It is not right therefore to suppose that it is sufficient.</start_of_turn
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	In that case in which the dislocation is fixed, and is one of the four kinds of dislocation: then it is proper for you to join the limb and extend it both forward and backward, and to move the limb from side to side: perhaps thereby the dislocation will be reduced, and no other treatment will be necessary.</start_of_turn
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	If it does not return in this manner, then it is necessary that you prepare a strong minister and extend his leg from the lower part: either with the hands alone or with a ligature which is bound above the knee: and another minister extends his hand above, so that he may insert his hand under the tiles of his leg.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	Then string it with a soft ligature over the root of the hip, and hold the extremity of the other ligature.
Et sit extensio eius aut ab anteriori parte inguinis ad partem furculae, aut a posteriori ad partem dorsi.	And let the extension be either from the front part of the groin to the part of the buttocks, or from the back to the part of the back
Et sit extensio eorum omnium uice una, donec eleuetur infirmus cum corpore suo a terra, et remaneat pendens.	And let the extension be all at once, until the patient is lifted with his body from the earth, and remains hanging
Et haec enim species extensionis est species communis specierum quatuor.	And this is one of the common kinds of extension of four kinds.
Si ergo redit dislocatio cum eo quod diximus, est bonum: et si non, tunc necesse est omni speciei illud quod dicam de curatione propria.	If, therefore, the dislocation returns with this, it is good: and if not, then it is necessary to use every kind of treatment which we mentioned concerning proper care.
In reductione quidem eius propria quando dislocatio est ad interiora, oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super latus suum sanum.	In reduction, however, of its own when the dislocation is towards the inside, it is necessary that the patient be placed upon his sound side.
Deinde ponat ligamentum super radicem coxae, in eo quod est inter caput coxae, et locum qui est sub inguine.	Then lay a ligament upon the root of the hip, in that place which is between the head of the hip and the groin.
Deinde extende ligamentum ad sursum a parte inguinis ad altiorem partem corporis, ad partem furculae.	Then extend the ligament upwards from the groin to the upper part of the body, to the part of the buttocks
Deinde accipiat minister alius fortis brachia eius, et minuat locum grossum coxae infirmae, et extendat ad exteriora extensione uehementi.	And another minister takes a strong arm and grasps the thick part of the lower hip, and extends it outwards with the extension mentioned above.
Iam enim redit ad locum suum.	And thus it returns to its place.
Et haec species est facilioris reliquis speciebus curationis, qua reducitur hoc membrum.	And this kind is easier than the rest of the treatments by which this limb is reduced
Si autem excusatur super te, et non obedit tibi ad introitum cum hac specie curationis omnino: tunc oportet, ut ligentur duo pedes infirmi simul cum ligamento forti, leni, super duos calcaneos, et super duo genua: et sit longitudo cuiusque a compare suo quantitatis quatuor digitorum: et sit crus infirmum extensum plus altero quantitate duorum digitorum.	If, however, he excuses himself from thee, and doth not obey thy order to enter with this kind of treatment: then it is necessary, that two feet of the patient be bound together with a strong, soft ligament, over two calcanei, and over two knees: and that the length of each be equal to four fingers; and that the diseased limb be extended more than the other by two fingers' breadth.
Deinde suspendatur infirmus super caput ligni, quod sit in domo: et sit longitudo eius a terra quantitas duorum brachiorum.	The diseased limb is then suspended over the head of the ligament, which is in the house: and its length from the ground is equal to the quantity of two arms.
Deinde praecipe iuueni forti, ut muniat caput coxae: et suspendatur cum infirmo inuenis alius: et impellat iuuenis alius, muniens coxam cum fortitudine, nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	Then command the strong youth to grasp the hip: and suspend it with the patient together: and the youth grasps the other, grasping the hip with force, for the ligament returns to its place with speed.
In reditione autem eius propria, quando est dislocatio ad exteriora, oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super podium, secundum quod narrauimus in habente gibbositatem.	But when its dislocation is outwards, it is necessary that the patient lie upon a board, as we have said in the case of a gibbosity.
Et stringatur ligamentum super crus eius, infirmum proprie, et super pectus eius.	And the ligament is bound over the limb itself, and over the breast.
Deinde ponantur duo ligna, unum apud pedes eius, et alterum apud caput ipsius.	Then two boards are laid, one at his feet, and the other at his head.
Deinde ponatur lignum additum in medio podii, fixum bene: super quod inuoluti sint panni humidi, ut non laedat infirmum: et sit lignum inter coxas eius, ut non attrahatur ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then a board is laid in the middle of the foot, fixed well: over which are laid wet cloths, that they do not hurt the patient: and let the board rest between his thighs, so that it does not be drawn downwards during extension.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem suam, et medicus aequet reductionem manu sua.	Then extend all the limbs to their proper parts, and the physician equalizes the reduction with his hand.
Si ergo obedit ad reuersionem, erit bonum.	If, therefore, he obeys towards restoration, it will be good.
Et si non, pone super ipsam tabulam, et preme ipsam, sicut diximus in gibbositate, aequaliter.	And if not, place upon his head a board, and press it down, as we said in the case of a gibbosity, equally
Verumtamen oportet, ut iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	The patient must lie upon his healthy side.
Et quando dislocatio est ad anteriora, tunc oportet, ut extendatur crus infirmi uelociter: et est secundum hanc eandem narrationem super podium: et ponat medicus palmam manus suae dextrae super inguen infirmum.	When the dislocation is forward, then it is necessary to extend the limb of the patient quickly: and it is in accordance with this that the physician places his right hand upon the patient's knee
Deinde coartet ipsum cum manu altera, et cum illa coartatione pone ipsum extensum ad inferiora ad partem genu.	Then he grasps the limb with the other hand and, with that embrace, he stretches it downwards to the ankle
Et si dislocatio est ad posteriora: tunc non oportet, ut extendatur infirmus ad inferiora, et sit eleuatus super terram: imo oportet, ut sit positus super rem duram, sicut oportet, ut fit etiam si dislocatur ancha eius ad exteriora, secundum illud quod diximus de accubitu eius super duas anchas: et est super faciem eius, et ligamenta extensa: secundum quod diximus nuper.	If the dislocation is backwards, then it is not necessary to stretch the limb downwards, but rather to elevate it above the ground: indeed it is necessary to place it upon a firm support, as it is also done if the dislocation is wide outwards, as we mentioned above concerning the recumbent position.
Et oportet, ut administretur compressio cum tabula etiam super locum ad quem egreditur iunctura, cum completur reductio secundum quod oportet.	It is necessary to apply a compress also with a board upon the place where the fracture has been reduced, until the reduction is complete.
Et signum reditionis eius non occultatur tibi: et est, ut extendas duo crura infirmi: et quando uides ea aequalia, et infirmus stringit crus suum, et expandit ipsum absque excusatione: tunc scias, quia iam redit membrum, secundum quod oportet: tunc coniunge duas coxas, et pone emplastrum, et stringe cum imemati, id est, rota: ita, ut non moueatur ancha ad aliquam partium: et adhaereat infirmus quieti tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	And the sign of its reduction is not hidden: when you extend both limbs of the patient and when he tightens his limb and expands it without pain: then you know that the limb has been reduced, as it should be: then join the two thighs and apply a dressing, and bind with a bandage, that is, by rotation: so that it does not move to any part: and let the patient rest quietly for three days, or four.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et emplastrum, et compara crus cum altero: tunc si uides ea aequalia in statu, tunc scias, quod dislocatio iam firmata est: absolue ergo infirmum ad ambulandum.	Then loosen the ligament and the dressing, and compare the limb with the other: then if you find them equal in position, you know that the dislocation is fixed: absolutely so let the patient walk again.
Et si uides aliquid mollificationis: tunc redi, et emplastra illud, et stringe illud secundum stricturam tuam primam: et dimitte illud etiam tribus diebus.	If you see any softening: then repeat the reduction, and apply the dressing once more, and bind it as before: and leave it for three days.
Deinde solue illud et fac ipsum tardare in ambulatione super utrumque aliquot diebus, donec confortetur bene.	Then solve that and make it tardy in walking on both sides for a few days, until it is comfortable.
¶ De dislocationis Genu.	Until it is comfortable.
Caput XXXIII.	Until it is comfortable.
Genu dislocatur secundum tres modos.	Until it is comfortable
Dislocatur ad exteriora, ad interiora, et ad inferiora, scilicet ad posteriora.	Until it is comfortable
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora.	Until it is comfortable
Et signum dislocationis eius, est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut applicet crus suum ad coxam suam.	Until it is comfortable
Si autem non adhaeret cum coxa: tunc scias, quod Genu est dislocatum.	Until it is comfortable
Et restauratio omnium modorum dislocationis eius est, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum, ita ut iam extendat crus suum si potest super illud, et adhaeret dorsum tuum ad faciem eius: et pone pedem eius inter pedes tuos.	Until it is comfortable
Deinde adhaerere fac Genu eius cum palmis tuis, et recta eas inter digitos tuos super Genu eius.	Until it is comfortable
Deinde applica cum palma tua duo latera Genu eius cum fortitudine.	Until it is comfortable
Et minister alius extendat pedem eius, donec redeat Genu ad locum suum.	Until it is comfortable
Et signum reditionis est, ut adhaereat crus cum coxa in lenitate, non laboriose.	Until it is comfortable
Deinde emplastra ipsum, et adhaerere fac crus cum coxa.	Until it is comfortable
Deinde liga ea simul cum uitta tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Until it is comfortable
Deinde solue ea.	Until it is comfortable.
Et non utatur infirmus ambulatione aliquot diebus, donec sanetur.	Until it is comfortable
Si autem recusatur tibi reductio eius, tunc administra extensionem fortem cum ligamentis, quorum praecessit narratio in curatione anchae, donec redeat.	Until it is comfortable
¶ De curatione dislocationis Calcanei.	Until it is comfortable
Caput XXXIIII.	Until it is comfortable
Calcaneus quandoque remouetur remotione parua, et quandoque dislocatur secundum complementum.	Until it is comfortable
Et dislocatio eius fit, aut ad interiora, aut ad exteriora.	Either the dislocation is towards the interior, or towards the exterior.
Et signum dislocationis eius est, quod uides Calcaneum inflatum, procedentem ad partem ad quam dislocatur.	The sign of dislocation is that the calcaneus is swollen, proceeding towards the part from which it is dislocated.
Curatio autem remotionis eius, est facilis reditionis: et est, ut extendatur cum facilitate cum manibus, et aequetur, donec redeat.	The treatment for the removal of the dislocation is easy restoration: it is to extend with ease with the hands, and to straighten out, until it returns to its place
In curatione autem eius quando dislocatur secundum complementum, oportet, ut facias sedere infirmum rectum: et teneat ipsum minister fortis ualde a posteriori parte dorsi eius, in medio ipsius.	In the treatment of the dislocation when it is displaced according to the rule, it is necessary to make the patient sit upright: and hold him firmly from behind the back of his back, in the middle of his body.
Deinde tene tu cum manu tua dextra pedem eius a superiori parte eius, et cum manu tua sinistra ab inferiori parte pedis eius loco cauillae.	Then hold your right hand the upper part of his foot, and your left hand from the lower part of his foot at the ankle bone.
Deinde trahe pedem ad tecum manu tua dextra.	Then draw the foot towards you with your right hand
Deinde cum sinistra duabus uicibus.	And with your left hand support both ankles.
Deinde extende cum sinistra, et impelle pectus pedis cum dextra uersus crus absque labore.	Then extend with your left hand, and push the ankle with your right hand without pain
Fac illud bis, sicut narrauimus.	Do this twice as we have said.
Deinde impelle pectus pedis ad crus in uice tertia, et tu trahis cauillam.	Then push the ankle towards the knee in the third space, and you pull the heel.
Si ergo redit in uice una, aut in duabus secundum hunc modum, et uides pedem aequatum, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera operationem super ipsum: quoniam ipse redit.	If it returns in one space, or in two according to this method, and you see the foot is equal, it is good: and if not, do the operation again over it: because it will return
Si autem prohibetur tibi reductio eius cum eo quod narrauimus: tunc fac iacere infirmum super dorsum suum super terram, et fige paxillum in terra firmatum ualde, ut cadat inter coxas eius: et tu iam inuoluisti super ipsum pannum, ut non laedat infirmum.	If, however, it is forbidden for you to reduce it as we have said: then make the patient lie on his back on the earth, and fix the heel firmly on the ground, under the buttocks: and put a cushion under his thighs so that it lies between his thighs: and I will support over it above the ankle, so that it does not pain the patient.
Deinde accipiat minister coxam eius: postea extendat minister alter pedem, aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento quod liget super collum pedis.	Then he will grasp the coxal bone of the minister: afterwards he will extend the other minister's foot, either with his hands or with a ligament which binds over the ankle of the foot.
Deinde extendat omnis minister contra extensionem comparis sui: et paxillus sit stans inter duas coxas infirmi retinens eum, ut non attrahatur corpus eius ad inferiora apud extensionem.	Then he will extend all the ministers against the extension of their companion: and the little toe will be stable between the two coxae of the patient, retaining him, so that it does not draw the body towards the lower parts during the extension.
Deinde aequet medicus dislocationem manibus suis, et minister alter teneat crus sanum ad inferiora.	Then the doctor will equalize the dislocation with his hands, and the other minister will hold the sound limb towards the lower parts.
Nam dislocatio redit cum uelocitate.	For the dislocation returns with speed.
Quando ergo redit dislocatio, et declaratur tibi sanitas reditionis eius: tunc pone emplastrum et stuppam, et stringe ipsam cum ligamentis firmiter, et liga pedem cum ligamento ad crus.	When the dislocation has returned, and it is declared that the limb is in a state of restoration: then put on a compress and a bandage, and bind the limb firmly with ligaments, and bind the foot with a ligament to the ankle
Et oportet, ut caueas uel timeas de neruis, qui sunt supra calcaneum posterius, ut non sit ligamentum super eos uehemens, et laedat eos.	And it is necessary that you beware of the nerves that are above the heel behind, so that there is no tension on the ligaments over them, and that you do not damage them
Deinde dimitte ipsum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then let him go in two or three days
Quod si mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum: deinde solue ipsum in die tertio, aut quarto: et prohibe infirmum ab ambulatione quadraginta diebus.	If the ligament is softened, bind it: then solve it on the third or fourth day: and prohibit the patient from walking for forty days.
Si uero conatur ambulare ante illud spacium, non fit securitas quin dissoluatur super ipsum dislocatio, et corrumpatur, et non recipiat post illud curationem.	If he attempts to walk before that time, there will be no security that the dislocation will be dissolved above and not be damaged, and it will not recover after that time
Quod si accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc oportet, ut administres in sedatione eius illud, in quo praecessit narratio nostra in alio loco ex curatione, et embrocationem, donec remoueatur.	If there is a swelling of the heel: then it is necessary that you administer in sedation for it that in which it was mentioned in the story before concerning the treatment, and embrocation, until it is resolved
¶ De dislocatione Digitorum pedis, et cura.	Of the dislocation of the toes of the foot, and their care.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter V.
Oportet, ut aequetur quod dislocatur ex eis cum extensione pauca absque labore: et illud quidem non est difficile, imo est facile.	The head should be adjusted so that it becomes level with the dislocation of the bone from its place without excessive effort: this is not difficult, indeed it is easy.
Si autem dislocatio est in quibusdam nodis dorsi pedis: tunc oportet, ut faciat sedere infirmus pedem suum super locum aequalem terrae, aut super tabulam: et est stans sicut ambulans.	If, however, the dislocation is in some knot of the back or foot: then it is necessary to make the patient sit down with the affected limb resting on the ground or on a board: and thus it is as if he were walking
Deinde tu sta, et pone pedem tuum super illud quod eminet ex illis iuncturis.	Then stand up, and place your foot upon that which projects from the joints
Deinde calca illud cum pede tuo cum uirtute, donec redeat, et uideas ipsum iam aequatum, et non appareat in loco eminentia.	Then step upon it with your foot with force, until it returns to its place, and let it be seen to be level, and not to project outwards.
Deinde pone sub uentre pedis eius tabulam quae capiat pedem totum, cui sint duo capita.	Then place under the foot a board which will hold the foot entirely, having two heads.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti tribus diebus.	And bind it with a bandage three days in a row.
Deinde solue ipsum, et fac quiescere eum ab ambulatione diebus multis, donec stringatur et securetur a reductione.	Then loosen it, and make it rest from walking for many days, until it is bound up and secured from reduction
¶ De speciebus dislocationis cum uulnere uel fractura.	And concerning the species of dislocation with wound or fracture
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit aliquid ex illo, et conaris curationem eius, et ipsius restaurationem, multotiens succedit mors: et propter illud non oportet, ut praesumat super curationem eius, quod est huiusmodi, nisi qui est prudens in arte longi usus, misericors, pius, tardus, non audax, neque praesumptuosus: et ut utatur in incaeptionce medicinis quae sedant apostemata calida tantum: et dimittat infirmum diuino iudicio.	When anything has happened, and you know the cure and the restoration of it, many times success follows: and because of this it does not be necessary to rush over the cure, which is of this sort, except for one who is prudent in the art of long practice, merciful, pious, tardy, not daring, and not rash: and that he should make use of the advice of physicians who sit around the sickbed only for warmth: and let the patient go with the judge's decision.
Nisi uideas, aut speras salutem a perditione cum lenitate aegritudinis, et in quo apparet quiddam spei.	Unless you believe, or hope for recovery with the gentleness of treatment, and in which there appears some hope.
Conare ergo reductionem eius statim in principio rei, antequam accidat apostema calidum.	To attempt a reduction immediately at the outset of the case, before the swelling becomes hardened.
Si ergo redit membrum, secundum quod uolumus, tunc administra regimen quod sedat apostema: et cura uulnus cum eo quod conuenit ei ex unguentis desiccatiuis.	If the limb returns, as we desire, then administer a regimen that will quiet the swelling: and care for the wound with those things which are appropriate to it from among the desiccant unguents.
Quod si dislocatio est cum fractura, et accidunt in osse satagiae separatae, tunc conare ablationem earum, et fac in illo quod diximus in aegritudinibus simplicibus ex eo quod praecessit in locis earum.	If the dislocation is with a fracture, and they are separated from the socket, then attempt to ablate them, and do in that what we said in the simple rules concerning these things in their place.</start_of_turn>
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, et custodi teipsum ab introitu in uiam timoris: secundum quod praecessit praedicatio mea tibi.	And be cautious according to your skill, and take care of yourself from the entrance into the danger: according to what I have predicted to you.</start_of_turn>
Nam illud est melius tibi apud Creatorem tuum, et magis permanens ad gloriam tuam, et magis saluum tuo corpori apud illos in tuo tempore.	For it is better for you with the Creator of all things, and more lasting for your glory, and more health for your body in this life.</start_of_turn>
